column14: Howard Waterfall Cave, Trenton, Dade County, Georgia
column23: I found on female M. leibii (Univ. Georgia no. 2749) in Howard Waterfall Cave, Trenton, Dade County, Georgia. This individual was in the same room with four solitary Pipistrellus subflavus.
column34: Wilson Baker W. Myotis leibii leibii in Georgia. Journal of Mammalogy. 1967 Feb 20;48(1):142.

column14: Howard Waterfall Cave, Trenton, Dade County, Georgia

column14: Howard Waterfall Cave, Trenton, Dade County, Georgia
column23: I found on female M. leibii (Univ. Georgia no. 2749) in Howard Waterfall Cave, Trenton, Dade County, Georgia. This individual was in the same room with four solitary Pipistrellus subflavus...I considered two species to be using the same roost site if they were within 0.5 m of each other
column34: Wilson Baker W. Myotis leibii leibii in Georgia. Journal of Mammalogy. 1967 Feb 20;48(1):142.

column14: eastern Peruvian Andes and in the adjacent lowlands.
column23: However, the discovery of a small hole in a slender fig (Ficus) tree occupied by Noctilio albiventris and Myotis simus was exceptional in that the occupants were members of different families. This discovery also was exceptional in the degree that the species were associated. The walls of the small cavity (25 by 25 by 30 cm) were covered with about equal numbers (30) of both species roosting in close contact with no apparent subdivision of the site.
column34: Graham 1988. Interspecific associations among Peruvian bats at diurnal roost and roost sites. Journal of Mammalogy, 69:711-720.

column23: Carollia brevicauda and C. perspicillata used the same hole in a tree (J. L. Patton, pers. comm.) but their positions inside the hole were not observed (Tuttle, 1970).

column23: Negative interspecific interactions.-I observed an agonistic interaction for only one pair of species. An individual Carollia perspicillata in a small room deep in a large cave made two unsuccessful attempts to land on a small knob on the ceiling occupied by three L. handleyi on the other side of the room. The Lonchophylla resisted the attempts and an individual chased the Carollia back to the other side of the room.
column34: Graham 1988. Interspecific associations among Peruvian bats at diurnal roost and roost sites. Journal of Mammalogy, 69:711-720.

column14: 9 small woodlands between Utrecht and Hilversum  (52810'N, 5810'E)
column23: Roost choice of both bat species was similar except that Daubenton's bats used woodpecker cavities less than noctules. Both bat species were selective in their roost choice. Daubenton's bats preferred oaks over beeches, and noctules preferred woodpecker cavities over naturalcavities, indicating dependence on woodpeckers. Both bat species preferred to roost close to the edge of the wood. Roosting close to the edge of the wood may reduce commuting Øight costs for both species or maybe preferable for thermoregulatory reasons.
column34: Boonman, M. 2000. Roost selection by noctules (Nyctalus noctula) and Daubenton's bats (Myotis daubentonii). Journal of Zoology (London), 251: 385- 389.

column14: Centro de EstudosAmbientais e Desenvolvimento Sustentável (CEADS-UERJ) biological station on the tropical island of IlhaGrande in southeastern Brazil
column23: From another house-root on Ilha Grande(approximately 1 km from the schoolhouse), we capturedsix individuals ofM. molossus.
column34: Dick CW, Esbérard CE, Graciolli G, Bergallo HG, Gettinger D. Assessing host specificity of obligate ectoparasites in the absence of dispersal barriers. Parasitology Research. 2009 Oct;105(5):1345-9.

column14: Centro de EstudosAmbientais e Desenvolvimento Sustentável (CEADS-UERJ) biological station on the tropical island of IlhaGrande in southeastern Brazil
column23: IndividualM. rufusandPhyllostomus hastatus(Pallas) were collected from the atticof an old school building, which had been converted intoliving quarters. Daytime surveys revealedP. hastatusroosting in two spatially separate groups; one was a haremof females, with a single (or at most, a few) large male(s);the other consisted of only bachelor males (see alsoMcCracken and Bradbury1981; McCracken and Wilkinson2000). On 30 September 2007, we visited the roost duringthe night (within 1 hour of dusk) when thePhyllostomuswere out foraging. During this time, we encountered a smallgroup of about 12 individualM. rufusin the preciselocation where the females ofPhyllostomuswere observedduring daytime. EightM. rufuswere live-captured usinglong forceps. On 1 October 2007, we returned to theroost during the daytime and captured 17 individuals ofP. hastatus.
column34: Dick CW, Esbérard CE, Graciolli G, Bergallo HG, Gettinger D. Assessing host specificity of obligate ectoparasites in the absence of dispersal barriers. Parasitology Research. 2009 Oct;105(5):1345-9.

The day lodges where we were able to capture it are the hollow trunks of large trees] such as baobab (Adansonia digitata) or cheese (Ceiba pentendra) of termite hills ovidoes  by warthog,  wells or even  simple holes in the ground. The colonies  are never very large,  sometimes 2 or 3 individuals,  generally from 10 to 20, rarely more than fifty.

column23: Colonies of N. thebaica are of the same size as those of N. macrotis and are found in dwellings (millet granaries) where they were ecologically related to N. gambiensis as well as in hollow trees (baobabs) where they were either monospecific, or ecologically related to N. ma crotis. This species seems to present a certain anthropophilia, at least in the choice of its diurnal roost.
column34: Adam and Hubert, 1976. Les Nycteridae (Chiroptera) du Senegal: distribution, biometric, et dimorphis mesexueI. Mammalia, 40:597~13.

column23: During hibernation (December-March) only two specimens were captured, both were torpid bats from holes cut in trees (Table 2).
column34: Alcalde, J. 1999. New ecological data on the noctule bat (Nyctalus noctula Schreber, 1774) (Chiroptera, Vespertiliondae) in two towns of Spain. Mammalia, 63: 273-280.

column23: Most of the 56 shelters of noctule bats (48 in Pamplona and eight in San guesa) were cavities in trees, except seven, which were crevices in a big wall. Along with common noctules, this wall housed some common pipisrelles (Pipistrellus pipistrellus) and Leisler's bats (Nycteris leisleri), although the different species never occupied the roost at the same time n the same fissure. The trees used as shelters by the noctules belong to different species: 14 shelters were in horse chestnuts (Aesculus hippocastanum), 14 in white poplar (Populus alba), 12 in common ash (Fraxinus excelsior), five in poplar (Populus nigra), two in tree of Heaven (Ailanthis altissima), one in sycamore maple (Acer psendoplatanus) and one in London plane (Platanus hispanica). The 74.5% of occupied shelters were located near streams and river banks. During the perios of the study ar least 12 old trees had noctule bats have been cut. In Sanguesa all the shelters were situated in white poars growing  in a park neat the Aragon River. In Pamplona, however, shelters were more varies and were distributed among several wooden areas of the town (Figure 2).
column34: Alcalde, J. 1999. New ecological data on the noctule bat (Nyctalus noctula Schreber, 1774) (Chiroptera, Vespertiliondae) in two towns of Spain. Mammalia, 63: 273-280.

column23: Most of the 56 shelters of noctule bats (48 in Pamplona and eight in San guesa) were cavities in trees, except seven, which were crevices in a big wall. The trees used as shelters by the noctules belong to different species: 14 shelters were in horse chestnuts (Aesculus hippocastanum), 14 in white poplar (Populus alba), 12 in common ash (Fraxinus excelsior), five in poplar (Populus nigra), two in tree of Heaven (Ailanthis altissima), one in sycamore maple (Acer psendoplatanus) and one in London plane (Platanus hispanica). The 74.5% of occupied shelters were located near streams and river banks. During the perios of the study ar least 12 old trees had noctule bats have been cut. In Sanguesa all the shelters were situated in white poars growing  in a park neat the Aragon River. In Pamplona, however, shelters were more varies and were distributed among several wooden areas of the town (Figure 2).
column34: Alcalde, J. 1999. New ecological data on the noctule bat (Nyctalus noctula Schreber, 1774) (Chiroptera, Vespertiliondae) in two towns of Spain. Mammalia, 63: 273-280.

column23: Most of the 56 shelters of noctule bats (48 in Pamplona and eight in San guesa) were cavities in trees, except seven, which were crevices in a big wall. Along with common noctules, this wall housed some common pipisrelles (Pipistrellus pipistrellus) and Leisler's bats (Nycteris leisleri), although the different species never occupied the roost at the same time n the same fissure. The trees used as shelters by the noctules belong to different species: 14 shelters were in horse chestnuts (Aesculus hippocastanum), 14 in white poplar (Populus alba), 12 in common ash (Fraxinus excelsior), five in poplar (Populus nigra), two in tree of Heaven (Ailanthis altissima), one in sycamore maple (Acer psendoplatanus) and one in London plane (Platanus hispanica). The 74.5% of occupied shelters were located near streams and river banks. During the perios of the study ar least 12 old trees had noctule bats have been cut. In Sanguesa all the shelters were situated in white poars growing  in a park neat the Aragon River. In Pamplona, however, shelters were more varies and were distributed among several wooden areas of the town (Figure 2).
column34: Alcalde, J. 1999. New ecological data on the noctule bat (Nyctalus noctula Schreber, 1774) (Chiroptera, Vespertiliondae) in two towns of Spain. Mammalia, 63: 273-280.

column23: The single specimen of this species presently known from Tamaulipas was shot while it was roosting in a ranch house.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Northwest of El Encino, near the headwaters of the Río Sabinas
column23: Most individuals of this species were taken in mist nets. Northwest of El Encino for example, bats were collected from a net placed in "a strategic position across a narrow opening" (Schaldach, fieldnotes) in a cave near the headwaters of the Río Sabinas...
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, In the cave near El Encino
column23: In the cave near El Encino the collector (Schaldach) estimated the population of P. rubiginosus at between two and three hundred; at Ojo de Agua this bat was found in the deepest part of a cave ecologically related to Myotis nigricans.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: The specimens from Miquihuana were captured in a mine by a native.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, four kilometers north of Joya Verde
column23: Those from four kilometers north of Joya Verde also were taken from a mine. Females obtained in August at La Mula were lactating.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Sierra de Tamaulipas, 3 mi. S,  16 mi. W Piedra, 1400 ft.
column23: Specimens from the Sierra de Tamaulipas were taken in a cave along with Desmodus rotundus and Tadarida laticaudata.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, 20 miles north of El  Mante
column23: Specimens from 20 miles north of El  Mante were collected from a cave about 50 yards deep.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: Specimens from La Mula were obtained in a small cave, which was inhabited also by Desmodus rotundus and Tadarida brasiliensis. La Mula, 13 mi. N Jaumave, 4; Cueva La Mula, 10 km. W Joya Verde, 2400 ft.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: In the cave near El Encino the collector (Schaldach) estimated the population of P. rubiginosus at between two and three hundred; at Ojo de Agua this bat was found in the deepest part of a cave ecologically related to Myotis nigricans.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Sierra de Tamaulipas, 3 mi. S,  16 mi. W Piedra, 1400 ft.
column23: Specimens from the Sierra de Tamaulipas were taken in a cave along with Desmodus rotundus and Tadarida laticaudata.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Sierra de Tamaulipas, 3 mi. S,  16 mi. W Piedra, 1400 ft.
column23: Specimens from the Sierra de Tamaulipas were taken in a cave along with Desmodus rotundus and Tadarida laticaudata.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, 6.5 mi. N, 13 mi. W  Jimenez, 1250 ft.
column23: The specimens herein reported were taken in a cave...Specimens examined, 28...Twelve females taken on August 27, 1961, were pregnant.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: The specimens from northwest of El Encino were shot deep (250 yards) in a cave;  specimens of Myotis nigricans were obtained in the same cave. A female taken on May  24 carried a single embryo
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: The specimens from northwest of El Encino were shot deep (250 yards) in a cave;  specimens of Myotis nigricans were obtained in the same cave. A female taken on May  24 carried a single embryo
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, cave at headwaters of Río Sabinas, 10 km. N, 8 km. W El  Encino, 400 ft.
column23: Two specimens from the Río Sabinas were taken in a mist net placed across the  small, crevicelike entrance to a cave. Ten pregnant females taken in late May
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: Specimens from Rancho del Cielo were collected in a limestone cave in the cloud  forest. A female taken on July 2 carried a small embryo and another obtained on August  14 had an embryo that appeared to be nearly ready for birth.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Río Soto la Marina, 4 mi. SW Padilla, 800 ft.,
column23: Most of the vampires examined in this study were taken in caves; those from four  miles southwest of Padilla were obtained from a hollow tree.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, 70 km. S Cd. Victoria (via Highway), 6 km. W of Highway,
column23: Nine specimens were  collected in a small cave 70 kilometers south of Ciudad Victoria on January 18, when  water on the floor of the cave was frozen; the bats were congregated on the ceiling at a  height of 20 feet.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Sierra de Tamaulipas, 1400 ft., 3 mi. S, 16 mi. W Piedra
column23: In a cave in the Sierra de Tamaulipas, 16 miles west and three miles  south of Piedra, females and young were found some 50 yards from the entrance; Natalus  stramineus and Glossophaga soricina were obtained from the same cave.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Sierra de Tamaulipas, 1400 ft., 3 mi. S, 16 mi. W Piedra
column23: In a cave in the Sierra de Tamaulipas, 16 miles west and three miles  south of Piedra, females and young were found some 50 yards from the entrance; Natalus  stramineus and Glossophaga soricina were obtained from the same cave.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Sierra de Tamaulipas, 1400 ft., 3 mi. S, 16 mi. W Piedra
column23: In a cave in the Sierra de Tamaulipas, 16 miles west and three miles  south of Piedra, females and young were found some 50 yards from the entrance; Natalus  stramineus and Glossophaga soricina were obtained from the same cave.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: In another cave  only half a kilometer distant, 12 males were collected.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva La Mula, 10  km. W Joya Verde, 2400 ft.
column23: In Cueva La Mula, Desmodus was  found near the mouth, whereas Choeronycteris mexicana and two Tadarida brasiliensis were collected in the deepest part.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva La Mula, 10  km. W Joya Verde, 2400 ft.
column23: In Cueva La Mula, Desmodus was  found near the mouth, whereas Choeronycteris mexicana and two Tadarida brasiliensis were collected in the deepest part.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva La Mula, 10  km. W Joya Verde, 2400 ft.
column23: In Cueva La Mula, Desmodus was  found near the mouth, whereas Choeronycteris mexicana and two Tadarida brasiliensis were collected in the deepest part.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva La Esperanza, 6 km.  SW Rancho Santa Rosa, 360 m.
column23: At Cueva La Esperanza, 300 feet deep and on the east  side of the Sierra Madre Oriental, four different congregations of vampires were found  along with about 400 Natalus.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva La Esperanza, 6 km.  SW Rancho Santa Rosa, 360 m.
column23: At Cueva La Esperanza, 300 feet deep and on the east  side of the Sierra Madre Oriental, four different congregations of vampires were found  along with about 400 Natalus.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, cave 13 miles west and  six and a half miles north of Jiménez
column23: A male Desmodus obtained in a cave 13 miles west and  six and a half miles north of Jiménez also was ecologically related to Natalus.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, cave 13 miles west and  six and a half miles north of Jiménez
column23: A male Desmodus obtained in a cave 13 miles west and  six and a half miles north of Jiménez also was ecologically related to Natalus.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva de la Sepultura, 7.5 km. NNW and hence 7 km. SSW (via highway) Cd. Victoria
column23: Malaga and Villa  remarked that the species was abundant at Cueva de la Sepultura, being found in small  groups clinging to the roof of the cave. Two females taken there on November 11 carried  one embryo each; a lactating female was taken on November 14. The vampire, Desmodus  rotundus, also was taken at Cueva de la Sepultura.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva de la Sepultura, 7.5 km. NNW and hence 7 km. SSW (via highway) Cd. Victoria
column23: Malaga and Villa  remarked that the species was abundant at Cueva de la Sepultura, being found in small  groups clinging to the roof of the cave. Two females taken there on November 11 carried  one embryo each; a lactating female was taken on November 14. The vampire, Desmodus  rotundus, also was taken at Cueva de la Sepultura.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva de la Esperanza, 6 km. SW Rancho Santa Rosa, 360 m.
column23: All specimens examined were obtained from caves. At Cueva la Esperanza,  approximately 400 individuals were found along with individuals of Desmodus rotundus;
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva de la Esperanza, 6 km. SW Rancho Santa Rosa, 360 m.
column23: All specimens examined were obtained from caves. At Cueva la Esperanza,  approximately 400 individuals were found along with individuals of Desmodus rotundus;
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, 3 mi. S, 14 mi. W Piedra
column23: Natalus and Desmodus also were collected together in a cave approximately 30 yards  deep three miles south and 14 miles west of Piedra, and in a cave six and a half miles  north and 13 miles west of Jiménez, the northernmost locality from which N. stramineus is presently known.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, 3 mi. S, 14 mi. W Piedra
column23: Natalus and Desmodus also were collected together in a cave approximately 30 yards  deep three miles south and 14 miles west of Piedra, and in a cave six and a half miles  north and 13 miles west of Jiménez, the northernmost locality from which N. stramineus is presently known.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, cave six and a half miles  north and 13 miles west of Jiménez
column23: Natalus and Desmodus also were collected together in a cave approximately 30 yards  deep three miles south and 14 miles west of Piedra, and in a cave six and a half miles  north and 13 miles west of Jiménez, the northernmost locality from which N. stramineus is presently known.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, cave six and a half miles  north and 13 miles west of Jiménez
column23: Natalus and Desmodus also were collected together in a cave approximately 30 yards  deep three miles south and 14 miles west of Piedra, and in a cave six and a half miles  north and 13 miles west of Jiménez, the northernmost locality from which N. stramineus is presently known.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: Specimens from San  Fernando probably were taken in houses by natives, who brought the bats to the  collectors (Clifton and Bodley).
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cave in canyon of Río Boquillas, 8 km. SW Chamal
column23: Additional record: Cave in canyon of Río Boquillas, 8 km. SW Chamal (Goodwin,  1954:6).
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas,  from Joya Verde, 35 km. SW  Cd. Victoria, 3800 ft.
column23: The specimens reported herein were shot in July in a canyon that contained some  standing water. According to the field notes of the collector (Schaldach), individuals of  this bat in Tamaulipas flew later, in his experience, than bats of the same species in  Sonora, Arizona and Coahuila, not emerging until it was almost fully dark.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: A young animal from Ciudad Victoria was captured inside a house.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Sierra de Tamaulipas, 3 mi. S, 16 mi. W Piedra, 1400 ft.
column23: Specimens from three miles south and 16 miles west of Piedra were found in a  crevice inside a cave. Two days previously Desmodus rotundus and Natalus stramineus were obtained from the same cave.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: At Rancho Pano Ayuctle, according to the field notes of the collector (Schaldach),  the red mastiff bat was common, and found daytime retreats in hollows in cypress trees. Schaldach twice found groups of bats in such hollows.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva La Mula, 10 km. W Joya  Verde, 2400 ft.
column23: Two specimens were shot in flight in the  deepest part of Cueva La Mula.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, [Cueva del Abra], 6 mi.  (by road) NNE Antiguo Morelos.
column23: Carter and Davis (1961) recorded for the first time this species from North  America, on the basis of five specimens collected at Cueva del Abra. From the same  locality P. L. Clifton collected several owl pellets which provide, besides many skulls of  Tadarida laticaudata, four crania of T. aurispinosa.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: In the cave near El Encino the collector (Schaldach) estimated the population of P. rubiginosus at between two and three hundred; at Ojo de Agua this bat was found in the deepest part of a cave ecologically related to Myotis nigricans.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: Specimens from La Mula were obtained in a small cave, which was inhabited also by Desmodus rotundus and Tadarida brasiliensis. La Mula, 13 mi. N Jaumave, 4; Cueva La Mula, 10 km. W Joya Verde, 2400 ft.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: Specimens from La Mula were obtained in a small cave, which was inhabited also by Desmodus rotundus and Tadarida brasiliensis. La Mula, 13 mi. N Jaumave, 4; Cueva La Mula, 10 km. W Joya Verde, 2400 ft.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: Specimens from the Sierra de Tamaulipas were taken in a cave along with Desmodus rotundus and Tadarida laticaudata.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: Specimens from the Sierra de Tamaulipas were taken in a cave along with Desmodus rotundus and Tadarida laticaudata.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: Specimens from the Sierra de Tamaulipas were taken in a cave along with Desmodus rotundus and Tadarida laticaudata.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column23: The specimens from northwest of El Encino were shot deep (250 yards) in a cave;  specimens of Myotis nigricans were obtained in the same cave. A female taken on May  24 carried a single embryo
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Sierra de Tamaulipas, 1400 ft., 3 mi. S, 16 mi. W Piedra
column23: In a cave in the Sierra de Tamaulipas, 16 miles west and three miles  south of Piedra, females and young were found some 50 yards from the entrance; Natalus  stramineus and Glossophaga soricina were obtained from the same cave.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Sierra de Tamaulipas, 1400 ft., 3 mi. S, 16 mi. W Piedra
column23: In a cave in the Sierra de Tamaulipas, 16 miles west and three miles  south of Piedra, females and young were found some 50 yards from the entrance; Natalus  stramineus and Glossophaga soricina were obtained from the same cave.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Sierra de Tamaulipas, 1400 ft., 3 mi. S, 16 mi. W Piedra
column23: In a cave in the Sierra de Tamaulipas, 16 miles west and three miles  south of Piedra, females and young were found some 50 yards from the entrance; Natalus  stramineus and Glossophaga soricina were obtained from the same cave.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva La Mula, 10  km. W Joya Verde, 2400 ft.
column23: In Cueva La Mula, Desmodus was  found near the mouth, whereas Choeronycteris mexicana and two Tadarida brasiliensis were collected in the deepest part.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva La Mula, 10  km. W Joya Verde, 2400 ft.
column23: In Cueva La Mula, Desmodus was  found near the mouth, whereas Choeronycteris mexicana and two Tadarida brasiliensis were collected in the deepest part.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva La Mula, 10  km. W Joya Verde, 2400 ft.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva La Esperanza, 6 km.  SW Rancho Santa Rosa, 360 m.
column23: At Cueva La Esperanza, 300 feet deep and on the east  side of the Sierra Madre Oriental, four different congregations of vampires were found  along with about 400 Natalus.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, cave 13 miles west and  six and a half miles north of Jiménez
column23: A male Desmodus obtained in a cave 13 miles west and  six and a half miles north of Jiménez also was ecologically related to Natalus.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva de la Sepultura, 7.5 km. NNW and hence 7 km. SSW (via highway) Cd. Victoria
column23: Malaga and Villa  remarked that the species was abundant at Cueva de la Sepultura, being found in small  groups clinging to the roof of the cave. Two females taken there on November 11 carried  one embryo each; a lactating female was taken on November 14. The vampire, Desmodus  rotundus, also was taken at Cueva de la Sepultura.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, Cueva de la Esperanza, 6 km. SW Rancho Santa Rosa, 360 m.
column23: All specimens examined were obtained from caves. At Cueva la Esperanza,  approximately 400 individuals were found along with individuals of Desmodus rotundus;
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, 3 mi. S, 14 mi. W Piedra
column23: Natalus and Desmodus also were collected together in a cave approximately 30 yards  deep three miles south and 14 miles west of Piedra, and in a cave six and a half miles  north and 13 miles west of Jiménez, the northernmost locality from which N. stramineus is presently known.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column14: Tamaulipas, cave six and a half miles  north and 13 miles west of Jiménez
column23: Natalus and Desmodus also were collected together in a cave approximately 30 yards  deep three miles south and 14 miles west of Piedra, and in a cave six and a half miles  north and 13 miles west of Jiménez, the northernmost locality from which N. stramineus is presently known.
column34: Alvarez 1963. The Recent mammals of Tamaulipas, Mexico. University of Kansas Publications, Museum of Natural History 14:363–473.

column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: In internal species, especially troglophiles, the darkness is relatively important:except, in particular, for Rouseltus aegypliacus leachi which acceptsto wear in a certain penumbra.
column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: Rousettus (Rousettus aegyptiacus leachi (A Smith. 1829)Andaux material: April. June and October 1957, April. August and November 1958,March and October 1959, 11 males and 39 females, in the Mwanga cave (Pempere). (CollectionsMHNG & MRAC). In a colony of several thousand individuals,present almost all the year (not including Ies, 21/4/1958 and 21/6/1959):Fruit bats are isolated or form small swarms in the middle zonea large joint or a top opening spreads a dim light. Sex-ratio: 30% males and 70% females. Not very sociable species.In the Kalomoni cave (Kakontwe), 6 corpses on the underground lake and a few solitary individuals on the walls, July 17, 1956.
column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: TaphoZouS perforatus sudani (Thomas, 1915)Anciallx material (IRSNB, MHNG, MRAC, SMF): in June 1957, June and August 1958, August 1962, 9 males and 17 females in the Mwanga cave (Pempere). within acolony of several hundred individuals occupying a small, very dark room (upper level); this colony is absent during the rainy season(from October to March). Its lodging is very close to the area of ​​a pair of Tyto alba: this owl does not seem to attack this species.fiercely independent species. Sex ratio: 35% males and 65% females. In the Kasowena grote (Pempere), only males, on 06/28/1964.
column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: TaphoZouS perforatus sudani (Thomas, 1915)Anciallx material (IRSNB, MHNG, MRAC, SMF): in June 1957, June and August 1958, August 1962, 9 males and 17 females in the Mwanga cave (Pempere). within acolony of several hundred individuals occupying a small, very dark room (upper level); this colony is absent during the rainy season(from October to March). Its lodging is very close to the area of ​​a pair of Tyto alba: this owl does not seem to attack this species.fiercely independent species. Sex ratio: 35% males and 65% females. column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: Anciaux Material: a female (MHNG), 29/9/1957, ecologically related to Miniopterus schreibersinatalensis and Rhinolophus swinnyi, in the Ruisseau cave (Tantara).A male (BMNH), 22/4/1959, solitary, in the cave of Kondo (Kakanda).A male (SMF), 7/16/1962, ecologically related to Rhinolophus simulator and Rh. Swinnyi,in the Lusolo cave (Lubudi). In gutters under the Lubumbashi roadtowards Kasenga: at km 60, 1 cf (MRAC), 3/7/1956; at km 67, 1 male(RMCA), 8/6/1956. A male (MRAC), 12/7/1956, in orcterope burrow,Mount Mukwene (Lubumbashi). In a tunnel under the forge workshop of theCatholic Mission of Kapolowe, 1 male, 1female and 2 n.nes male (MRAC), 1 male and 1 female (SM F), 18 / I0 / 1956, as well as a female. (SMF), 8/9/1962, in a colony oftwenty very alert individuals, suspended from a wooden ceiling, in the midst ofdarkness and in a very dry and very hot atmosphere. Sex ratio: 47% male and53% female.
column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

(SMF), 8/9/1962, in a colony oftwenty very alert individuals, suspended from a wooden ceiling, in the midst ofdarkness and in a very dry and very hot atmosphere. Sex ratio: 47% male and53% female.

column14: road from Lubumbashi to Kasenga, at km 36 (Bulaya)
column23: Materiel Anciaux: a female (MRAC), 26/3/1956, in a cement drain under theroad from Lubumbashi to Kasenga, at km 36 (Bulaya). A male (MRAC),12/3/1956, in the cave of Baya, isolated in the middle of a colony of Rhinolophus hildebrandti. One male and 2 females. (I RSN B), 1 male and I female (SMF), 2/8/1960, withinof a colony of about fifty individuals, in a mining gallery in Shinkolobwe.In water drainage channels under the Lubumbashi roadtowards Sakania, near the Droogmans farm (Keyberg), 8 males and 6 females (BMNH,MHNG, MHNP, MRAC, SMF) from October to December 1955 as well as in Marchand in June 1956.Usually in small colonies of 5.10-20 individuals. Frequent cohabitationwith Hystricidae (porcupines). Sex-ratio: 47% males and 53% females
column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: Colonies are often distant from other Chiroptera (Hipposideridae,Minioptera, other Rhinolophidae). In Mwanga cave, Rhinolophllshildebrandti exhibits aggressive behavior towards Rh. clivoslis zulllensisand Rh. swinnyi. If the size of the cave of Baya put them close toMinioptera, these two species - following our visits in March 1956 - formedclearly distinct colonies in the lower galleries of a borehole,more than a km from the cave of Baya. It seems that these plurispecific groupings correspond more tosimilar ecological demands rather than a social attraction of aspecies for another (BROSSET, 1974).
column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: The Anciaux material coming from the same caves is attributed by V. AELLENa Rhinolophus swinnyi, but H. FELTEN confirms its first diagnosis (<< inlittera ”, April 23, 1971): one male and one female, 11/6/1960, Kalomoni cave; a male and 1 female7/8/1960, Mwanga cave; a male, 6/30/1962, cave at Ruisseau; cavesLubudi: a male and 2 females 7/18/1962, Kyamankonde; two males and 3 females, 7/26/1962,Mulonga; one male and 5 females, 7/16/1962, Lusolo; four males and 1 female 23/7 / 1962, Kaboyaboya.Kasoma cave: four males and 3 females 13/8/1962.Small colonies of 10 to 20 individuals, cohabiting with Rhinolophus hildebrandti,Rh. Swinnyi, Hipposideridae and Minioptera, in cavesKalomoni, Pempere, Tantara, Lubudi and Kasoma.Sex-ratio: equality of the sexes.

FELTEN confirms its first diagnosis (<< inlittera ”, April 23, 1971): one male and one female, 11/6/1960, Kalomoni cave; a male and 1 female7/8/1960, Mwanga cave; a male, 6/30/1962, cave at Ruisseau; cavesLubudi: a male and 2 females 7/18/1962, Kyamankonde; two males and 3 females, 7/26/1962,Mulonga; one male and 5 females, 7/16/1962, Lusolo; four males and 1 female 23/7 / 1962, Kaboyaboya.Kasoma cave: four males and 3 females 13/8/1962.Small colonies of 10 to 20 individuals, cohabiting with Rhinolophus hildebrandti,Rh. Swinnyi, Hipposideridae and Minioptera, in cavesKalomoni, Pempere, Tantara, Lubudi and Kasoma.Sex-ratio: equality of the sexes.
column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: Material Anciaux: four males and females (MRAC), 22/4/1959, Kondo cave, ina colony of about fifty individuals, in the company of Hipposiderosruber and Rhinolophus hildebrandti; one male and 4 females (MRAC) and 2 females (SMF),18/12/1957, gallery along a forced pipe at Mwadingusha, in acolony of 20 to 30 individuals, near Rhinolophus landeri lobatus. Sex ratio:30% (males and 70% females.
column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: Anciaux Materiel Un male et 1 female (MRAC) and I female (BMNH), 15/6/1958, I male and 1 female (SMF) 4/6/1960. cave at the Ruisseau (Tantara); a male (MHNG), I male and I female (SMF), 23/7/1962. column23: Myotis (Myotis) tricolor (Temminck, 1832)Ancient Material: a male (MHNG), 9/22/1957, Kalomoni cave; a male (SMF),4/6/1960, cave at the Ruisseau (Tantara); two female (MHNG & SMF), 1817/1962,Kyamakonde cave (Lubudi); a male (MRAC), 7/30/1957, Mulonga cave(Lubudi).Individuals isolated in crevices in the vault or in the company of Minioptera(sometimes in the same crack): narrow commensually interacts with Miniopteraschreibersi natalensis (a Minioptere male behind 2 Myotis tricolor female, caveKyamakonde; a M. tricolor with several Minioptera, Mulonga cave).Sex-ratio: 60% male and 40% female.
column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: Large colonies, often in lethargy (ANCIAUX, 1976b), especially present during the dry season (from May to August): from 500 to 1,000 individuals in the cave Kalomoni (upper level); a few hundred in Pempere (Mwanga cave) and in the Likasi mining gallery. During the other months of the year, individuals isolated or forming small colonies.
column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: Anciaux Materials: two males and 2 females (BMNH), 2 males and 2 females (MHNG), 4 males and 8 females(MRAC), 7/16/1957; two males (MRAC), 14 males and 11 females (rings), 20/5/1959; captureof 25 individuals (not preserved), 9/17/1958. All in a big colony(more than 500 individuals) occupying the expansion joints of the walls of the factoryhydroelectric from Mwadingusha, only in dry season (from May to the endSeptember). Animals very alert during the day.The colony leaves Mwadingusha in early October to reach an unknown refuge(hollow trees?) or it stays until the end of April; this displacement is linked tothe reproduction.25 banded individuals were released on May 20, 1959, in Likasi (distance 80km): no recovery, except a female (25 May 1959) in a house1 in Likasi.
column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: Materiel Anciaux: a female (MRAC), 26/3/1956, in a cement drain under theroad from Lubumbashi to Kasenga, at km 36 (Bulaya). A male (MRAC),12/3/1956, in the cave of Baya, isolated in the middle of a colony of Rhinolophus hildebrandti. One male and 2 females. (I RSN B), 1 male and I female (SMF), 2/8/1960, withinof a colony of about fifty individuals, in a mining gallery in Shinkolobwe.In water drainage channels under the Lubumbashi roadtowards Sakania, near the Droogmans farm (Keyberg), 8 males and 6 females (BMNH,MHNG, MHNP, MRAC, SMF) from October to December 1955 as well as in Marchand in June 1956.Usually in small colonies of 5.10-20 individuals. Frequent cohabitationwith Hystricidae (porcupines). Sex-ratio: 47% males and 53% females
column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: Anciaux Materials: 9 males and 7 females, in July 1956 and 1957 (RMCA), Kalomoni cave.12 males and 5 females (BMNH, IRSNB, MHNP, MRAC), in June 1956, in October andin December 1959, in the caves of Mulungwishi. One male and one female. (RMCA),1/7/1959, in the Kalumbu cave (Kabolela). A female (RMCA), 1/5/1958,Mura cave (Kambove). A male (lRSNB) and a female (SMF), 9/21/1960, caveby Kondo. 2 females (SMF), 18/12/1957, in a gallery along a pipeforcee, in Mwadingusha.Colonies of 20 to 50 individuals, ecologically related to Hipposideros ruber and various Rhinolophidae.

column23: Colonies are often distant from other Chiroptera (Hipposideridae,Minioptera, other Rhinolophidae). In Mwanga cave, Rhinolophllshildebrandti exhibits aggressive behavior towards Rh. clivoslis zulllensisand Rh. swinnyi. If the size of the cave of Baya put them close toMinioptera, these two species - following our visits in March 1956 - formedclearly distinct colonies in the lower galleries of a borehole,more than a km from the cave of Baya. It seems that these plurispecific groupings correspond more tosimilar ecological demands rather than a social attraction of aspecies for another (BROSSET, 1974).
column34: Anciaux de Faveaux, 1978b. Noteseco-ethologiques et parasitologiques surles Chiropteres cavernicoles du Shaba (Zaire). International Journal of Speleology, 10: 331-350

column23: Anciaux Material: a female (MHNG), 29/9/1957, ecologically related to Miniopterus schreibersinatalensis and Rhinolophus swinnyi, in the Ruisseau cave (Tantara).A male (BMNH), 22/4/1959, solitary, in the cave of Kondo (Kakanda).A male (SMF), 7/16/1962, ecologically related to Rhinolophus simulator and Rh. Swinnyi,in the Lusolo cave (Lubudi). In gutters under the Lubumbashi roadtowards Kasenga: at km 60, 1 cf (MRAC), 3/7/1956; at km 67, 1 male(RMCA), 8/6/1956. A male (MRAC), 12/7/1956, in orcterope burrow,Mount Mukwene (Lubumbashi). In a tunnel under the forge workshop of theCatholic Mission of Kapolowe, 1 male, 1female and 2 n.nes male (MRAC), 1 male and 1 female (SM F), 18 / I0 / 1956, as well as a female. (SMF), 8/9/1962, in a colony oftwenty very alert individuals, suspended from a wooden ceiling, in the midst ofdarkness and in a very dry and very hot atmosphere. Sex ratio: 47% male and53% female.

column23: Materiel Anciaux: a female (MRAC), 26/3/1956, in a cement drain under theroad from Lubumbashi to Kasenga, at km 36 (Bulaya). (I RSN B), 1 male and I female (SMF), 2/8/1960, withinof a colony of about fifty individuals, in a mining gallery in Shinkolobwe.In water drainage channels under the Lubumbashi roadtowards Sakania, near the Droogmans farm (Keyberg), 8 males and 6 females (BMNH,MHNG, MHNP, MRAC, SMF) from October to December 1955 as well as in Marchand in June 1956.Usually in small colonies of 5.10-20 individuals. Frequent cohabitationwith Hystricidae (porcupines). Sex-ratio: 47% males and 53% females

column14: Merrill barn/land/site/facility in Hancock, Hillsborough County, New Hampsh
column23: Two night roosts used by M. lucifugus were studied in an aban- doned barn/land/site/facility (Merrill barn/land/site/facility) in Hancock, Hillsborough County, New Hampshire. These roosts consisted of rectangular mortices or cavities (# 1 =8 ? 5 ? 10.5 cm; # 2= 15 ? 5 ? 12 cm) in the lower surface of horizontal beams, approximately 4 m from the floor
column34: Anthony, E. L. P., M. H. Stack, and. H. Kunz. 1981. Night roosting and the nocturnal time budget of the little brown bat, Myotis lucifugus: effects of reproductive status, prey density, and environmental conditions. Oecologia, 51: 151- 156.

column23: Females form summer maternity colonies of 100 to over 1,000 individuals, primarily in barn/land/site/facilitys and attics, and cluster during the day in warm ( > 32? C) maternity roosts along ridge poles, under metal roofs, in joist crevices, etc. Males usually day roost singly in cooler sites, but a few males are sometimes found roosting in buildings occupied by maternity colonies.
column34: Anthony, E. L. P., M. H. Stack, and. H. Kunz. 1981. Night roosting and the nocturnal time budget of the little brown bat, Myotis lucifugus: effects of reproductive status, prey density, and environmental conditions. Oecologia, 51: 151- 156.

column14: Castries Waterworks Reserve along the Old French Road near Forestiere
column23: ...we began a bird censes...On 20 March, we noticed our mist net line ran adjacent to a very densely populated bat roost located within a large cavity in the main trunk of a "chatagnier" tree (Sloanea caribaea). Trunk circumference at breast height was 2.82 m. Vertical distance to the cavity was 7.22 m. Cavity height, width, and inside diameter were 2.74, 0.24, and 0.50 m respectively. At 1640 hours, as daylight began to fade...

column23: The nursery colony of Myotis myotis that I studied was located in the attic of a house of worship/temple between flat farmland and hilly ground with forested areas dominated by coniferous species (especially Picea abies) and cultivated fields. Before parturition, the colony consisted of approximately 600 individuals, mostly females.
column34: Audet, D. 1990. Foraging behavior and habitat use by a gleaning bat, Myotis myotis (Chiroptera: Vespertilionidae). Journal of Mammalogy, 71: 420 -427.

column23: In Cueva  del  Abra,  Tamaulipas,  this  bat  has  been  observed  nearthe  cave  entrance,  in  a  faintly  lighted  area.  Individuals  wereroosting within the rifts, channels, and winding hollows amongstalactites  formed  in  walls,  at  heights  from  6  to  at  least  30  m
column34: Avila-Flores, R.; Flores-Mart¬ínez, J.J.; Ortega, J. Nyctinomops laticaudatus. Mamm. Species 2002, 697,1-6.

column23: In  theMayan  ruins  of Uxmal,  Yucatan,  a  group  of 200  bats was bandedin March 1955. When the complete colony (270 females and 280males) was captured and banded 3 months later, it contained only17 of the previously banded bats (less than 10%). In November ofthe same year, the colony had 520 individuals, many of them young.
column34: Avila-Flores, R.; Flores-Mart¬ínez, J.J.; Ortega, J. Nyctinomops laticaudatus. Mamm. Species 2002, 697,1-6.

column23: A large resident colony is also known at Cueva del Abra, Tamaulipas
column34: Avila-Flores, R.; Flores-Mart¬ínez, J.J.; Ortega, J. Nyctinomops laticaudatus. Mamm. Species 2002, 697,1-6.

column23: Nyctinomops  laticaudatus hosts  several  species  of  flea  (Siphonaptera: Hormopsylla kyriophylla, Ptilopsylla leptina stubbei, and Rothschildopsylla noctilionis—Morales-Mucin ̃ o and Llorente-Bousquets 1985), mites (Acarina:Chiroptonyssus robustipes, C. ve-nezolanus, Ewingana yaguajayensis, and Notoedres lasionycteris minimus—Silva-Taboada 1979), and chiggers (Acarina:Hooperellayucatanica, Tecomatlana yucatanica—Loomis 1969). Endoparasites  from N.  laticaudatusinclude  trematodes  (Limatulum  solitarium,Ochoterenatrema  diminutum,O.  pricei,Postorchigenescubensis, and Urotrema scabridum), cestodes (Vampirolepis deci-piens), and nematodes (Anoplostrongylus paradoxus,Litomosoidesguiterasi, L.  chandleri, Physaloptera,  and Physocephalus sexalatus—Silva-Taboada 1979).
column34: Avila-Flores, R.; Flores-Mart¬ínez, J.J.; Ortega, J. Nyctinomops laticaudatus. Mamm. Species 2002, 697,1-6.

column23: Nyctinomops  laticaudatus hosts  several  species  of  flea  (Siphonaptera: Hormopsylla kyriophylla, Ptilopsylla leptina stubbei, and Rothschildopsylla noctilionis—Morales-Mucin ̃ o and Llorente-Bousquets 1985), mites (Acarina:Chiroptonyssus robustipes, C. ve-nezolanus, Ewingana yaguajayensis, and Notoedres lasionycteris minimus—Silva-Taboada 1979), and chiggers (Acarina:Hooperellayucatanica, Tecomatlana yucatanica—Loomis 1969). column23: It "earns its English name of Banana Bat from its habits of sheltering in banana and plantain stems, commonly choosing what certainly is a remarkable hiding place, the long narrow tube formed by the as yet unfolded terminal leaf. Into this these tiny bats creep to rest by day"
column34: Baagøe, HJ. 1978. Observations on the biology of the banana bat, Pipistrellus nanus. Pp. 275- 282 in: Proceedings of the Fourth International Bat Research Conference (R. J. Olembo, J. B. Castelino, and F. A. Mutere, eds.). Kenya National Academy for Advancement of Arts and Sciences, Kenya Literature Bureau, Nairobi.

column23: ...sheltering in banana and plantain stems, commonly choosing what certainly is a remarkable hiding place, the long narrow tube formed by the as yet unfolded terminal leaf. Into this these tiny bats creep to rest by day". Also Anciaux de Faveaux (1972) mentions it as the common hiding place for these bats, and Verschuren (1957) and Brosset (1966 a, b) both state it as about the only hiding place.
column34: Baagøe, HJ. 1978. Observations on the biology of the banana bat, Pipistrellus nanus. Pp. 275- 282 in: Proceedings of the Fourth International Bat Research Conference (R. J. Olembo, J. B. Castelino, and F. A. Mutere, eds.). Kenya National Academy for Advancement of Arts and Sciences, Kenya Literature Bureau, Nairobi.

column14: East African Institute of Malaria and Vector-borne Diseases at Amani in the rain-forested Usambara Mountains
column23: All animals in the present study were found roosting in the terminal leaves of Musa sp. ...A total of 49 females and 34 males were collected, and both sexes were found roosting singly. In 7 of the 19 leaves containing more than one bat, the sex of all residents (2-7) was noted; 6 of these contained groups of both sexes. One had the sole content of 2 females-In none of these leaves was more than one male found. In 4 leaves only some of the bats were determined as to sex. These were all females (p.281)
column34: Baagøe, HJ. 1978. Observations on the biology of the banana bat, Pipistrellus nanus. Pp. 275- 282 in: Proceedings of the Fourth International Bat Research Conference (R. J. Olembo, J. B. Castelino, and F. A. Mutere, eds.). Kenya National Academy for Advancement of Arts and Sciences, Kenya Literature Bureau, Nairobi.

column23: Allen et al. (1917) found that the favourite hiding places were among the fruits of bananas, but curiously enough they did not seem to have found the bats in the terminal leaves.
column34: Baagøe, HJ. 1978. Observations on the biology of the banana bat, Pipistrellus nanus. Pp. 275- 282 in: Proceedings of the Fourth International Bat Research Conference (R. J. Olembo, J. B. Castelino, and F. A. Mutere, eds.). Kenya National Academy for Advancement of Arts and Sciences, Kenya Literature Bureau, Nairobi.

column23: They also occur in oil palms and in houses "among thatch, under rafters" (Rosevaer, 1965) (see also Anxiaux de Faveaux, 1972), or in culverts (Cansdale cited in Rosevaer, 1965), or exceptionally under bark of trees (Anciaux de Faveaux, 1972) and abnormally in a  cave (Aellen and Brosset, 1968).

column23: In their comment on Pipistrellus stamflii, which seems to be conspecific with P. nanus, Allen and Coolidge (1930) mention that these bats "are especially fond of spending the day underneath the masses of palm leaf thatch of the native huts".

column14: the old fortifications in  the Lubuskie Lake District, western Poland,  remains  of  fortifications in the former Międzyrzecki  Fortified Region (das befestigte  Gebiet  Oder-Warthe-Bogen). The studies were carried out in the part  of the underground passages  situated  near the village  of Wysoka  (52°23'N,  15°28'E; UTM grid square WU  30) in  the  Gorzôw voivodship, this including the exit passage  1500 m long, about  2  km  of  part  of the main corridor and several side passages,
column23: Eleven species of bat occur in the underground  passages: Myotis myotis (Borkhausen,  1797), M.  bechsteini (Kuhl,  1818), M. nattereri Kuhl, 1818),  M.  mystacinus (Kuhl, 1819),  M. brandti (Eversmann, 1845), M.  dasycneme  (Boie,  1825),  M.  daubentoni  (Kuhl,  1819),  Eptesicus seroti-nus (Schreber, 1774),  Pipistrellus pipistrellus (Schreber, 1774),Plecotus  auritus  (Linnaeus, 1758), Barbastella barbastellus (Schreber, 1774). In view of  the  fact  that  at  first  no  distinction  was  made  between M.  my-stacinus  and M. brandti,  and  that their differentiation  on  the basis of external  morphological  characteristics  did  not  always  give  reliable  results,  both species  were  treated jointly as M. mystacinus.
column34: Bagrowska-Urbanczyk, E., and Z. Urbanczyk. 1983. Structure and dynamics of a winter colony of bats. Acta Theriologica, 28:183-196.

column23: Eleven species of bat occur in the underground  passages: Myotis myotis (Borkhausen,  1797), M.  bechsteini (Kuhl,  1818), M. nattereri Kuhl, 1818),  M.  mystacinus (Kuhl, 1819),  M. brandti (Eversmann, 1845), M.  dasycneme  (Boie,  1825),  M.  daubentoni  (Kuhl,  1819),  Eptesicus seroti-nus (Schreber, 1774),  Pipistrellus pipistrellus (Schreber, 1774),Plecotus  auritus  (Linnaeus, 1758), Barbastella barbastellus (Schreber, 1774). In view of  the  fact  that  at  first  no  distinction  was  made  between M.  my-stacinus  and M. brandti,  and  that their differentiation  on  the basis of external  morphological  characteristics  did  not  always  give  reliable  results,  both species  were  treated jointly as M. mystacinus.
column34: Bagrowska-Urbanczyk, E., and Z. Urbanczyk. 1983. Structure and dynamics of a winter colony of bats. Acta Theriologica, 28:183-196.

column23: Eleven species of bat occur in the underground  passages: Myotis myotis (Borkhausen,  1797), M.  bechsteini (Kuhl,  1818), M. nattereri Kuhl, 1818),  M.  mystacinus (Kuhl, 1819),  M. brandti (Eversmann, 1845), M.  dasycneme  (Boie,  1825),  M.  daubentoni  (Kuhl,  1819),  Eptesicus seroti-nus (Schreber, 1774),  Pipistrellus pipistrellus (Schreber, 1774),Plecotus  auritus  (Linnaeus, 1758), Barbastella barbastellus (Schreber, 1774). In view of  the  fact  that  at  first  no  distinction  was  made  between M.  my-stacinus  and M. brandti,  and  that their differentiation  on  the basis of external  morphological  characteristics  did  not  always  give  reliable  results,  both species  were  treated jointly as M. mystacinus.
column34: Bagrowska-Urbanczyk, E., and Z. Urbanczyk. 1983. Structure and dynamics of a winter colony of bats. Acta Theriologica, 28:183-196.

column34: Bagrowska-Urbanczyk, E., and Z. Urbanczyk. 1983. Structure and dynamics of a winter colony of bats. Acta Theriologica, 28:183-196.

column14: Howard Waterfall Cave, Trenton, Dade County, Lookout Plateau Region, Georgia
column23: On 27 November 1964, I found one female M. leibii (Univ. Georgia no. 2749) in Howard Waterfall Cave, Trenton, Dade County, Georgia. This individual was in the same room with four solitary Pipistrellus subflavus. The cave is located in the Lookout Plateau Region of extreme northwest Georgia at an elevation of approximately 800 ft.
column34: Baker, W. 1967. Myotis leibii leibii in Georgia. Journal of Mammalogy,48:142.

column14: The base of El Nevado de Colima, 8 miles W of Atenquique, Jalisco
column23: Myotis volans amotus Miller. One of us (Phillips) was hunting at 10:30 PM (tempera- ture 55° F) with a headlight with guide Jose Rodriquez in a fir forest when several flying bats appeared in the light beam. Phillips' attention was directed to the side of a large fir from which the bats seemed to be coming. The underside of a piece of bark (15 X 20 inches), loosened at the bottom from the tree trunk (diameter 4.5 ft) at about 15 ft above ground level, served as the roost. Phillips obtained 33 bats (15 males, 18 females ); at least two of the females were in lactation.
column34: Baker, R. H.,and C. J. Phillips. 1965. Mammals from El Navado de Colima, Mexico. Journal of Mammalogy, 46: 691-693.

column14: St. John's College in Tirunelveli  building (8° 44' N; 77° 42' E)
column23: Long slender twigs of V. scandens with loosely arranged leaves were closely interwoven (at a height of ca. 5 m) drooping at their free ends. The crowns were hidden from open view by the surrounding vegetation. On 15 September 1991 at dusk we saw a chain of fruit bats C. sphinx emerging from this ‘foliage tent.
column34: Balasingh, J., S. Isaac, and R. Subbaraj. 1993. Tent-roosting by the frugivorous bat Cynopterus sphinx (Vahl 1797) in southern India. Current Science, 65: 418.

column23: Subsequently, we searched for other foliage roosts of C. sphinx. Evidently, this bat prefers palm trees (Borassus flabellifer - the palmyrah palm), Areca catechu (areca nut palm) and tall shady trees (Polyalthia longifolia) roosting very high up at the base of the fronds and leaves respectively.
column34: Balasingh, J., S. Isaac, and R. Subbaraj. 1993. Tent-roosting by the frugivorous bat Cynopterus sphinx (Vahl 1797) in southern India. Current Science, 65: 418.

column23: C. brachyotis is also ķnown to roost under palm fronds and is reported to modify roost sites
column34: Balasingh, J., S. Isaac, and R. Subbaraj. 1993. Tent-roosting by the frugivorous bat Cynopterus sphinx (Vahl 1797) in southern India. Current Science, 65: 418.

column23: C. brachyotis is also ķnown to roost under palm fronds and is reported to modify roost sites4. Brosset? observed that when palm trees are not available in the vicinity, banyan trees (Ficus bengalensis) and Ficus trees (Ficus religiosa) are used for roosting.
column34: Balasingh, J., S. Isaac, and R. Subbaraj. 1993. Tent-roosting by the frugivorous bat Cynopterus sphinx (Vahl 1797) in southern India. Current Science, 65: 418.

column14: St. John's College in Tirunelveli  building (8° 44' N; 77° 42' E)
column23: Cynopterus sphinx used at least six different species of plants as roost sites. These  include the mast  tree, Polyalthia longifoliu, curtain creeper, Vernoniu scandens, palmyrah palm, Borassus jhbellifer, areca palm, Areca catechu, banyan tree, Ficus bengalensis, and banana, Musa paradisiuca. Because C. sphinx most commonly roosted in P. longifolia and V. scandens, we concentrated our obser- vations on tents  that were constructed in  these two plant species.
column34: Balasingh, J, J. Koilraj, and. H. Kunz. 1995. Tent construction by the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae) in southern India. Ethology, 100: 210- 229.

column14: St. John's College in Tirunelveli  building (8° 44' N; 77° 42' E)
column23: Cynopterus sphinx used at least six different species of plants as roost sites. These  include the mast  tree, Polyalthia longifoliu, curtain creeper, Vernoniu scandens, palmyrah palm, Borassus jhbellifer, areca palm, Areca catechu, banyan tree, Ficus bengalensis, and banana, Musa paradisiuca. Because C. sphinx most commonly roosted in P. longifolia and V. scandens, we concentrated our obser- vations on tents  that were constructed in  these two plant species...Although the total population occupying the six tents remained relatively stable, variations in the number of bats present suggest some daily movement of individuals from  one tent to another.
column34: Balasingh, J, J. Koilraj, and. H. Kunz. 1995. Tent construction by the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae) in southern India. Ethology, 100: 210- 229.

column23: PHILLIPS (1924) was the first to suggest that  the  centre ‘seed strings’ of the kitul palm, Curyota wens were severed by Cynopterus sphinx (= brachyotis), creating a bell-shaped  cavity in which bats roosted (see PHILLIPS 1980 for a name re-assignment). This type of stem-tent construction in the flower and fruit clusters of Curyota urens has been  described  (BHAT & KUNZ 1995) and  referred to as a stem tent (KUNZ et al. 1994).
column34: Balasingh, J, J. Koilraj, and. H. Kunz. 1995. Tent construction by the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae) in southern India. Ethology, 100: 210- 229.

column23: P. Cox (pers. com.) saw what seemed to be the same pair of bats in the same area of Upolu, Western Samoa (although not always in the same tree) for 4 consecutive years.
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: Occasionally larger groups roosted in close proximity to one another. I observed one group consisting of five individuals (two male-female pairs and a single female) within the same tree and subsequently roosting in adjacent trees for a period of 9 weeks....
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: A typical evening of following collared animals revealed a pattern of foraging on nectar from banana flowers (Musa spp.) within nearby plantations directly after leaving the roost and before flying elsewhere...After feeding for a couple hours or more, the bats hang about on the tree as they do at the roost. This appears to be an interval of rest ...
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: P. tonganis and P. samoensis have very different social structures. P. tonganus roosts in large colonies predominantly in inaccessible or protected areas. The majority of these roost sites are on exposed ocean cliffs.
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: Intensive searches by Lemke (1986) on 12 of the 14 islands or island groups inthe Marianas located only four bats (in Guano Cave on Aguijan Island). A small population on Aguijan was still present in March 1992 (Rice & Taisacan  1992). It was the most common mammal found in excavations on Rota but was probably lo t in the l960's (Lemke, 1986, Steadman 1992). Bruner & Pratt (1979) reported

column14: cave below Sauniatu, Upolu, Western Samoa
column23: Sheath-tailed bats were previously aundant on Upolu, Western Samoa (Ollier et al. 1979), and Cox (1983) found a colony of over 50 individuals in a cave below Sauniatu, Upolu.
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column14: Pe'a pe'a Cave in O le Pupu Pu's National Park on Upolu
column23: Pe'a pe'a Cave in O le Pupu Pu's National Park on Upolu formerly housed several thousand sheath-tailed bats and white rumped swiflets (Aerodramus spodiopygius), but surveys failed to find the bats there or elsewhere on the island (Ollier et al. 1979, Lovegrove et al. 1992, Park et al. 1992).
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column14: sea caves near Vavau Resort, Upolu
column23: Three bats were found by David Butler (pers. comm.) in sea caves near Vavau Resort, Upolu, on 30 March 1994 and there are recent unconfirmaed reports of a few bats at other locations in the Western Samoa (pers. comm. Department of Lands, Surveys and Environment, Western Samoa).
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: About 10,000 bats were using two large caves at Anape'ape'a Cove near Afono, Tutuila and only 15 to 20 bats were reported using other caves on Tutuila (Amerson et al. 1982).
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: A small cave north of Alao was visited on 3 December 1992 and on 11 August 1993. On both occasions it contained only a single sheath-tailed bat.
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: Utilization sites within Olovalu Crater varied in a consistent pattern between September 1992 and March 1994. Harem trees were located on the NW crater wall during Januaryy-April and moved counter-clockwise to trees in the vicinity of a large banyan fig (Ficus prolixa) in April-May.
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column14: Amalau Valley, along perimeter of Olovalu crater
column23: P. samoensis was also observed roosting in trees along the perimeter of Olovalu crater adjacent to a large colony of P. tonganus and occasionally within the same trees as the P tonganus colony.
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column14: Pe'a pe'a Cave in O le Pupu Pu's National Park on Upolu
column23: Pe'a pe'a Cave in O le Pupu Pu's National Park on Upolu formerly housed several thousand sheath-tailed bats and white rumped swiflets (Aerodramus spodiopygius), but surveys failed to find the bats there or elsewhere on the island (Ollier et al. 1979, Lovegrove et al. 1992, Park et al. 1992)
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: We visited both caves at Anape'ape'a Cove on 3 November 1992. We saw one sheath-tailed bat and about 10 swiflet nests in the large cave on this date.
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: The shifting trees for P. tonganus within Olovalu Crater over the course of a yea's time might be a response to ectoparasite load. Wingless batflies (family Nycteribiidae) deposit full-term prepupa on leaves and twigs in bat roosts (Allison 1987). Some bats in America Samoa appear to be heavily infested with batflies. We frequently encountered numerous batflies on mist-netted bats and observed roosting bats scratching and abruptly shaking their wings presumably in response to parasitic flies and mosquitos. Interestly, bat flies were absent from 16 netted P. samoensis, which roost in pairs and have been observed to shift roosting trees on occasion (Banack, unpublished data).
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: On 18 August 1993 I watched a P. samoensis forage from 18:58 until after 21:50 in a small Ficus tinctoria.
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: On 14 September 1993 I observed a uniquely marked female P. samoensis forage within a different FIcus sp. from 06:09 to 6:28, just after dawn. Although, it was not possible to identify individual markings with certainty using a night vision device, a P. samoenisis stayed in this tree from 21:20 until midnight (on the same day) and defended the tree from at least one intruding flying fox. The next evening, I observed one P. samoensis in the tree intermittently from 18:38 until 6:15 the next morning.
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: On 9 May 1994, I watched at least two P. samoensis foraging within a fruiting Planchonella samoensis tree from 18:27 unitl 05:15 the next morning.
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: Heidman (1988) suggested that specific plant species may prove to be important cues for pteropid reproduction. Wodzicki and Felton (1980) identified partuition to be correlated with the onset of the kapok flowers for P. tonganus in the Cook Islands.
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: It is plausible that P. samoensis uses the flowering of Syzygium inophylloides an indigenous species as a cue for reproduction.
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: Samoa has only one natural predator on flying fox species, Tyto alba, a nocturnal barn/land/site/facility owl (Grant and Banack 1995).
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.

column23: Competition with P.tonganus, a cogener which shares numerous plant resources (Chapter 3), may encourage P samoensis to occasionally defend highly favored resources throughout the night. P. samoensis defended resources from P. tonganus during two of the three times I observed them foraging during the night.
column34: Banack, S. A. 1996. Flying foxes, genus Pteropus, in the Samoan Islands: interactions with forest communities. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of California, Berkeley.
