column23: Several animals are known to prey upon M. lucifugus. Judging from reports of recoveries of banded bats, house cats must take them frequently. At a colony in a house in New York the resident told how his cat perched on the roof in the evening and struck at the bats as they emerged, catching some. We have also heard it reeounted how a cat would crouch in high grass and spring at low flying bats.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Mink enter caves and feed upon bats (Goodpaster andHoffmeister, 1950).
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Racoons, which commonly enter caves,surely feed upon this species at times.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Voles have been reported as preying on the bats in a cave (Martin, 1961a), and Hitchcock (1965) suspected a wood mouse, Peromyscus leucopus, of preying on bats hibernating in Ontario.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Voles have been reported as preying on the bats in a cave (Martin, 1961a), and Hitchcock (1965) suspected a wood mouse, Peromyscus leucopus, of preying on bats hibernating in Ontario.

column23: Borell and Ellis (1934) watched trout eat bats which were shot over a lake in Nevada. One which we banded in Kentucky was recovered from the stomach of a bass, and one which Harold Hitchcock and Wayne Davis released while banding in Vermont was captured by a broad-winged hawk.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Kinsey (1961) watched a leopard frog, Rana pipiens, eats a Myotis which it had captured.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Rat snakes, Elapheobsoleta, probably also take them. Barr and Norton (1965) watched one capture a Myotis sodalis in the ceiling of a cave in Kentucky.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Rice (1957) believes predation is the most important mortality factor for M. austroriparius in Florida. Rat snakes (Elaphe obsoleta) and corn snakes (Elaphe guttata) were frequently found in the bat caves and were thought to be the most important predators. They are excellent climbers and readily feed upon bats. Various carnivorous mammals and owls take some. Hawks are apparently not a factor, since M. austroriparius emerges late in the evening. Cockroaches [Periplaneta americana and Periplaneta australasiae) are abundant in the bat caves and eat very young bats which have fallen to the floor.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Twente (1955b) believed population size in M. velifer is controlled primarily by predators. He re-corded predation in Kansas by hawks, owls, racoons, and cornsnakes [Elaphe guttata), but considered the latter to be one of the most important predators. Cockrum (1952a) noted a wood rat, Neotoma micropus, carrying a M. velifer in a Kansas cave.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: In captivity M. velifer seemed more quarrelsome than most species. When Stagerconfined them with several other species of bats they attaekedand devoured Macrotus waterhousii.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: M. yumanensis is closely related to M. lucifugus and apparently the two species have been derived from the same stock in the rather recent geologic past. In some places in California the two species apparently are not reproductively isolated and introgressive hybridization occurs (Harris and Findley, 1962).
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: No one should enter a cave housing an active colony ofT. brasiliensis unless he has been immunized against rabies.Although one is not likely to be bitten, even when bats arecrawling all over him, rabies is a hazard in these caves. Inrecent years a bat research worker and another individual diedof rabies after entering the Texas bat caves, although neitherwas known to have been bitten by any animal.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: When heat forces the bats to move they frequently encounterman. They may first be noticed squeaking in the walls. Ifthere is a crevice around one of the window frames they maycrawl out into a room. Each time there is a heat wave we getseveral calls from people who have bats in the house. Usuallysuch bats are youngsters which have crawled out of the wallor from a crevice around a fireplace.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Luckens and Davis (1964) reported that these batsare extremely sensitive to DDT in comparison with othermammals. They were about 10 times as sensitive as somelaboratory species. Recent work, however, has shown that theeffect is influenced by season. A dose 20 times that which islethal in spring is not lethal in fall. The chlorinated hydrocarbonpesticides are fat soluble and apparently are quicklydeposited in the fat when eaten in autumn. The bats are mostsusceptible to poisoning when they emerge from hibernationwith fat reservoirs depleted in the spring.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: There are numerous reports of this species,as well as L. cinereus, being impaled on the barbs of a wirefence. In nearly every instance a barb of the top strand ofwire pierced the interfemoral membrane (fig. 76).
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Koestner (1942) gathered 15 red bats entrapped in oil on a 500-footstretch of road in Illinois in September. The road was heavilyoiled, and probably a migrating group mistook it for water.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: In West Virginia the species is still ratherabundant in certain caves. The center of distribution there isPendleton County, where it has been found in at least 15caves. The distribution in this region has been studied byConrad (1961). The bats seem to be abandoning more caveseach year, apparently as a result of ever increasing humandisturbance as spelunking becomes more popular. The species seems destined to perish in the eastern United States unlessthe caves it uses receive protection. It may not be too lateto save the eastern population, for as recently as 1962 anursery colony of over 1,000 survived in a remote portion ofa popular West Virginia cave (Hall, 1963b) and the colonyin Kentucky remains intact.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Prior to 1963 several nursery colonies were known, but apparentlynone remains in California caves today. Abandonment was caused by increasing disturbance by people. Some longestablished roosts were vacated. Graham chronicled the shiftingof one colony to ever more inaccessible regions of onecave before the cave was finally abandoned in 1961. He saidthat with cave exploration becoming ever more popularPlecotus may soon disappear entirely from the natural cavesof California.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Pearson et al. (1952) found that banding the young at night after allDuring the same night that 75 young were banded, the adultsreturned, picked up their young, and moved to another roostreturned, picked up their young, and moved to another roost1.3 miles away.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Night roosts in buildings are frequently a source of annoyance to man. Orr(1954) described instances where their excrement fouled hay in a barn/land/site/facility and a car in a garage. '"The open porch of a ranch house less than a year old was used as a night roost by agroup of these bats. When Orr visited the locality one evening, nine bats were resting on the beams supporting the roof. The beams had been creosoted recently, and an electriclight had been left burning on the porch all evening; neither seemed to discourage the bats.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: In Kansas a population of about 200, which inhabited an abandonedbarn/land/site/facility in summer, hibernated in winter in a crevice inthe ceiling of a cave about four miles away; they were destroyedin 1964 by vandals.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: There are several reports of these bats being caught inmousetraps. Davis (1960) captured one in a trap set beneatha mesquite bush in such a position that the bat must havecrawled over the ground to reach it. Most collectors of smallmammals who have trapped extensively in the NorthAmerican deserts have caught A. pallidus in mousetraps.Probably the bats are attracted to insects feeding on the bait.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: In most of the caves which harbor great colonies of T. brasiliensisin the United States the guano is harvested and sold asfertilizer. At Bracken Cave, Texas, where 20 million adultTadarida and their young live in summer, about 60 tons ofguano are harvested each year. The guano is removed during December and January when the bats are not present. It isa considerable source of income to the owner of the cave.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: We had some difficulty obtaining specimens of E. perotisto photograph. Since the known roosts in Arizona are in nearlyinaccessible crevices in high cliffs, we decided to try to getone in California where many roosts have been found in buildings.However, Luther Little told us that all the colonies hehad known have been destroyed, and Charles McLaughlin saidthat specimens have rarely been brought to the Los AngelesCounty Museum in recent years. We talked with several otherCalifornians who work with bats, and none knew where wecould obtain a E. perotis
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: C. mexicana is known from southern California as a result of an invasion in September 1946 when the animals appeared at many scattered localities in the city of San Diego. From September to December Laurence Huey collectedthirty-nine from such places as hallways, patios, and garages.Most were roosting singly but one group of about 40-50 livedin the cave-like understructure of a house for about a month.We know of no records of this bat in California before or sincethis invasion, except for a single individual captured in SanDiego in October, 1963.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: The cave in which M. grisescens of Kentucky and Illinois hibernate has recently been commercialized apparently resulting in the loss of this population.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: Summer colonies of this species are also receiving ever increasing harassment. The largest known colony (200,000- 300,000) inhabits Santa Cave in Alabama. This cave has been converted into a fallout shelter and is being commercialized. The bats were present as late as 1967 but their fate is un-certain. Old Nickajack Cave, the type locality and one of the best known colonies of M. grisescens, is being destroyed. The Tennessee Valley Authority has built a dam which will flood the cave.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column23: One male banded by MerlinTuttle in mid-winter in a cave in Campbell County, Tennessee,spent subsequent winters in Bat Cave, 145 miles to the north-east. The Tennessee cave had been converted to an air raidshelter. This disturbance may have caused the move.
column34: Barbour, R. W.,and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. Univ. Kentucky Press, Lexington, 286 pp.

column14: of the University of Manitoba Field Station, Delta Marsh, Manitoba, Canada (50011'N; 98023'W). The study area is at the southern end of Lake Manitoba
column23: Adult female L. cinereus and their young were located dur- ing the day as they roosted in the foliage of trees in the ridge.
column34: Barclay, R. M. R. 1989. The effect of reproductive condition on the foraging behavior of female hoary bats, Lasiurus cinereus. Behavioral and Ecological Sociobiology, 24: 31 -37.

column23: In summer, maternity or nursery roosts are found in attics, barn/land/site/facilitys, sheds, house of worship/templees, and other buildings. Such maternity locations are so common that data on the ecology and behavior of this species come almost exclusively from artificial roost sites (Kunz, 1982).
column34: Barclay, R. M. R., and K. J. Cash. 1985. A noncommensal maternity roost of the little brown bat (Myotis lucifugus). Journal of Mammalogy, 66: 782- 783.

column23: In summer, maternity or nursery roosts are found in attics, barn/land/site/facilitys, sheds, house of worship/templees, and other buildings. Such maternity locations are so common that data on the ecology and behavior of this species come almost exclusively from artificial roost sites (Kunz, 1982).

column23: In summer, maternity or nursery roosts are found in attics, barn/land/site/facilitys, sheds, house of worship/templees, and other buildings. Such maternity locations are so common that data on the ecology and behavior of this species come almost exclusively from artificial roost sites (Kunz, 1982).

column23: Here we report on a maternity colony of M. lucifugus located in a hollow tree near Payuk Lake, Manitoba (54?39'N/101?30'W). The bats inhabited a hollow 2 m above the ground in a live aspen (Populus tremu- loides). The roost entrance was a gap between the bark and inner wood extending vertically for 20-30 cm and the bats roosted above the entrance, under the bark. This tree was located in a stand of aspen and spruce (Picea glauca) approximately 250 m from the lake and amongst a dozen summer cottages.
column34: Barclay, R. M. R., and K. J. Cash. 1985. A noncommensal maternity roost of the little brown bat (Myotis lucifugus). Journal of Mammalogy, 66: 782- 783.

column23: On 10 and 11 July 1984 we counted 24 and 23 M. lucifugus, respectively, as they emerged from the aspen at dusk. The first bats emerged at 2237 h each night (23 min. after sunset). All had emerged by 2250 h on the 10th but on the 11th most did not emerge until 2319-2326 h, possibly due to our mist-netting activities the night before.
column34: Barclay, R. M. R., and K. J. Cash. 1985. A noncommensal maternity roost of the little brown bat (Myotis lucifugus). Journal of Mammalogy, 66: 782- 783.

column23: Roosts used by L. noctivagans typically were narrow crevices in tree trunks. The most common type ofroost (15 of 36 roosts) was a narrow space behind folds of the heavily furrowed bark of peach-leaved willowtrees. Other common roost types were splits in tree trunks (n = 12) and the narrow spaces formed betweentwo touching tree trunks (n=5).

column23: To determine whether previous occupancy affected roost selection, we presented artificial roosts to captiveL. noctivagans. A recently captured bat and two identical plywood roosts, constructed to mimic the narrowcrevices used naturally by L. noctivagans, were placed in a 1.25- by 1.00- by 0.75-m outdoor cage at dusk.One of the roosts had been occupied for 24 h by at least one L. noctivagans within the previous two days.

column23: It is also known to construct elaborate shelters. These shelters orstem tents are primarily constructed by single males atnight over a period of about 30 to 50 days. In TamilNadu, their construction corresponds to a biannualbreeding season. They provide the diurnal roosting site of females, their pups and a single breeding male(Balasingh et al, 1995).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: Phillips (1980) suggests that inSri Lanka it particularly favours the Talipot Palm as aroosting site; normally there are six to twelve individualsin each palm, with one or two bats sharing each leaf,hanging from the central rib by one foot with the wingswrapped around the body.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: Its roosting sites include talipot palms (BMNH) and morecommonly kitul palms where it spends the day suspendedwithin the large seed-clusters.

column23: Bhat et al. (1980) noted that when roosting, it formed compactclusters amidst the predominant R. leschenaulti. Theseclusters tended to be segregated according to sex andage, such that some were composed of juveniles, othersof adult males and yet more of adult females. It occupiedthe deeper crevices and cavities of the roof of the cavesand when disturbed it sought darker crevices and cornersas alternative roosting sites.

column23: It roosts in small caves, underground tunnels, old monuments and buildings. It is sometimes found in dark crevices, at other times it may be seen in large numbers in swarms on ceilings. It is surprisingly tolerant of light.

column23: Its favoured diurnal roost appearsto be hollow trees, especially old, decayed and broken offKitul and Arecanut palms, here it spends the day,clinging to the inside of the trunk with its wing clawsand feet while maintaining its head-down position; itmay occasionally also be found in the roofs of buildings (Phillips, 1980) and rock crevices (Lekagul & McNeely,1977).

column23: Its natural roost sites would appear to becaves, as at Talewadi, but it has also become adapted toman-made sites such as Buddhist caves (Brosset, 1962b),disused wells (Wroughton, 1913i), a mud temple (Rylejf1913bii), verandahs (Wroughton, 1915b), the lofts ofnative houses, especially those with tiled roofs,abandoned dwellings and occasionally hollow trees(Phillips, 1980).

column23: In the extensive cave complex atWavulpane in Sri Lanka, which includes a small ruimingstream, it shared its roost with a huge colony ofRousettus leschenaulti; other species present includedHipposideros lankadiva, Rhinolophus rouxii andMiniopterus schreibersii. Colony size ranges from a fewindividuals to over 200; when roosting it remainsisolated from its neighbour (Madhavan et al, 1978).

column23: In India, a colony ranging in size from 200 to500 individuals was located in a building in Khandwar,Madhya Pradesh between 26 May and 16 September;they were absent at other times. The bats selected thewarmer parts of the large, hot, dimly lit room, roostingin clusters both on the ceiling and in cracks. Themaximum temperature was about 40°C with a dailyfluctuation of about 10°C.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: Otomops wroughtoni is apparently confined toone diurnal roost, a large natural cave, situated on aremote plateau rising above a forested valley at analtitude of about 800 metres (2600 feet). The entrance tothe cave is concealed by trees and bushes. The cave isabout 40 metres deep, 25 metres broad and 6-7 metreshigh; there are permanent patches of water and a highdegree of humidity. Colony size is difficult to determineas they live in small groups of usually five to sevenindividuals in narrow cracks and deep hollows in theroof During the day, they keep silent and motionless;they hang by their feet, head down and with only theextremity of their muzzles protruding; both sexes livetogether (Brosset, 1962c).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: Otomops wroughtoni is apparently confined toone diurnal roost, a large natural cave, situated on aremote plateau rising above a forested valley at analtitude of about 800 metres (2600 feet)...The colony was brieflyrevisited in March 1992 (Daniel et ai, 1992); it was notpossible to determine colony size with accuracy but thereappeared to be at least 40+ individuals (Bates et ai,1994c).

column14: the square near the Royal Palace, Jalalabad
column23: At Jalalabad in Afghanistan, a colony of 2000 individualsformed a smnmer colony in an underground canalbeneath the square near the Royal Palace. The canal isabout 50 metres long and 1.5 metres wide. At its entrance, it is about 1.2 metres high, graduallydecreasing to 0.8 metres at the far end. The tuimel isvery warm with an estimated temperature of about 20°C.The bats hung in several clusters freely from the ceiling;the roost was shared with a small colony of about 200Miniopterus schreibersii (Hanak & Gaisler, 1969).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: According to Topal (1970b), it was collected ina mist net set in the large entrance chamber of a cave inthe village of Mausmai, near Cherrapunji in Meghalaya. The gave was at an altitude of 1600 metres (5200 feet)and was situated in a rather dense karst forest, whichwas subtropic in character, with Dracena and anevergreen Quercus as the dominant plant species. Nearby was a large stream. A single specimen wascollected at 5.40 pm on 19 November 1967, some 4 5minutes after nightfall. It was flying into the cave fromthe outside and was caught some 60-70 cm above theground. The cave was possibly its nocturnal restingarea; it was not used as a diurnal roost. The previousnight some three individuals of this species had beenobserved in this same cave at 5.30 pm (Topal, 1970b).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: During the day, it lives singly or in very small partres of both sexes hidden away amongthe foliage of some very large, very dense, large-leafedtree. Once concealed amongst the leaves, it is usuallyexceedingly difficult to discover (Phillips, 1980).

column23: At Robbers' Cave, near Mahableshwar, Brosset (1962c) estimated therewere some 100,000 individuals with a density of about2000 bats/ m . The majority were in vast swarms, theirheads kept down and their bodies extraordinarily pressedtogether, often in several layers. Others were isolated,scattered all around and hanging by their fore limbs.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: At Robbers' Cave, near Mahableshwar, Brosset (1962c) estimated therewere some 100,000 individuals with a density of about2000 bats/ m ...Brosset (1962c) suggested that there are two types ofcolony; the 'mother colony' which is situated in a largenatural cave, usually with a subterranean water sourceinside and 'secondaiy colonies', usually situated within70 km of the mother house and located in caves of muchsmaller size, here groups of individuals stay periodically
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: The specimen from the Kathmandu Valley wasfound dead in a room early on the morning of 2September (Scully 1887).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column14: Mount Hiko at an altitude of 700 metres
column23: In Japan, a group of six females with young were located on Mount Hiko at an altitude of 700 metres(2275 feet); they were roosting in the open at the top of aJapanese cedar tree (Cryptomeria).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: Single individualswere also found in caves during the summer (Wallin, 1969).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: Summer roosts of M. ussuriensis (formerly included in M. auratasee Maeda, 1980) in Japan include open dense bushes; afemale with a single infant was collected from such aroosting site.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: Its diurnal roosts include large dead and dryleaves of cardomom plants. Usually several individualswill be secreted in a single leaf or bunch of leaves, thecolour of the fiu blending so perfectly with that of the dead leaf that they are verydifficult to detect Phillips 1980).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: A colony of three individuals was also foundroosting in a small rock cave in the forests ofGammaduma (BMNH).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column14: North-Western Frontier Province, slopes of Mikanjani above Nathia Gali at an altitude of 2615 metres (8500 feet)
column23: In North-Western Frontier Province, Pakistan, itwas collected on the slopes of Mikanjani above NathiaGali at an altitude of 2615 metres (8500 feet); it wasroosting in a tree, some 1.2 metres (4 feet) above theground (BMNH).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column14: 2462 metres (8000 feet) at Miranjani in the Murree Hills
column23: In Pakistan, it was collected at 2154 metres(7000 feet) at Gilgit in Naltar Valley and at 2462 metres(8000 feet) at Miranjani in the Murree Hills. This latterspecimen was found under a flake of bark.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: It roosts during the day, either singly oroccasionally in pairs, in the dead, down-hanging driedleaves of plantain (or "banana') plants, usually in a smallgrove. Its bright pelage colour makes it very difficult tolocate amongst these dead leaves (Phillips, 1980).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: In Rajasthan, it was found roostingin July/August in the half built nests of the Baya Weaverbird (Ploceus philippinus) suspended from trees of Prosopis spicigera-, the bats were hanging from the roofof the nests (Sharma, 1986).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: In Kerala, a male, female andsuckling infant were collected from dry banana leaves on26 August (Ramachandran & Jayson, 1994).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column14: altitude of 2060 metres (6695 feet) at Patni Top in Kashmir
column23: In India, it was found at analtitude of 2060 metres (6695 feet) at Patni Top inKashmir where it was roosting among the tiles coveringthe roof of a forest bungalow.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column14: Gomok, at altitude of 308 metres (1000 feet)
column23: At Gomok at an altitude of 308 metres (1000feet), a roosting pair were collected from the intemodeof a dead bamboo (BMNH).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: Very little is known of the habits of this bat inthe Nicobar and Andaman Islands. One specimen wasreportedly collected in dense forest, together withPteropus melanotus (Zelebor, 1869).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: In Karnataka, it was found in subterraneancaves in laterite rock situated on forest clad hill slopes.It was ecologically related to Rousettus leschenaulti throughoutthe year and with the maternity colonies of Hipposideroslankadiva and Hipposideros speoris.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: In Karnataka, it was found in subterraneancaves in laterite rock situated on forest clad hill slopes.It was ecologically related to Rousettus leschenaulti throughoutthe year and with the maternity colonies of Hipposideroslankadiva and Hipposideros speoris.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: In Karnataka, it was found in subterraneancaves in laterite rock situated on forest clad hill slopes.It was ecologically related to Rousettus leschenaulti throughoutthe year and with the maternity colonies of Hipposideroslankadiva and Hipposideros speoris.

column23: Bhat et al. (1980) noted that when roosting, it formed compactclusters amidst the predominant R. leschenaulti. Theseclusters tended to be segregated according to sex andage, such that some were composed of juveniles, othersof adult males and yet more of adult females. It occupiedthe deeper crevices and cavities of the roof of the cavesand when disturbed it sought darker crevices and cornersas alternative roosting sites.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: It was "plentiful" in a caveat Tagoot, Myamnar, which it cohabited with other fruitbats and Emballonuridae (Wroughton, 1915b).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: At Barmer in Rajasthan, a colony of some 30-40 individualswas located in cave; this locality was also inhabited byRhinopoma microphyllum; however, the two specieswere spatially separated with T. perforatus occupying thedarkest portion (Prakash, 1961).

column23: Little is known of this rare bat in India. AtKrishnapur, its roost was located in a natural cave inwild and forested country; Rousettus leschenaulti wasalso present (Brosset, 1962a).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: In the extensive cave complex atWavulpane in Sri Lanka, which includes a small ruimingstream, it shared its roost with a huge colony ofRousettus leschenaulti; other species present includedHipposideros lankadiva, Rhinolophus rouxii andMiniopterus schreibersii. Colony size ranges from a fewindividuals to over 200; when roosting it remainsisolated from its neighbour (Madhavan et al, 1978).

column23: In Malaysia, it is a gregarious species that is recorded from many cave sites, including Batu Cave, Selangor and is often associatedwith Hipposideros armiger
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: In. Arabia, it is a relatively rare bat which is found roosting inunderground water channels where it frequently cohabitswith Asellia tridens (Harrison & Bates, 1991).

column14: the square near the Royal Palace, Jalalabad
column23: At Jalalabad in Afghanistan, a colony of 2000 individualsformed a smnmer colony in an underground canalbeneath the square near the Royal Palace. The canal isabout 50 metres long and 1.5 metres wide. At its entrance, it is about 1.2 metres high, graduallydecreasing to 0.8 metres at the far end. The tuimel isvery warm with an estimated temperature of about 20°C.The bats hung in several clusters freely from the ceiling;the roost was shared with a small colony of about 200Miniopterus schreibersii (Hanak & Gaisler, 1969).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: Other bat species known to share the same roosting sites includeRhinolophus rouxii (HZM), Miniopterus schreibersii andHipposideros speoris (Hill, 1976b).

column23: In Pakistan, a specimen was collected fromDunga Gali at an altitude of 2338 metres (7600 feet); itwas roosting in a deserted pump house, which it sharedwith a small colony of female Myotis mystacinus(BMNH).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: In Malaysia, of the 402 roosting sites examined, 208 hadonly T. pachypus, 193 only T. robustula and just one hadboth species present. However, sometimes roosts vacatedby one species are subsequently used by the other.

column23: Its diet includes the fruits of dates (Phoenix dactylifera), guava(Psidium guajava) and pipal tree (Ficus religosa),bananas (Musa sp.) and papayas (Carica papaya), thenectar of mango (Mangifera indica) and silk cotton trees(Bombax malabarica) and the berries of the PersianLilac (Melia azedarach) and 'Neem' tree (Meliaazedarachta).

column23: Blanford (1888-91) reported Rousettus amplexicaudatus (here considered tobe R. leschenaulti) feeding on exposed molluscs atMoulmein in Myarunar. This would appear to beexceptional behaviour as generally it feeds on fruits andflowers which it detects using its advanced sense ofsmell; it may share fruit trees with other species such asPteropus giganteus and Cynopterus sphinx.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: Advani (1982a) noted that during the late monsoon (July) season in north-west India, it feeds on the ripe fiuits of jaman(E. jambolana), consuming juices and rejecting the stoneand pulp. During the flowering of the mango, itdamages mango orchards. In August and September, itfeeds upon ripe pears in Pakistan. In late winter (March) it has been observed feeding on the nectar of the Silkcotton trees (Salmalia malabaricuni) in Pakistan and theguava {P. guajava) in Rajasthan and Gujarat.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: Food plants of P. g. giganteus fromIndia and Sri Lanka include the flowers and flower budsof the silk cotton tree {Gossampinus malabaricus), tuliptree{Spathodea campunulata), red gum {Eucalyptusrobusta), albizzia (A. falcata), dadap (Erythrinalithosperma), rubber (Heavea braziliensis) and coconutpalms. Fruits include those of the mango (Mangiferaindica), the jak (Artocarpus Integra), soursop (Annonamuricata), guavas (Psidium guajava and Rhodomyrtustomentosus), plantain, banana (Musaparadisiaca),papaws (Carica papaya)', Indian blackberry (Syzygiumcumini). Ficus (Prakash, 1961), teak, custard apple, palm(Borassus flabelifer), date (Phoenix silvestris), mahua(Bassia latifolia) and wood apple (Feronia sp.), togetherwith the many fruits and flowers of jungle trees (Phillips,1980: Sinha, 1986a).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: Food plants of P. g. giganteus fromIndia and Sri Lanka include the flowers and flower budsof the silk cotton tree {Gossampinus malabaricus), tuliptree{Spathodea campunulata), red gum {Eucalyptusrobusta), albizzia (A. falcata), dadap (Erythrinalithosperma), rubber (Heavea braziliensis) and coconutpalms. column23: On Christmas Island off the south coast ofJava, over 20 species of food plant utilised by P.melanotus have been identified, including mango(Mangifera indica), papaya (Carica papaya) and guava(Psidium guajava) (Mickleburgh et al., 1992).

column23: In Rajasthan, it favours guavasin winter (December-February); the Indian mango; datepalm and the seeds of Phoenix sylvestris in summer(March-June); the custard apple in the monsoon period(July-August) and the fruits of chikus in the postmonsoon season (October-November); it is also known toeat bananas and lichies (Advani, 1982a).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: Balasubramanian (1988) estimates that it eats the fruitsof nearly 25 plant species, as well as the leaves of Cassiafistula.

column23: According to Phillips (1980), it favours the twospecies of guava commonly grown in the hills of SriLanka. It will eat large quantities of these fruits, suckingthe juices and scattering the remains often in theverandahs of nearby bungalows.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: The diet consists mostly of pollen and nectarfrom night flowering plants and according to Andersen(1912) it feeds in groups.It rarely, if ever eats fruits, butis a pollinator of many commercially important speciesincluding durian, kapok (Bombacaceae), abaca(Musaceae), wild banana {Musa spp.), mangroves andmany valuable forest trees (Start & Marshall, 1976;Gould, 1978).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: In winter (December-Febmary), some53.4% is comprised of beetles, whilst cockroaches andhouse crickets are also favoured. In summer (March-June), the percentage of beetles falls to 16.2% and isreplaced by winged white ants, moths, grasshoppers,crickets, wasps and lace winged flies; there is also a highoccurrence of the bat's own fur in stomach contents. Inthe monsoon season (July-September), the percentage ofwinged termites increases, along with beetles,cockroaches and moths. In the post monsoon period(October-November), the percentage of beetles increasesto 38.7%, house crickets and cockroaches are also favoured. In general, it is apparent that this speciesperforms a useful role in reducing the abundance ofharmful insects.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: According to Advani (1981a), who examined the stomach contents of 150 M.lyra from 8 districts of Rajasthan, the diet varies on aseasonal basis. In winter (December-February),vertebrates comprise 77.8%, beetles 12.2% and otherinsects 10.0% of the food intake; the vertebrates areprimarily reptiles (30.5%) such as the wall lizard,Hemidactylus flaviviridis, as well as fishes and birds. Insummer (March-June), the ratio of insects andvertebrates is about equal, 46.7% and 53.3%respectively; the coleoptera are mainly scarabids, curculionids and carabids; winged termites are alsoabundant (10%); lizards are in higher proportions(18.3%) to the other vertebrate groups, followed by birds(10.4%), fishes (10.2%) and frogs (9.2%). In the rainyseason (July-September), insects constitute 70% andvertebrates 30% of the total diet; among the insects, theproportion of termites and beetles increase to 26.0% and24.6% respectively. In the post-monsoon season(October-November), insects (59.1%) are favoured tovertebrates (40.9%); Hymenoptera, mainly swarmingwasps and ants represent 17.8%, followed by beetles,moths and termites; amongst the vertebrates, theproportion of frogs and toads increase abruptly to 21.5%,while lizards are only 5.5%; some fish material is alsopresent. Bird species preyed on include White-eyes(Zosterops sp.) and Sunbirds (Nectarinia sp.), theSparrow {Passer domesticus) (Advani, 1981a) andDusky Crag Martin {Hirundo concolor) (Brosset,1962b); bat species include Rhinopoma microphyllum, R.hardwickii, Taphozous perforatus (Advani, 1981a);Pipistrellus sp. (Brosset, 1962b) and Hipposideros sp.(Sinha, 1986a); Insectivores such as Suncus murinus(Sinha, 1986a) are also taken. It will also eat rats, miceand gerbils.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

(Brosset, 1962b) and Hipposideros sp.(Sinha, 1986a); Insectivores such as Suncus murinus(Sinha, 1986a) are also taken. It will also eat rats, miceand gerbils.

(Brosset, 1962b) and Hipposideros sp.(Sinha, 1986a); Insectivores such as Suncus murinus(Sinha, 1986a) are also taken. It will also eat rats, miceand gerbils.
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: According to Advani (1981a), who examined the stomach contents of 150 M.lyra from 8 districts of Rajasthan, the diet varies on aseasonal basis. In winter (December-February),vertebrates comprise 77.8%, beetles 12.2% and otherinsects 10.0% of the food intake; the vertebrates areprimarily reptiles (30.5%) such as the wall lizard,Hemidactylus flaviviridis, as well as fishes and birds. Insummer (March-June), the ratio of insects andvertebrates is about equal, 46.7% and 53.3%respectively; the coleoptera are mainly scarabids, curculionids and carabids; winged termites are alsoabundant (10%); lizards are in higher proportions(18.3%) to the other vertebrate groups, followed by birds(10.4%), fishes (10.2%) and frogs (9.2%). column23: Advani (1982b) undertook a detailedanalysis of their diet. He noted that Coleoptera,Lepidoptera, Orthoptera, Hymenoptera and Diptera arepreferred in all four main seasons, whilst termites areeatsd in all except the winter season. The presenceof ground-dweUing insects, caterpillars, spiders, largerbodied insects and water beetles suggests that these preyitems were collected not through aerial pursuit but ratherby picking them off the ground and other surfaces.

column23: In Rajasthan for example, in winter (December-February)it feeds primarily on beetles (66.6%) followed by cockroaches and wingless ants. In summer (March-June), it lives on a variety of insects including grasshoppers and crickets, termites, beetles, and moths. In the monsoon season (July-September), the soft winged forms of termites are eatsd in the highest proportion (45.5%) whilst moths, Hymenoptera and Orthopteraaverage between 10-15% of the diet. In the post monsoon period (October- November), beetles represent some (31.4% of the siet; winges ants and wasps (31 0%), crickets, grasshoppers, flies and mosquitoS are also favoured (Advani, 1981b).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: An analysis of its feeding habits in Rajasthansuggests that there is seasonal variation in the composition of the diet. In winter (December-February),it mainly feeds on beetles (40% of intake), also moths,grasshoppers, crickets and Neuroptera (at about 10-17%). In the summer season (March-June), wingedtermites (24.4%) and beetles (21.0%) are the preferredfood, with moths, Orthoptera and Hymenoptera alsoeaten in appreciable proportions. In the monsoon season(July-September), termites constitute 43.5% of the diet; Coleoptera, Lepidoptera, Orthoptera and Hymenopteraare also present in variable proportions. In the postmonsoonperiod (October-November), beetles once moredominate the diet (42.1%) (Advani, 1981c).
column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column34: Bates, P. J. J., and D. L. Harrison. 1997. Bats of the Indian Subcontinent. Harrison Zoological Museum, Sevenoaks, Kent.

column23: An analysis of its feeding habits in Rajasthansuggests that there is seasonal variation in the composition of the diet. In winter (December-February),it mainly feeds on beetles (40% of intake), also moths,grasshoppers, crickets and Neuroptera (at about 10-17%). In the summer season (March-June), wingedtermites (24.4%) and beetles (21.0%) are the preferredfood, with moths, Orthoptera and Hymenoptera alsoeaten in appreciable proportions. In the monsoon season(July-September), termites constitute 43.5% of the diet; Coleoptera, Lepidoptera, Orthoptera and Hymenopteraare also present in variable proportions. In the postmonsoonperiod (October-November), beetles once moredominate the diet (42.1%) (Advani, 1981c).

column23: Advani (1982a) noted that during the late monsoon (July) season in north-west India, it feeds on the ripe fiuits of jaman(E. jambolana), consuming juices and rejecting the stoneand pulp. column14: north slope of the SIerra de Guadarrama, Valsain, Segovia
column23: The study site is in a 130 ha forest of Pinus sylvestris situated on thenorth slope of the Sierra de Guadarrama (Valsam, Segovia, CentralSpain) at an altitude of 1,400 m. During 1988 bird boxes were erectedin the study area. Some ofthese boxes were subsequently used by bats.The boxes were distributed in rows 50-70 m apart, distribution wasnot always uniform due to the topography of the forest. The meandensity was four boxes per hectare.The cumulative number of box checks was 5,674. Visits were madefrom March to November 1989, with intervals of 2 to 12 days betweenvisits. We found bats in 170 box checks (3 %) and bat droppings in an-other 479 (8,44%). Lofts, bridges and small caves in the sourroundingarea were also visited periodically as probable alternative roostingsites.
column34: Benzal, J. 1991. Population dynamics of the brown long-eared bat (Plecotus auritus) occupying bird boxes in a pine forest plantation in central Spain. Netherlands Journal ofZoology, 41: 241- 249.

column14: Guano Cave (5 km N Buena Vista), Falcon
column23: Field and laboratory work was performed 24July-18 September 1985, 30 June-10 August1986, 9-24 June 1987, and 12-20 August 1988in the state of Falcon, Venezuela. A total of 35P. davyi, 25 P. personatus, 29 P. parnellii, and23 M. megalophylla was used. All mormoopidspecies except P. parnellii were captured at Gua-no Cave (5 km N Buena Vista) and at BarraHonda Cave (3 km W San Jose de Cocadita)within tropical thorn forest. P. parnellii was cap-tured at Chipare Cave (8 km E Guaibacoa) with-in tropical dry forest.
column34: Bonaccorso, F, A. Arends, M.Genoud, D. Cantoni, and T. Morton. 1992. Thermal ecology of moustached and ghost-faced bats (Mormoopidae) in Venezuela. Journal of Mammalogy, 73:365-378.

Domes and tunnels in the deepest partof Guano Cave are sites of M. megalophyllanurseries and have the highest temperatures(36.00C) in the cave because of the com-bined effects of trapping metabolic heat frombats and organic reactions taking place inthe guano and arthropod community on thecave floor.

All mormoopidspecies except P. parnellii were captured at Gua-no Cave (5 km N Buena Vista) and at BarraHonda Cave (3 km W San Jose de Cocadita)within tropical thorn forest. P. parnellii was cap-tured at Chipare Cave (8 km E Guaibacoa) with-in tropical dry forest.
column34: Bonaccorso, F, A. Arends, M.Genoud, D. Cantoni, and T. Morton. 1992. Thermal ecology of moustached and ghost-faced bats (Mormoopidae) in Venezuela. Journal of Mammalogy, 73:365-378.

column14: Chipare Cave (8 km E Guaibacoa), Falcon

column14: Chipare Cave (8 km E Guaibacoa), Falcon
column23: In the upland tropical dry forest, groupsof mixed-sex P. parnellii select roosts within Chipare Cave 90C cooler than roost sitesof female mormoopids at Guano Cave (Ta-ble 3). P. parnellii roost in large numbers indomes and under ledges that trap metabolicheat. Roost sites chosen by female P. par-nellii as nurseries were inaccessible to us,though lactating females were captured fly-ing in this cave in July and August. Wehypothesize that females select somewhatwarmer nursery sites, possibly in remotechambers with restricted ventilation or inother caves with small entrances such thatbody heat can be trapped more efficiently.
column34: Bonaccorso, F, A. Arends, M.Genoud, D. Cantoni, and T. Morton. 1992. Thermal ecology of moustached and ghost-faced bats (Mormoopidae) in Venezuela. Journal of Mammalogy, 73:365-378.

column14: Barra Honda Cave (3 km W San Jose de Cocadita), Falcon
column23: Most female M. megalophylla are scattered through a variety ofwarmer interior chambers mixed with nurseries of Leptonycteris curasoae where ambient temperature ranges from 33.4 to34.20C.
column34: Bonaccorso, F, A. Arends, M.Genoud, D. Cantoni, and T. Morton. 1992. Thermal ecology of moustached and ghost-faced bats (Mormoopidae) in Venezuela. Journal of Mammalogy, 73:365-378.

column23: Male M. megalophylla select cooler cavesthan Guano Cave as day-roosts, a behaviorthat frees them from having depressed basalrates of metabolism. At Guano Cave, malescomposed only 5% of the M. megalophyllapopulation of 300 bats.

column23: The three megachiropteran species used in this study belong to the genus Pteropus (familyPteropodidae) and are all fruit, flower and nectar feeders. They roost in trees during daylighthours, forming large colonies or ‘camps’.
column34: Bennett, M. 1993. Structural modifications involved in the fore and hind limb grip of some flying foxes (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Journal of Zoology (London), 229: 237- 248.

column14: Alter do Chao, near Santarern, Para State. (2'31'S, 55'OO'W)
column23: On 6 May 1998. during a survey of the bat fauna of Alter do Chao. near Santarern, Para State. Brazil(2'31'S, 55'OO'W), I found a roost of P. leucoptera...Twelve white-winged bats (fable 1) were roosting in an unidentified. dead. hollow tree that was lying onthe ground in an 8-ha forested area. The trunk of the tree was 10m long and ca. 1.5 m m diameter. Therewas one main entrance at the base of the fallen tree and three smaller openings along the trunk...The colony consisted of three adult females (one carrying a young). three adult males. and five subadults, all grouped together. This grouping suggests the lack of harems. and the presence of several subadults, as well as pregnant females, may indicate that the colony was a maternity roost.
column34: Bernard, E. 1999. Notes on a colony of Perapteryx leucoptera (Emballonuridae) in Brazil. Bat Research News, 40: 37- 38.

column23: In Ontario, a summer colony of ca. 12 bats was behind a slidingbarn door on 6 July (Hitchcock, 1955).

column23: The only known hibernation sites are cavesand old mines (Davis, 1955; Fenton, 1972; Hall, 1962; Hitchcock,1946; Krutzsch, 1966; Mohr, 1933, 1936; Schwager and Benton,1956), where it often occupies narrow crevices, hangs on the wallor from the ceiling, or is on the floor of the hibernaculum in crevicesor under rocks (Allen, 1939; Davis, 1955; Martin et al., 1966;McDaniel et al., 1982).

column23: The largest known group of hibernating M. leibii was in FourthChute Cave, Renfrew Co., Ontario. In the drafty passage at FourthChute Cave, M. ·leibii usually hibernated in narrow cracks in thewall or ceiling (Hitchcock, 1949). On 5 April, 30 were present, on6 January, there were 76, on 25 and 26 February, there were 85and 142, respectively (Hitchcock, 1946). In one small fissure, 35were present on 4 January. They were packed so solidly that itappeared almost impossible for those farthest in to get air. On 29November, few M. leibii were present (Hitchcock, 1949).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: It also occurred in a mine shaft located alonga large creek that passed through a tract of hemlock-beech-hardmaple forest. The shaft extended ca. 25 m horizontally into the sideof a steep hill, and in winter, the temperature was nearly freezingthroughout its length (Schwager and Benton, 1956).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column14: Little Mammoth Cave, Campbell Co., Tennessee
column23: In Tennessee, M. leibii was present in Little Mammoth Cave,Campbell Co., on 27 March. Outside the cave, the temperature was21°C, the temperature 135 m inside, where two M. leibii wereencountered, was 9°C, and 220 m inside, where a third individualwas encountered, it was 11°C. The cave was 315 m long and locatedon the side of a steep hillside in a mature deciduous forest. Theentrance to the cave was ca. 2 m wide and 3 m high. The pelageof these three bats was entirely dry, indicating they probably hadbeen active. Although torpid, the bats became active quickly. On4 March, another was 3 m back under a ledge and 0.3 m abovethe floor. The temperature was 4°C and the bat was torpid (Tuttle,1964).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: In North Carolina, one male and one female were present on19 January in man-made tunnels, which had been constructed formining of talc. The tunnels in which the bats were found were ca.25 m deep, and both were moist. One bat was flying and the otherwas hanging from the wall ca. 20 m inside the mouth of the tunnel.Because the bats were easily disturbed, it is possible they were nothibernating (Schwartz, 1954).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: In Vermont, M. leibii was hibernating in a cave with E. fuscus, M. lucifugus, M.septentrionalis, M. sodalis, and P. subflavus in late January. Insteadof hanging by the hind feet, M. leibii was tucked away singlyor rarely two together, in small depressions or crannies of the rock,lying down flat on their venters (Allen, 1939).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: A mine ca. 10 km from this cave, which had been flooded from 1918 to1964, was drained in 1964. In winter 1965-1966, 57 hibernatingM. leibii were counted in the mine, and 22 were present in winter1966-1967. The small-footed myotis hibernated in areas of themine with good air flow, lower humidity, and lower temperaturesthan other parts of the mine (M. B. Fenton, in litt.).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: In Pennsylvania, most groups of M. leibii reported in cavesprior to 1979 have disappeared. However, 21 new hibernacula havebeen reported from an eight-county area; 17 of these were newlocalities for hibernating M. leibii. Most populations contained fewerthan five individuals per site; the largest group in a cave contained29 individuals (Dunn and Hall, 1989).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: It apparently uses the ceilings of caves, ca. 3 m above the floor, as nightroosts (Davis et al., 1965).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: This tiny bat occurs in drafty open mines and caves, and hangsnear the entrance where the temperatures drop below freezing. Atthese roost sites, humidity is relatively low (Barbour and Davis,1969; Fenton, 1972) and subject to greater fluctuation than deeperin the cave or mine (Fenton, 1972).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: Myotis leibii is among the last to move into caves in autumn, seldom appearing before mid-November and leaving by March or April (Bailey, 1933; Barbour and Davis, 1969; Fenton, 1972; Ganier ad Elder, 1973; Hitchcock, 1965; Mohr, 1945).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: Myotis leibii is among the last to move into caves in autumn, seldom appearing before mid-November and leaving by March or April (Bailey, 1933; Barbour and Davis, 1969; Fenton, 1972; Ganier ad Elder, 1973; Hitchcock, 1965; Mohr, 1945).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: Myotis leibii is among the last to move into caves in autumn, seldom appearing before mid-November and leaving by March or April (Bailey, 1933; Barbour and Davis, 1969; Fenton, 1972; Ganier ad Elder, 1973; Hitchcock, 1965; Mohr, 1945).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: Myotis leibii is among the last to move into caves in autumn, seldom appearing before mid-November and leaving by March or April (Bailey, 1933; Barbour and Davis, 1969; Fenton, 1972; Ganier ad Elder, 1973; Hitchcock, 1965; Mohr, 1945).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: Myotis leibii is among the last to move into caves in autumn, seldom appearing before mid-November and leaving by March or April (Bailey, 1933; Barbour and Davis, 1969; Fenton, 1972; Ganier ad Elder, 1973; Hitchcock, 1965; Mohr, 1945).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: Myotis leibii is among the last to move into caves in autumn, seldom appearing before mid-November and leaving by March or April (Bailey, 1933; Barbour and Davis, 1969; Fenton, 1972; Ganier ad Elder, 1973; Hitchcock, 1965; Mohr, 1945).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: Furthermore, M. leibii may move in and out of caves during the milder parts of winter (Hitchcock, 1965; Mohr, 1936), returning when it becomes colder. No shifting from one cave to another has been noted, except for one individual, which after original hibernating site was closed during a rock fall, took up winter quarters in a cave several hundred meters away (Mohr, 1936).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: Furthermore, M. leibii may move in and out of caves during the milder parts of winter (Hitchcock, 1965; Mohr, 1936), returning when it becomes colder. No shifting from one cave to another has been noted, except for one individual, which after original hibernating site was closed during a rock fall, took up winter quarters in a cave several hundred meters away (Mohr, 1936).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: Some individuals hibernate horizontally (Godin, 1977), beneath stones or in crevices on the floor of caves and mines (Davis, 1955; Martin et al. 1966).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: Some individuals hibernate horizontally (Godin, 1977), beneath stones or in crevices on the floor of caves and mines (Davis, 1955; Martin et al. 1966).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column14: Schoolhouse Cave, Pendleton Co., West Virginia
column23: One was found on the floor of Schoolhouse Cave, Pendleton Co., West Virginia, on 26 January. It was in a small crevice in the clay floor, well out of sight, and it was vocalizing and active when uncovered.
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column14: Greenville Saltpeter Cave, Monroe Co., West Virginia
column23: Another was observed under loose rocks on the floor of Greenville Saltpeter Cave, Monroe Co., West Virginia, on 27 Decemeber. It was ca. 15 cm below the surface and there was considerable amount of feces among the rocks near the bat (Davis, 1955).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: Myotis leibii deserts the caves long before other hibernating bats. This may indicate migratory movement in late winter (Mohr, 1933).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: Myotis leibii deserts the caves long before other hibernating bats. This may indicate migratory movement in late winter (Mohr, 1933).  Departures occur while M. lucifugus and M. sodalis are still hibernating (Mohr, 1936).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: In Ontario and Quebec, M. leibii occurs in the same caves asEptesicus fuscus, Pipistrellus subflavus, M. lucifugus, and M. septentrionalis(Hitchcock, 1949)...In Ontario, M. leibii is known tohibernate in physical contact with E. fuscus, usually in small clustersof less than five bats, but it was not observed close to or inphysical contact with M. lucifugus (Fenton, 1972).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: In Vermont, M. leibii was hibernating in a cave with E. fuscus, M. lucifugus, M.septentrionalis, M. sodalis, and P. subflavus in late January. Insteadof hanging by the hind feet, M. leibii was tucked away singlyor rarely two together, in small depressions or crannies of the rock,lying down flat on their venters (Allen, 1939).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column23: In commercializing Fourth Chute Cave, construction eliminatedthe circulation of cold air in one of the unvisited passages ofthe cave where the largest known population of M. leibii in easternNorth America hibernated. These bats were totally dispossessed asa result of the warmer microclimate produced (Mohr, 1972).
column34: Best, T.L.; Jennings, J.B. Myotis leibii. Mamm. Species 1997, 547, 1-6.

column14: Spring Creek, about 20 km west of La Grande, Oregon
column23: Regardless of the reasons that these bats need big trees and regardless of the reasons for roost site liability, it is clear that individuals use several large trees each breeding season. Unfortunately, large trees, both live and dead, are often most valued by humans for lumber, other wood products, and firewood,. There is tremendous political pressure in our study region to increase salwage logging of large tracts of timber killed by recent insect attacks and drought before the trees lose their value through decay and before they fuel a devastating fire. Lumber companies want large trees as well as small, but even if only the smaller ones are removed the remaining isolated ones are more than likely to fall in a windstorm. It is important that forest managers recognize the value of large trees to bats as well as other species as they plan salvage and green timber sales. Hopefully, the information coming out of this conference will help provide the documentation that they will need to plan wisely.

column23: In the present study, day roosts with single or small groups of bats were located under roofeves, roofing over porches; funnel or boat shaped tents fabricated by the bats under green fronds of palms, namely Borassus flabellifer (Palmyra palm), Coccothrinax argentea(Silver thatch palm), Corypha umbraculifera (Talipot palm), Livistona chinensis (Chinesefan palm), Roystonea regia (Cuban royal palm) and Sabal palmetto (Cabbagepalm); within the space between drooping dry fronds of the above palms; underbanana leaves ; inside clustered leaves of Philodendron giganteum ; in the funnel-shapedspace under the foliage of Polyalthia longifolia var pendulosa (often the space iscaused by the bat by pruning the obstructing branches); in leaf clusters of Persea gratissima(Avocado); and in bell-shaped cavity in the pendulous flower or fruit bunch ofCaryota urens carved out by bats by chewing and dropping the central flower or fruitbearing strings.
column34: Bhat, H. R. 1994. Observations of the food and feeding behavior of Cynopterus sphinx Vahl (Chiroptera, Pteropodidae) at Pune, India. Mammalia, 58: 363-370.

column34: Bhat, H. R. 1994. Observations of the food and feeding behavior of Cynopterus sphinx Vahl (Chiroptera, Pteropodidae) at Pune, India. Mammalia, 58: 363-370.

column23: The roosts under the man-made permanent structuressuch as ceilings, roofeves and roofings over porches are used year after year. Theselong term spaces and some of the compact tents are generally used as maternity roosts.
column34: Bhat, H. R. 1994. Observations of the food and feeding behavior of Cynopterus sphinx Vahl (Chiroptera, Pteropodidae) at Pune, India. Mammalia, 58: 363-370.

column23: A preferred feeding roost is often located under a horizontalbough with a dense drooping umbrella-like crown of leaves. Where fan palms arefound the feeding roosts are located under funnel-shaped tents.
column34: Bhat, H. R. 1994. Observations of the food and feeding behavior of Cynopterus sphinx Vahl (Chiroptera, Pteropodidae) at Pune, India. Mammalia, 58: 363-370.

column23: C. sphinx has been reported to roost during day in small groups inside the droopinggreen and dry palm fronds, drooping green foliage, aerial roots of banyan trees;under the roof or ceilings of deserted buildings and the bark of trees (Brosset 1962,Sandhu 1984, Sinha 1986, Khajuria 1979, Advani 1982).
column34: Bhat, H. R. 1994. Observations of the food and feeding behavior of Cynopterus sphinx Vahl (Chiroptera, Pteropodidae) at Pune, India. Mammalia, 58: 363-370.

column23: This bat also is reported to construct tent-like roosting structures from large pinnate fronds of Corypha palm bychewing veins of the leaflets which causes the collapse of the leaflets to form a tent(Goodwin 1979, Kunz 1982).
column34: Bhat, H. R. 1994. Observations of the food and feeding behavior of Cynopterus sphinx Vahl (Chiroptera, Pteropodidae) at Pune, India. Mammalia, 58: 363-370.

column23: This bat also is reported to construct tent-like roosting structures from large pinnate fronds of Corypha palm bychewing veins of the leaflets which causes the collapse of the leaflets to form a tent(Goodwin 1979, Kunz 1982)...Among the new world pteropodid bats the genus Cynopterus is onlyknown to make tents for roosting (Kunz 1982).
column34: Bhat, H. R. 1994. Observations of the food and feeding behavior of Cynopterus sphinx Vahl (Chiroptera, Pteropodidae) at Pune, India. Mammalia, 58: 363-370.

column23: A related species C. brachyotis was also reported toroost in the similar self-fabricated bell shaped cavity of fruit bunch of Fish-tail palm(Phillips 1924).
column34: Bhat, H. R. 1994. Observations of the food and feeding behavior of Cynopterus sphinx Vahl (Chiroptera, Pteropodidae) at Pune, India. Mammalia, 58: 363-370.

column23: If the fruit is too large to transport (eg. mango), it is eaten in situ on the fruitingtree ; also, smaller soft fruits and flower parts and pollen are generally eaten at source.

column23: Phillips (1924) reported that Cynopterus brachyotis ceylonensis (referred to as C. sphinx ceylonensis by Phillips, 1980), altered large hanging ‘seed clusters’ of the kitul palm (Caryota urens) by biting off the central strings, and thereby creating cavities in which bats could roost.
column34: Bhat, H. R., and. H. Kunz. 1995. Altered flower /fruit clustersof the kitul palm used as roosts by the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Journal of Zoology (London), 235: 597- 604.

column23: Lekagul & McNeely (1977) reported that C. brachyotis altered palm leaves in Thailand, but gave no details of either the tents or thebehaviour of this bat.
column34: Bhat, H. R., and. H. Kunz. 1995. Altered flower /fruit clustersof the kitul palm used as roosts by the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Journal of Zoology (London), 235: 597- 604.

column23: The strongest evidence for tent construction in the Megachiroptera is basedon observations in Timor by Goodwin (1979), who noted that C. sphinx roosts in modified leaves of the palmate palm Corypha sp., and those of Balasingh, Isaac & Subbaraj (1993) and of Bhat (1994), in India, who reported that this bat roosts among altered stems of Vernonia scandens and Polyalthia longifolia, and in leaf tents of at least two species of palms (Borassusflabellifer and Areca catechu).
column34: Bhat, H. R., and. H. Kunz. 1995. Altered flower /fruit clustersof the kitul palm used as roosts by the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Journal of Zoology (London), 235: 597- 604.

column23: When C. sphinx constructs tents in palm trees, it usually does so by chewing the veins and plications, creating a characteristic ‘flask’ or ‘funnel-shaped’ pattern in the leaf (Goodwin, 1979).
column34: Bhat, H. R., and. H. Kunz. 1995. Altered flower /fruit clustersof the kitul palm used as roosts by the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Journal of Zoology (London), 235: 597- 604.

column23: This, and similar types of leaf tents attributed to Cynopterus, have beenobserved in Java and North Sulawesi, Indonesia (Kunz et al., 1994).

column23: In his review of roosting ecology of bats, Kunz (1982) considered the type of shelterconstructed by Cynopterus brachyotis (= sphinx) from Sri Lanka as being similar in concept toleaf tents, and has referred to this type of shelter as a ‘stem tent’ (Kunz et al., 1994).
column34: Bhat, H. R., and. H. Kunz. 1995. Altered flower /fruit clustersof the kitul palm used as roosts by the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Journal of Zoology (London), 235: 597- 604.

column23: Reports of such shelters formed in Polyalthia longifolia in western India (Bhat, 1994), and in Vernonia scandens and P. longifaliu in southern India (Balasingh et al., 1993) suggest that the construction of stem tents may be rather common.

column23: The construction of stem tents differs in one important wayfrom leaf tents. Instead of being formed by the alteration of living leaves (reviewed in Kunz, 1982;Timm, 1987; Kunz et al., 1994), they are made when bats sever stems of vines, tree branches, orpalm flower/fruit strings. Although both singles and small groups of C. sphinx have beenobserved in roost situations (Goodwin, 1979; Sandhu, 1984; Balasingh et al., 1993; Bhat, 1994), itremains to be determined whether tent construction by this species is an exclusive malebehaviour, as has been postulated for some of the tent-making members of New WorldPhyllostomidae (Kunz & McCracken, 1995).
column34: Bhat, H. R., and. H. Kunz. 1995. Altered flower /fruit clustersof the kitul palm used as roosts by the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Journal of Zoology (London), 235: 597- 604.

column23: In the present study, we report on tent-roosting and tent-making behaviour by C. sphinx fromwestern India, in which stem tents are formed when one or more bats sever the central flower/fruitstrings from immature flower/fruit clusters of the kitul palm (Caryota urens)...In January 1993, while conducting studies on the roosting and feeding ecology of Cvnopterus sphinx oneof us (HRB) observed a small group of about 10 individuals roosting in a cylindrical cavity that was formedin the middle of a compact fruit cluster of the kitul palm, Curyotu wens (Plate Ia and b).
column34: Bhat, H. R., and. H. Kunz. 1995. Altered flower /fruit clustersof the kitul palm used as roosts by the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Journal of Zoology (London), 235: 597- 604.

column23: On 20 February 1993, another group of 14 C. .sphinx was discovered about 5 km from group A, roosting ina similar cavity inside the flower cluster of a kitul palm. This tree was one in a row of 5 kitul palms, and thebats roosting in this cluster were designated as ‘group B’. This tent, located about 8 m above the ground, wasobserved periodically until mid-June 1993.
column34: Bhat, H. R., and. H. Kunz. 1995. Altered flower /fruit clustersof the kitul palm used as roosts by the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Journal of Zoology (London), 235: 597- 604.

column23: Two small groups of Rhynchonycteris were reported to me as roosting on the lock gates at Pedro Miguel and on a tree trunk near Juan Mina, each group arranged in the characteristic pattern for the species-clinging head down in a line on a vertical surface.
column34: Bloedel, P. 1955. Observations on life histories of Panama bats. Journal of Mammalogy, 36: 232-235.

column23: Two small groups of Rhynchonycteris were reported to me as roosting on the lock gates at Pedro Miguel and on a tree trunk near Juan Mina, each group arranged in the characteristic pattern for the species-clinging head down in a line on a vertical surface.
column34: Bloedel, P. 1955. Observations on life histories of Panama bats. Journal of Mammalogy, 36: 232-235.

column23: While this pattern is found exclusively in it, Rhynchonycteris shares with the following two characteristic roosting habits: (1) individuals always hang against a vertical held well out from that surface with the long forearms extending straight the level of the head; (2) all three species tend to choose open places as Rhynchonycteris and Saccopteryx in trees, sometimes in open rock recesses Peropteryx in open caves or clefts with more than one entrance.
column34: Bloedel, P. 1955. Observations on life histories of Panama bats. Journal of Mammalogy, 36: 232-235.

column23: On Barro Colorado Island they roosted on the sides of buildings, at Borinquen Dam in a shaft in the concrete of the dam, on Taboga Island in munitions shed and under a rock overhang, in a cleft in a rock bluff near the Pacific entrance to the canal, and at Santa Rosa, Panama, in a cave described below under They were always alert and difficult to approach.

column14: across the Chagres from Santa Rosa
column23: On May 27, I found a population of about 20 in the more open parts of a cavelike series of limestone fissures across the Chagres from Santa Rosa, Panama. Whether or not they were roosting I could not ascertain, but four were captured, and all these proved to be females young. A few Saccopteryx bilineata were found in the same general part the darker part there was a large cluster of Carrollia perspicillata.
column34: Bloedel, P. 1955. Observations on life histories of Panama bats. Journal of Mammalogy, 36: 232-235.

column14: Sardanillo Mine, two miles north of Summit
column23: About 25-50 of this species were found at Sardanillo Mine, two miles north of Summit, C.Z., ecologically related to over 1000 Carrollia perspicillata and Lonchorhina aurita. While these two species hung from the roof in single- layered clusters, each Chilonycteris was found separately from others of its kind, usually in the densest part of one of these clusters. Some specimens examined externally on Febru- ary 24 were apparently in late pregnancy, while one of two females taken March 24 was at this stage, and another was not. Males were also present in the mine.
column34: Bloedel, P. 1955. Observations on life histories of Panama bats. Journal of Mammalogy, 36: 232-235.

column23: This species I found either solitary or in small clusters in culverts under roads through forested areas, in the dark underground chambers of the ruins of Fort San Lorenzo, C. Z., and in sheds and houses in El Valle de Anton, Panama, never more than about 20 in one place. These bats always hung from the roof of whatever structure they used as a roost, in loosely aggregated clusters.
column34: Bloedel, P. 1955. Observations on life histories of Panama bats. Journal of Mammalogy, 36: 232-235.

column23: Phyllostomus was found night-roosting under bridges and in a shed on Borinquen Dam; in the daytime I found one in the Pacorachurch, and about 20 in a monument tower on the highway from Panama City to Tocumen Airport. In all these places the bats hung from the highest place available, while other species occupied lower roosting. sites. These other smaller species showed no apparent fearor caution in the presence of Phyllostomus, either in the wild orin captivity; their equanimityis surprising in view of the known predatory habits of Phyllostomus. When such speciesas Carrollia perspicillata or Glossophaga soricina were placed in a cage with one of these largebats, the former were apparently completely unconcerned; the Phyllostomus killed themsimply by sidling up and biting them in the
column34: Bloedel, P. 1955. Observations on life histories of Panama bats. Journal of Mammalogy, 36: 232-235.

When such speciesas Carrollia perspicillata or Glossophaga soricina were placed in a cage with one of these largebats, the former were apparently completely unconcerned; the Phyllostomus killed themsimply by sidling up and biting them in the

column23: I observed these bats only in their palm-leaf tents atSummit Experimental Gardens, and can only confirm their already known habits. (Allen,op. cit.). In the latter part of March most females have nursing young, and are roosting inclusters of 20 to 40, while the males are separated from them, usually solitary or in smallgroups of from 2-5. The females are active throughout the first half of the night at least,returning during this time occasionally to the young, which are left hanging in the palmleafshelters.
column34: Bloedel, P. 1955. Observations on life histories of Panama bats. Journal of Mammalogy, 36: 232-235.

column23: About 1000 comprised most of the bat Pacora church attic, a hot, dry, almost completely dark space. The Tadarida hung from the  sides of the floor joists and often were piled up on the floor between the joists. None hung from the roof, as did the small cluster of Myotis listed above. Dry dung inches thick in places where the bats were most concentrated. There were no young bats or pregnant females among the specimens examined, all taken during March.
column34: Bloedel, P. 1955. Observations on life histories of Panama bats. Journal of Mammalogy, 36: 232-235.

column14: across the Chagres from Santa Rosa
column23: On May 27, I found a population of about 20 in the more open parts of a cavelike series of limestone fissures across the Chagres from Santa Rosa, Panama. Whether or not they were roosting I could not ascertain, but four were captured, and all these proved to be females young. A few Saccopteryx bilineata were found in the same general part the darker part there was a large cluster of Carrollia perspicillata.
column34: Bloedel, P. 1955. Observations on life histories of Panama bats. Journal of Mammalogy, 36: 232-235.

column14: Sardanillo Mine, two miles north of Summit
column23: About 25-50 of this species were found at Sardanillo Mine, two miles north of Summit, C.Z., ecologically related to over 1000 Carrollia perspicillata and Lonchorhina aurita. While these two species hung from the roof in single- layered clusters, each Chilonycteris was found separately from others of its kind, usually in the densest part of one of these clusters. Some specimens examined externally on Febru- ary 24 were apparently in late pregnancy, while one of two females taken March 24 was at this stage, and another was not. Males were also present in the mine.
column34: Bloedel, P. 1955. Observations on life histories of Panama bats. Journal of Mammalogy, 36: 232-235.
