column23: An exception to this is formed by M. myotis at Brno, which found a convenient place for hibernation in the galleries on the outskirts of this town (Gaisler, 1979)
column34: Bogdanowicz W. Community structure and interspecific interactions in bats hibernating in Poznań. Acta theriologica. 1983;28(23):357-70.

column23: A situation similar to this was observed in these towns in summer, when P. pipistrellus occurred in such large numbers, and simultaneously in such varied sheltering places, that the situation took on the character of an "invasion" (Palaśthy& Gaisler, 1965; Grummt & Haensel, 1965; Hurka, 1966). This phenomenon was not observed in either West Berlin or in Poznań. In both these cities, as was the case at Modlin and MFR, the structure of the community and the large numbers of hibernating bats were to a great extent determined by the presence of numerous and relatively extensive fortifications. At Puławy the artificial cave played a similar role.
column34: Bogdanowicz W. Community structure and interspecific interactions in bats hibernating in Poznań. Acta theriologica. 1983;28(23):357-70.

column23: Figure 2....Data on the "urban" chiropterofauna of these centres were compared with observations carried out in the external ring of fortifica-tions at Modlin (52°27'N, 20°43'E) (Lesiński, 1982, in litt., 1983) and in the fortifications of'the Międzyrzecki Fortified Region (MFR) (52°23'N, 15°28'E) (Bagrowska-Urbańczyk & Urbańczyk, 1983) (Fig. 2). For purposes of comparison use was also made of the results of studies in an artifical cave at Puławy [11,700 inhabitants (1956) (Krzanowski, 1959)]

column23: It was found that two pairs of species have a statistically significant tendency to co-occurrence in clusters: 1) B. barbastellus and P. auritus, 2)M. nattereri and M. daubentoni. In the first case this is due to the greater tendency to clustering of B. barbastellus, which forms the clusters with P. auritus, and in the second case with the greater tendency to clustering of M. nattereri than of M. daubentoni.
column34: Bogdanowicz W. Community structure and interspecific interactions in bats hibernating in Poznań. Acta theriologica. 1983;28(23):357-70.

column23: It was found that two pairs of species have a statistically significant tendency to co-occurrence in clusters: 1) B. barbastellus and P. auritus, 2)M. nattereri and M. daubentoni. In the first case this is due to the greater tendency to clustering of B. barbastellus, which forms the clusters with P. auritus, and in the second case with the greater tendency to clustering of M. nattereri than of M. daubentoni.
column34: Bogdanowicz W. Community structure and interspecific interactions in bats hibernating in Poznań. Acta theriologica. 1983;28(23):357-70.

column23: Tatarinov (1956) draws attention to competition inwinter hiding places such as exists between B. barbastellus and P. auritus in respect of numbers.
column34: Bogdanowicz W. Community structure and interspecific interactions in bats hibernating in Poznań. Acta theriologica. 1983;28(23):357-70.

column23: Brosset & Caubère (1959) consider that relationsbetween some species, and particularly between M. emarginatus andRhinolophidae, M. schreibersi and M. myotis, and R. euryale andR. jerrumequinum, are conditioned by interspecific social ties ("lienssociaux interspécifiques"), the so-called "facteur psychologique" determiningthis in R. euryale.
column34: Bogdanowicz W. Community structure and interspecific interactions in bats hibernating in Poznań. Acta theriologica. 1983;28(23):357-70.

column34: Bogdanowicz W. Community structure and interspecific interactions in bats hibernating in Poznań. Acta theriologica. 1983;28(23):357-70.

column23: Brosset & Caubère (1959) consider that relationsbetween some species, and particularly between M. emarginatus andRhinolophidae, M. schreibersi and M. myotis, and R. euryale andR. jerrumequinum, are conditioned by interspecific social ties ("lienssociaux interspécifiques"), the so-called "facteur psychologique" determiningthis in R. euryale.

column23: Relations between M. emarginatus and Rhinolophidae(particularly R. jerrumequinum) are defined by Brosset (1974a)by the term "parasitisme écologique". Fairon et al. (1982) have alsodrawn attention to the strong character of the relations betweenM. emarginatus and R. jerrumequinum.
column34: Bogdanowicz W. Community structure and interspecific interactions in bats hibernating in Poznań. Acta theriologica. 1983;28(23):357-70.

column14: West Berlin, Modlin (52°27'N, 20°43'E), Międzyrzecki Fortified Region (MFR) (52°23'N, 15°28'E)
column23: In short the proportion in the community of thermophilous species (chiefly M. myotis, fewer M. nattereri), in West Berlin and Poznań is greater than in areas outside towns (Modlin together with the MFR), and there is at least a similar proportion of species preferring lower temperatures (B. barbastellus, P. auritus and M. daubentoni) (Fig. 2)...On the other hand, however, it is known that atmospheric temperature in a town is higher than outside it (Schmuck, 1969) and bats' hibernation period lasts ashorter time there than in regions devoid of urban buildings (author's unpublished data).
column34: Bogdanowicz W. Community structure and interspecific interactions in bats hibernating in Poznań. Acta theriologica. 1983;28(23):357-70.

column23: The place of M. dasycneme in the bat communities examined isexceptional. In Central Europe this is one of the rarer species of bats,which usually everywhere occurs in very small numbers (cf. Hanâk &Gaisler, 1965). Certain general regularities can, however, be observedin the choice made by M. dasycneme of winter quarters — this speciesclearly avoids greatly urbanized areas (Fig. 2) (cf. also Hanâk & Gaisler,1965; Sluiter et al, 1971). It occurs at Modlin, MFR and at Puławy,and at one time it was recorded from Poznań (Schulz, 1911). ;In thisconnection the hypothesis may be put forward that within the limitsof its range M. dasycneme is a bioindicator of the changes taking placeover a period of years in a habitat subjected to urbanization pressure.
column34: Bogdanowicz W. Community structure and interspecific interactions in bats hibernating in Poznań. Acta theriologica. 1983;28(23):357-70.

column23: Summer shelters are usually found in hollow trees (Limpens et al., 1991), sometimes in buildings (Nyholm, 1965; Tiunov, 1989a), under bridges (Ryberg, 1947), in bird (Baumler, 1990) and bat boxes (Gerell, 1985), and in rock crevices and nests of sand martins (Kowalski and Ruprecht, 1981).

column23: Both scat and stomach analyses indicate that M. daubentonii consumes a diversity of Diptera, Trichoptera, Ephemeroptera, Lepidoptera, and Coleoptera in western Belarus (Kurskov, 1981) and Scotland (Swift and Racey, 1983).

column23: The diet of M. daubentonii in Switzerland consisted mainly of Diptera (Chironomidae) and Hemiptera (Aphididea-Beck, 1987), whereas in Finland Lepidoptera and Diptera were predominate (Nyholm, 1965).
column34: Bogdanowicz, W. 1994. Myotis daubentonii. Mammalian Species, 475: 1-9.

column23: In western France, predominant items in the diet of M. daubentonii were insects belonging to Tabanidae, crustaceans from Ostracoda and Cladocera, and par- ticles of fresh-water fish (Brosset and Deboutteville, 1966; see Mayle, 1990).
column34: Bogdanowicz, W. 1994. Myotis daubentonii. Mammalian Species, 475: 1-9.

column23: The mammals most usually recorded catching Daubenton's are domestic cats Felis catus (Abelencev et al., 1956; Bekker and Mostert, 1991; Richardson, 1985).

column23: Over 70 bats were killed within a few weeks by a cat sitting on a tree branch over a canal (Stebbings, 1988).

column23: A beech marten, Martes foina, preyed on Daubenton's bats hibernating in subterranean marl pits in the Netherlands (Bekker, 1988).
column34: Bogdanowicz, W. 1994. Myotis daubentonii. Mammalian Species, 475: 1-9.

column23: Myotis daubentonii is also occasionally eaten by rodents, such as Apodemus sylvaticus (Bekker and Mostert, 1991), and Gliridae (Rolandez and Pont, 1986), and by shrews, such as Sorex araneus (Iljin, 1989).
column34: Bogdanowicz, W. 1994. Myotis daubentonii. Mammalian Species, 475: 1-9.

column34: Bogdanowicz, W. 1994. Myotis daubentonii. Mammalian Species, 475: 1-9.

column23: The most common avian predators of M. daubentonii are a few species of owls, mainly barn (Tyto alba), tawny (Strix aluco), and long-eared (Asio otus) owls (e.g., Bekker and Mostert, 1991; Ruprecht, 1979, 1990).
column34: Bogdanowicz, W. 1994. Myotis daubentonii. Mammalian Species, 475: 1-9.

column23: The most common arthropod parasites collected from M. dau- bentonii are bat flies. In Poland, the Czech Republic, and Slovakia, 81-90% of the bats were infected with wingless, blood-sucking Nycteribia kolenatii, with an average of 3.9-4.7 flies per bat (Hurka, 1964; Nowosad, 1987).
column34: Bogdanowicz, W. 1994. Myotis daubentonii. Mammalian Species, 475: 1-9.

column23: A variety of mites, ticks, and chiggers parasitize M. daubentonii. These include Spinturnix daubentoni, S. andegavinus, Macronyssus ellipticus, M. crosbyi, Nycteridocoptes poppei, and Argas vespertilionis (e.g., Estrada-Pefia et al., 1989; Haitlinger, 1979; Medvedev et al., 1991).

column34: Bogdanowicz, W. 1994. Myotis daubentonii. Mammalian Species, 475: 1-9.

column23: Fleas are frequently recorded but are as host-specific; the most common are Ischnopsyllus simplex (Hurka, 1989; Skuratowicz, 1988), and in the Far East Myodopsylla trisellis (Medvedev et al., 1991).
column34: Bogdanowicz, W. 1994. Myotis daubentonii. Mammalian Species, 475: 1-9.

column23: Among 108 Daubenton's bats examined in Britain, 27 contained the malaria parasite Polychromophilus murinus, and 57 intraerythrocytic bacterium Grahamella sp. (Gardner et al., 1987). These hematozoa, however, are not considered harmful.

column23: Piroplasm, Babesia vesperuginis, was found in the blood of two M. daubentonii in the Netherlands (Goedbloed et al., 1964).

column23: Babesia-infected have significantly lowered blood hemoglobin, raised white blood counts, and enlarged spleens compared with uninfected bats (Gardner and Molyneux, 1987).

column23: Bacteria, Leptospira spp., were found in daubentonii in Denmark (Constantine, 1970).

column23: In the Netherlands, Daubenton's bats seem to closely follow linear landscape elements on their flight paths and hesitate to cross open spaces. They also avoid light while hunting (Limpens and Kapteyn, 1991).

column14: Estacion Sirena, Parque Nacional Corcovado, between 8"27' N and 8'39' N, and 83"25' W and 83"45' W
column23: Squirrel monkeys were observed flushing bats on numerous occasions; in twoinstances an attending kite captured and consumed one of the bats. On the firstoccasion, a subadult squirrel monkey unsuccessfully stalked four or five roosting Artibeus watsoni on Carludovica palmata by slowly climbing the frond’s petiole. Anattending double-toothed kite swooped in as soon as the bats flushed and capturedone in flight. It then landed on a nearby branch and ate the bat.
column34: Boinski, S., and R. M. Timm. 1985. Predation by squirrel monkeys and double-toothed kites on tent-making bats. American Journal of Primatology, 9: 121- 127.

column14: Estacion Sirena, Parque Nacional Corcovado, between 8"27' N and 8'39' N, and 83"25' W and 83"45' W
column23: On the second occasion, squirrel monkeys flushed two A. watsoni from a tent in Heliconia. Adouble-toothed kite caught one bat in flight at roughly 4 m from the ground andglided to the ground with the bat in its talons. The kite readjusted its grip on thebat, flew to a branch, and ate. Bats are only susceptible to kite predation whendisturbed from their roosts by foraging monkeys.
column34: Boinski, S., and R. M. Timm. 1985. Predation by squirrel monkeys and double-toothed kites on tent-making bats. American Journal of Primatology, 9: 121- 127.

column14: Estacion Sirena, Parque Nacional Corcovado, between 8"27' N and 8'39' N, and 83"25' W and 83"45' W
column23: Squirrel monkeys were observed on 24 separate occasions leaping on bat tentsand in five additional instances stalking the tent’s occupants. In both types ofapproach, the initial response of a squirrel monkey on identifying a tent was toapproach closely from the side or below and to visually inspect it. A leap at the battent flushed the bats immediately. Only once was a squirrel monkey clearly seen tocapture a juvenile bat (Artibeus watsoni) that had been knocked to the ground. Aftercapture, the 4-year-old male monkey delivered seven sharp bites to the head. He then climbed to a 2-m-high branch (most likely to avoid three curious juveniles) and proceeded to consume the entire bat in 1 minute 40 seconds.
column34: Boinski, S., and R. M. Timm. 1985. Predation by squirrel monkeys and double-toothed kites on tent-making bats. American Journal of Primatology, 9: 121- 127.

column23: C. brachyotis is a medium-sized bat (mean 37 .3 gms, n = 10, in Singapore) which typically roosts in small groups in trees, particularly under the fronds of palms.
column34: Boon, P. P, and R.. Corlett. 1989. Seed dispersal by the lesser short-nosed fruit bat (Cynopterus brachyotis, Pteropodidae, Megachiroptera). Malayan Nature Journal, 42: 251- 256.

column14: National University of Singapore, Singapore Botanic Gardens
column23: Almost any tree with horizontal branches more than 3 m above the ground might be used as a feeding roost but the preferred roosts, where available, were palm trees with fan-shaped leaves
column34: Boon, P. P, and R.. Corlett. 1989. Seed dispersal by the lesser short-nosed fruit bat (Cynopterus brachyotis, Pteropodidae, Megachiroptera). Malayan Nature Journal, 42: 251- 256.

column23: These were often used also as daytime roosts. The most favoured species in the Botanic Gardens was Corypha utan, which sometimes supported colonies of 100 or more bats. The bats construct 'tents' by chewing through the veins, causing the collapseof the distal area of the leaf, as described for Cynopterus sphinx in Timor(Goodwin, 1979).

column34: Boon, P. P, and R.. Corlett. 1989. Seed dispersal by the lesser short-nosed fruit bat (Cynopterus brachyotis, Pteropodidae, Megachiroptera). Malayan Nature Journal, 42: 251- 256.

column23: At least 6 species of Ficus were eaten but most could not be identified withcertainty from the fragmentary remains. Surprisingly, the fruit remnantsunder feeding roosts often included partly-eaten, seedless 'gall figs' of thedioecious F. fi'stulosa (sometimes with fig wasps still emerging) andoccasionally other species.
column34: Boon, P. P, and R.. Corlett. 1989. Seed dispersal by the lesser short-nosed fruit bat (Cynopterus brachyotis, Pteropodidae, Megachiroptera). Malayan Nature Journal, 42: 251- 256.

column23: Faecal samples were obtained from 40 bats netted in the University. Ofthese, 39 contained only seeds of Adinandra dumosa - the dominant speciesin the adjoining secondary forest - and the other only seeds of Muntingiacalabura. A total of 389 seeds were collected from plastic sheeting underbat flight paths: 92.8 percent A. dumosa and the rest Fagraea fragrans...Adinandra dumosa was by far the most important species in the diet atthe University, on the evidence of night observations, faecal samples anddiscarded fruit remnants under temporary feeding roosts.
column34: Boon, P. P, and R.. Corlett. 1989. Seed dispersal by the lesser short-nosed fruit bat (Cynopterus brachyotis, Pteropodidae, Megachiroptera). Malayan Nature Journal, 42: 251- 256.

column23: One surprising item in the diet of the Botanic Garden bats was the 'fruit'of the conifer Podocarpus rumphii: The fleshy red receptacle with attachedseed was carried off to a feeding roost, where the receptacle was eaten andthe seed dropped. The colour and position (buried among the foliage) of thefruit suggest that P. rumphii is usually bird-dispersed, but it formed a majorpart of the diet of nearby colonies while it was available.
column34: Boon, P. P, and R.. Corlett. 1989. Seed dispersal by the lesser short-nosed fruit bat (Cynopterus brachyotis, Pteropodidae, Megachiroptera). Malayan Nature Journal, 42: 251- 256.

column14: National University of Singapore, Singapore BotanicGardens
column23: Adinandra dumosa is the dominant pioneer on abandoned, degradedagricultural land in Singapore and the southernmost part of the MalayPeninsula. Its green fruits, displayed clear of the foliage, are producedcontinuously throughout the year and are apparently never taken by birds,and rarely by other mammals. This phenology ensures regular visits by C.brachyotis and, at least since human disturbance greatly increased itsabundance, A. dumosa must be a major factor in maintaining high densitybat populations. It would seem likely that the tree architecture, fruitmorphology and reproductive phenology of Adznandra have evo!ved inresponse to selection for dispersal by Cynopterus and similar medium-sizedfruit bats. Janzen (1983) suggests that the major stumbling block to tightplant-disperser coevolution is that few plants maintain a year-round crop offruits of sufficient quantity and quality to sustain a vertebrate population.Adinandra may be an exception.
column34: Boon, P. P, and R.. Corlett. 1989. Seed dispersal by the lesser short-nosed fruit bat (Cynopterus brachyotis, Pteropodidae, Megachiroptera). Malayan Nature Journal, 42: 251- 256.

column14: Laboratoire de Pritnatologie et d’Ecologie Equatoriale,Makokou, Gaboon (latitude 0.4° N, longitude 13° E) and North/South along the Ivindo River
column23: In some cases, it was possible to follow individual animalsthrough a succession of day roosts over periods of several months. Between 1970 and 1974, 35 different day roost locations were mapped and 24 of these were actually visited and monitored for extended periods. In 1974, the nearest neighbor distances between known roosts of Hypsignathus ranged between 0.4 and 6 km. As will be shown below, the cryptic nature of the day roosts and their sparse distribution over kilometers of uniform habitat make it virtually impossible to locate them by any means other than radio-tracking. All day roosts show a similar configuration. The bats typically roost high in the forest canopy at heights of from 20 to 30 m. Roosts are always exposed branches beneath a dense umbrella of vegetation. Usually access to the roosting branch is guaranteed by apparent selection for sites with few nearby lianas and epiphytes and several m gap between roost and understory.No preference for particular species of roost trees was noted.
column34: Bradbury, J. W. 1977 a. Lek mating behavior in the hammer-headed bat. Zeitschrift für Tierpsychologie, 45: 225- 255.

column14: Laboratoire de Pritnatologie et d’Ecologie Equatoriale,Makokou, Gaboon (latitude 0.4° N, longitude 13° E) and North/South along the Ivindo River
column23: A total of 133 oral swab and feces samples was taken from animalsnetted at the C.N.R.S. site between 1970 and 1974. All samples were takenin May to October; thus statements as to dietary preferences apply only tothis period. Of the 133 samples, 88 % contained seeds of only two generaof plants: Ficus and Anthocleista. The remaining 12 % of the samples containedseeds of Musanga cecropioides and Solanum spp., both of which arecommon in secondary growth areas and in old plantations.
column34: Bradbury, J. W. 1977 a. Lek mating behavior in the hammer-headed bat. Zeitschrift für Tierpsychologie, 45: 225- 255.

column23: At night, while adults are feeding, young are never left behind onthe roost tree. One lucky observation suggests that females carry non-volant youngto other trees and leave them hidden while foraging. A female from the Restanharem in Bush Bush flew from the roost to another tree some 60 m distantand landed. She gently pushed the baby bat off her teat and it began togroom and stretch its wings. The female then left and began foraging nearby. Thebaby was still roosting quietly on the tree some 3 h later, but was back onthe roost with its mother the next morning. The P did not use the same treeon subsequent nights
column34: Bradbury, J. W., and L. H. Emmons. 1974. Social organization of some rinidad bats. I. Emballonuridae. Zeitschriftfür Tierpsychologie, 36: 137- 183.

column23: While the latter species seems to prefer the dark hollows of buttressed trees,S. leptura usually roosts at heights of 3-10 tn on the boles of trees. Oftensuch sites are partly protected by some niinor concavity in the bole (verycommon on trees of the species Eschweilera subglandulosa), or above the batsby limbs or warty outgrowths (as is commonly found with Sterculia carihuea)...S. leptura also seem to accept a wider variety of roost tree species than do S. bilineuta. On the 5 acre tip of Restan peninsula in Bush Bush Forest,an attempt was made to find and census regularly every roost of S. leptura. Ofall the trees within this area, only 28 were used as roosts. In order ofdecreasing frequency these were: Sterculia caribaea (1 1 trees), Eschweilera subglandulosa(6), Brosimum aubletii (2), Nectandra surinamensis (2), Pithecellobiumjupunba (I), Guarea glabra (I), Zanthoxylum trinitense ( l ) , Buchenaviacapitata (I), Ficus sp. ( I ) , Spondias monbin (I), and one unidentified rottenstump.
column34: Bradbury, J. W., and L. H. Emmons. 1974. Social organization of some rinidad bats. I. Emballonuridae. Zeitschriftfür Tierpsychologie, 36: 137- 183.

column23: The Guanapo population roosted in three groups, which as a rule, tendedto occupy approximately the same sites on the cliff. column23: Female California bats preferred to roostin specific species of trees. The preferredtree, ponderosa pine, is relatively rare inboth the West Arm Demonstration Forestand Pend d'Oreille Valley study areas (Vonhof,1995). Indeed, the bats appeared to selectpatches of large-diameter ponderosapine to roost in, based on the fact that noponderosa pines were found in other areasof the same stand and size of tree did notdiscriminate between roost trees and availabletrees in the immediate vicinity.

column23: Generalizing our results with those of other studies conducted in the coniferousforests of the Pacific Northwest (e.g., Betts,1996; Brigham, 1991; Campbell et aI.,1996; Vonhof, 1996; Vonhof and Barclay,1996) leads to the conclusion that retentionand recruitment of snags in managed forestsmay be crucial for conservation of bats.

column23: In a previous study at the La Selva Biological Station, Costa Rica, Timm & Mortimer (1 976)found that E. alba selected small size-class leaves of Heliconia spp. (Musaceae) but showed noapparent preference for a particular species since the occurrence of tents was proportional to the abundance of Heliconia in the forest. Timm & Mortimer’s observations of 14 roosting E. alba suggested that roosting bats use more than one tent.
column34: Brooke, A. P. 1987. Tent selection, roosting ecology and social organization of the tentmaking bat, Ectophylla alba, in Costa Rica. Journal of Zoology (London), 221: 11-19.

column23: This study was also conducted at the La Selva Biological Station. For detailed descriptions of La Selva seeHartshorn (1983) and Frankie, Baker & Opler (1 974). The study area encompassed 4 ha of approximately 25-year-old secondary forest. During May-July 1985 and January-May 1986, this area was searched daily forroosting bats and freshly cut tents...Ectophylla alba was observed roosting in 48 different tents.

column14: La Selva Biological Station, Heredia Province
column23: Group composition of bats within tents changed when young were born. Prior to parturition, tentsheld aggregations of males and females; immediately after parturition tents had either nursing females plus non-volant young and a single sexually active male (N = 4) or only males (N = 2).This apparent segregation into 'maternity' and 'bachelor' tents continued until young wereindependent.
column34: Brooke, A. P. 1987. Tent selection, roosting ecology and social organization of the tentmaking bat, Ectophylla alba, in Costa Rica. Journal of Zoology (London), 221: 11-19.

column23: Only after the hurricanes in 1990 and 1992were roosting sites found in agricultural forest (N= 4; Table 2). This forest type, found near villages,along the coast, and in valleys, is a mixture of nativetrees and cultivated plants that include coconuts(C. nucifera), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), bananas(Musa spp.), papaya (Carica papaya), andmango (Mangifera indica) (Cole et al. 1988).
column34: Brooke, A. P., C. Solek, and A. Tualaulelei. 2000. Roosting behavior of colonial and solitary flying foxes in American Samoa (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Biotropica, 32: 338-350.

column23: Historically, flying foxeshave been abundant on Pacific islands, but withinrecent years there have been dramatic populationdeclines in many island countries (Wiles et al.1989, Fujita & Tuttle 1991, Pierson & Rainey1992, Bowen-Jones et al. 1997). Rapidly expandinghuman populations, deforestation of largetracts of land, and replacement of traditional huntingmethods with shotguns have had drastic consequenceson bat populations. While the ecologicalimportance of pteropodid bats in maintaining nativeforests and agricultural crops is well recognized(Fujita & Tuttle 1991, Rainey et al. 1995, Banack1998), flying foxes are hunted legally in most Pacificisland countries and there are few areas wherebats or roosting sites are protected.
column27: (Wiles et al.1989, Fujita & Tuttle 1991, Pierson & Rainey1992, Bowen-Jones et al. 1997
column34: Brooke, A. P., C. Solek, and A. Tualaulelei. 2000. Roosting behavior of colonial and solitary flying foxes in American Samoa (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Biotropica, 32: 338-350.

column23: Historically, flying foxeshave been abundant on Pacific islands, but withinrecent years there have been dramatic populationdeclines in many island countries (Wiles et al.1989, Fujita & Tuttle 1991, Pierson & Rainey1992, Bowen-Jones et al. 1997). Rapidly expandinghuman populations, deforestation of largetracts of land, and replacement of traditional huntingmethods with shotguns have had drastic consequenceson bat populations. While the ecologicalimportance of pteropodid bats in maintaining nativeforests and agricultural crops is well recognized(Fujita & Tuttle 1991, Rainey et al. 1995, Banack1998), flying foxes are hunted legally in most Pacificisland countries and there are few areas wherebats or roosting sites are protected.

column23: Historically, flying foxeshave been abundant on Pacific islands, but withinrecent years there have been dramatic populationdeclines in many island countries (Wiles et al.1989, Fujita & Tuttle 1991, Pierson & Rainey1992, Bowen-Jones et al. 1997). Rapidly expandinghuman populations, deforestation of largetracts of land, and replacement of traditional huntingmethods with shotguns have had drastic consequenceson bat populations. While the ecologicalimportance of pteropodid bats in maintaining nativeforests and agricultural crops is well recognized(Fujita & Tuttle 1991, Rainey et al. 1995, Banack1998), flying foxes are hunted legally in most Pacificisland countries and there are few areas wherebats or roosting sites are protected.
column34: Brooke, A. P., C. Solek, and A. Tualaulelei. 2000. Roosting behavior of colonial and solitary flying foxes in American Samoa (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Biotropica, 32: 338-350.

column23: The abandonment of a large colony at Olavalu crater(Fig. 1, no. 37) in 1994 and its relocation to FagateleBay (Fig. 1, no. 1) may have resulted fromgunshots or firecrackers, which were heard regularlyat dusk as bats exited to forage (S. Saucerman, pers.comm.).

column23: The colony at Olomoana Mt. (Fig. 1, no.17) temporarily abandoned their roost after a roadwas constructed nearby, and an unknown numberof bats were shot illegally in 1994. The colony fragmentedinto smaller groups of 50 to 200 individualsthat moved frequently between temporaryroosts but was reestablished at a less accessible siteon Olomoana Mt. within two months.
column34: Brooke, A. P., C. Solek, and A. Tualaulelei. 2000. Roosting behavior of colonial and solitary flying foxes in American Samoa (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Biotropica, 32: 338-350.

column23: Unlike P. tonganus, roosting P. samoensis werenot frightened easily and did not fly quickly when approached by people. We routinely stood directlybeneath roosting bats that were indifferent to ourpresence...The bats were not affected by vehicles, periodicroadside clearing by the village, or foot trafficpassing ca 6-15 m below where they hanged fromslender branches. Because I? samoensis rarely tookflight when disturbed, the bats roosting in the figwere easily overlooked and few people were awareof the roost.
column34: Brooke, A. P., C. Solek, and A. Tualaulelei. 2000. Roosting behavior of colonial and solitary flying foxes in American Samoa (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Biotropica, 32: 338-350.

column23: We encountered several confounding factorswhen trying to compare study valleys. Although theforest in the Malaeimi valley was third in numberof fruit-producing canopy trees (40.5%), it had thesmallest number of roosting sites (N = 2; Table 4).We heard gunshots on several occasions and spokewith a family living in the valley who said that theyroutinely shot bats. The constant hunting pressurein this area was likely the cause of the low numberof roosting sites
column34: Brooke, A. P., C. Solek, and A. Tualaulelei. 2000. Roosting behavior of colonial and solitary flying foxes in American Samoa (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae). Biotropica, 32: 338-350.

column23: Human disturbance at roosting sites appears tobe a strong influence in the selection of roosts forP. tonganus. The obvious and noisy colonies rely onisolated locations, the protection of cliffs above theocean and the steep hillsides of inland forest, todiscourage people from approaching roosting sites.

column23: Pteropus samoensis was hunted regularlyin the Malaeimi valley and some hunting stilloccurs within the National Park (on the roadthrough Amalau valley and on the Park‘s boundaryalong the Alava Mt. The newNational Park of American Samoa, established in1988, relies on community support to enforce itsno-hunting regulation, but this is a novel conceptnot yet accepted by everyone.

column23: Constantine says that in Georgia they live in apricot trees in summer, but take refuge in the fall among the evergreen orange trees. He notices that these Chiroptera look for trees growing on dark, non-reflective soil, and that they generally choose exposure to the west. The author thinks that this orientation allows the animal to receive the rays of the setting sun, at the time when it is activates its metabolism, before going on a hunt [142, 145].
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: From the cellar to the attic, the houses occupied by man are also occupied bybats. The exterior walls serve as a point of attachment for twoTaphozous. In America, anotherEmballonuride, Saccopteryx bilineata, is observed in an identical situation.

column23: The great European Horseshoe Bat, with its ecological associate Myotis emarginatus,also successively uses the different floors of the old castlesto the best of its metabolic comfort. Beaucournu gives an example with thecolony that he studied in the castle of the due de Nantes, and I made observationsvery similar in the castle colony of Glenay (Deux-Sevres).When Rhinolophs and Vespertilions arrive in April, they are localized in thecold cellars, where they hibernate during the day. Then when the femalesbecome pregnant, they reach the upper floor of the castle which benefitsof greater heat. This is where the birth takes place in June.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: Arboreal Chiroptera that live in foliage usually presenta mottled coat (fig. 13). Some species are even adorned withbrilliant colors. It is difficult to always attribute a survival value to thesecryptic stains. Nevertheless, the very generalization of the phenomenon leavesthink that it is not the product of chance. Lasiurus, some Taphozous, Rhynchiscus have a dorsal coatchina of white, red and gray, which mimics bark and epiphytes onwhich they rely on. White facial markings, spots or lines, constantin arboreal Phyllostomatides and many small Pteropides,effectively conceal them in foliage riddled with spots of light oilthey take shelter. The wings are brightly colored lemon yellow or orange, inCasinycteris, Lavia jrons and Kerivoula picta. They have a reticule designin sharp contrasts, in certain Glauconycteris. It is the forearms that areparticularly spotted in Nyctimenes and certain Lasiurus. All these species roost in the open air, hanging from the branches and exposed to the sight ofdiurnal predators.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

It is difficult to always attribute a survival value to thesecryptic stains. Nevertheless, the very generalization of the phenomenon leavesthink that it is not the product of chance. Lasiurus, some Taphozous, Rhynchiscus have a dorsal coatchina of white, red and gray, which mimics bark and epiphytes onwhich they rely on. White facial markings, spots or lines, constantin arboreal Phyllostomatides and many small Pteropides,effectively conceal them in foliage riddled with spots of light oilthey take shelter. The wings are brightly colored lemon yellow or orange, inCasinycteris, Lavia jrons and Kerivoula picta. They have a reticule designin sharp contrasts, in certain Glauconycteris. It is the forearms that areparticularly spotted in Nyctimenes and certain Lasiurus. All these species roost in the open air, hanging from the branches and exposed to the sight ofdiurnal predators.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: In India I saw Rhinolophus lepidusfly on the spot from twig to twig. The visit of a single large bushy treecan hold this Chiroptera for about an hour. column23: The migrations of Tadarida brasiliensis are proven both by observationdirect population movements and by resuming on the spotwintering of ringed individuals in summer colonies. column23: In June-September 1963 and January-April 1964, in Belinga, Gabon, I captured56 Hipposideros caffer, hunting around mercury lamps used bythe entomologists of Professor Grasse's mission. All these Chiropterawithout exception were adult males, in the red phase. These individuals, ringsand released, noticed each other regularly hunting in the same place at nightfollowing. The area studied was well operated by an individualized group ofmales of the same age. However, these Chiroptera belonged to the neighboring colony,counting about 500,000 male and female subjects, mixed in the samecave.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: Sudden rises of water in underground cavities drown entire colonies. The work of the quarrymen, the explorations of speleologists, a disinfectionundergrounds to cultivate mushrooms, not to mention evil and human stupidity, can cause losses in populations troglophiles [686].
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: It seems that the Tropical Horseshoes presentrhythms of activity interspersed with winter phases, triggered bypurely internal stimulation. column23: Genus Uroderma Peters. A Peters bilobatum species from Costa Rica inPeru and south of Brazil.BIOLOGY [80, 112, 178, 271]: Common species, with arboreal ecology.Uroderma usually cluster in small swarms under the leavesbanana trees, or under the palm leaves that they shear in such a waythat the drooping part forms a shelter for them. The diet is frugivorous.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: Genus Uroderma Peters. column23: Genre Vampyrops Peters incl. Vampyrodes Thomas, Vampyressa Thomas,Vampyriscus Thomas. About twenty species from Mexico to Paraguay.BIOLOGY [178, 271, 490]: poorly understood. V. lineatus (Geoffroy), helleri Peters,Major G. M. Allen.This group appears to be arboreal: individuals have been noted in the palm trees,under the hanging leaves of the bushes, in tree holes. The system of governmentwould be frugivorous.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: Genus Chiroderma Peters. Six species from tropical America.BIOLOGY [178, 271]: little known. C. villosum Peters, C. trinitatum Goodwin.Day roost is probably in the foliage, although Chirodermatrinitatum was found in a well-lit cavity. The diet is frugivorous,and reproduction is continuous in females of Chiroderma villosum atMexico.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: Genus Artibeus Leach (incl. Enchisthenes Andersen). About fifteenforms from Mexico to Paraguay. The systematics of Artibeus does not appearclear at the specific level.BIOLOGY [25, 104, 112, 178, 237, 271, 533]. A. jama'icensis Leach, lituratusOlfers, cinereus (Gervais).Group represented in tropical America by a large number of individuals.The ecology is essentially variable among large species, which sometimes roostin the open air in the foliage, sometimes occupy the caves, the tree holes,roofs, etc. The small species seem arboreal and spend the day infoliage. Artibeus cinereus builds a shelter similar to that of Uroderma
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: BIOLOGY [25, 160, 173, 174, 190, 192, 237, 271, 292, 717]: D. rotundus isa common species, robust and adaptable, which inhabits all kinds of environments,from sea level to 2,500 meters above sea level in the Andes.The day shelter can be a hollow tree, an old dark building. Cornthis Vampire seems to prefer caves, whose ceilings have flawsand crevices.

column23: Genus Diphylla Spix. One species: D. ecaudata Spix, widespread from Mexicoin Peru.BIOLOGY [112, 160, 237].This Vampire is less common than Desmodus rotundus. He lives incaves, between 200 and 1,100 meters above sea level, isolated or in little coloniesmany. The species appears to feed exclusively on blood.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: Genus Diaemus Miller. A D. yougi Jentink species from tropical America.BIOLOGY [271].Little different from that of the preceding species. Lives in hollow treesand caves, sometimes in association with Desmodus. Form colonies ormeet young people of various ages with adults of both sexes, breedersor not. Reproduction is not synchronous in individuals of asame population.The species seems clearly specialized from the food point of view byrelation to the Desmodus; it is the birds that she would immediately attack.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column14: Old World as far as Sumatra
column23: Genus Rhinopoma Geoffroy. Three species specific to deserts, or semidesertsfrom the Old World, a species found as far as Sumatra.BIOLOGY [14, 100, 544].The distribution is related to aridity factors, and varies with these factors.In addition, Rhinopomas are absent from regions with cold winters: northernSahara, cold deserts of Asia.Caves and rock shelters constitute the primitive diurnal environment. CornRhinopomas have adapted to human environments, populating monuments,Pyramids in Egypt, palaces and temples in India, wells, inhabited housesand the Saharan rhettara. The most numerous colonies are linked toremains of ancient civilizations. Rhinopomas are localized duringday at the entrances to the cavities, taking refuge in the dark parts when they areworry.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column14: south of Mexico to Peru and central Brazil.
column23: Genus Rynchiscus Peter. A species R. naso (Wied), distributed to the south ofMexico to Peru and central Brazil.BIOLOGY [112, 161, 271].Very small species, common in tropical America, linked to the aquatic environment: outdoor accommodation during the day, under trunks, stems or rocksleans over the water. The coloring is mimetic with the barks orlichens. Gravid females retreated into tree holes. This speciesappears to hunt over water exclusively.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column14: Old World below the 45 'degree of north latitude
column23: Miller Miniopterinae subfamily - Genus Miniopterus. column23: Mother, or that of hibernation in cold regions, is almost always a large cavity, with an underground river, and upper closed galleries, where the hot air collects. Individuals can gravitate around this cavewithin a radius of 50/100 kilometers, temporarily populating cavitiesusually of lesser importance, to then return to the cave " mother ".
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: In the colony of Robbes Caves, inIndia, have been counted over 100,000 individuals.

column23: BIOLOGY [21, 25, 105, 588]: K. picta Pallas, hardwickei Horsfield, harrisoniThomas, etc. Kerivoula are small, probably common Chiroptera, butalways difficult to observe. As a result, their biology remains poorly understood. don't readnever roost in underground cavities or constructions, masts occupyvarious shelters, sometimes unexpected, like old bird nests (lanosa),spider webs (harrisoni), clumps of dry leaves (picta). Somespecies live in the cramped holes of trees (cuprosa).
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: BIOLOGY [21, 95, 214, 218, 431, 591, 715, etc.]: M. myotis (Borkhausen),lucifugus Le Conte, bocagei Peters, etc.Large cosmopolitan group, relatively homogeneous. Palearctic speciesand nearctics, which form the majority of European Chiroptera andfrom North America, have been well studied. Tropical Myotis, which arerepresented by smaller and less accessible populations, remainon the other hand, poorly known.The ecology varies with the species. All conceivable types of day shelterwere colonized by Myotis: small or large underground cavities, artificialor natural, cracks in rocks, piles of stones, burrows, tree holes,human constructions, bridges, foliage, etc.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: BIOLOGY [95, 157, 214, 331, 551, 603, etc.]: P. auritus Linne (fig. 72), rafinesquei(Lesson), mexicanus (G. M. Allen), towsendi Cooper.The genus Plecotus is a group of Chiroptera characterized by very largeears. The morphology and biology of all species are similar.Auritus and rafinesquei have a predominantly phytophilic ecology withadaptation to human constructions. In forest regions, they occupytree holes. In cultivated regions they are located in bell towers,attics and roofs of houses. Plecotus mexicanus and towsendi would bemore troglophiles. In the pre-Saharan regions, the Plecotus roost inthe rhettara. The Earwigs hibernate in isolation, in the narrow faults ofwet underground.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: Genus Euderma J. M. Allen. A species maculatum J. M. Allen from the southwestthe United States.The biology of this rare Chiroptera, remarkable for its stained coat ofwhite, remains almost unknown. A few individuals have been observed inhouses or underground cavities [331].
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: BIOLOGY (no overall review. Details scattered in manypublications): P. pipistrellus (Schreber), hesperus (H. Allen), kuhli Kuhl,coromandra (Gray), abramus Temminck, etc.The ecology is fairly uniform. Pipistrelles are contact species,linked to faults and cracks in rock and wood. The micro-middle is essentiallyformed by a narrow space where the animal has just room to slip into.Pipistrelles show a strong propensity to colonize houses, whichhave become the almost exclusive home of these Chiroptera in many regionsof the world.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: BIOLOGY (no overall review. Details scattered in manypublications): P. pipistrellus (Schreber), hesperus (H. column23: There are some aberrant locations; so in Africa,Pipistrellus nanus inhabits the terminal buds of bananas. Her presenceappears to be determined by that of these plants. In general, the Pipistrellesare not troglophiles. They become so during hibernation onlyin the northern regions of Europe and especially the United States.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: There are some aberrant locations; so in Africa,Pipistrellus nanus inhabits the terminal buds of bananas. Her presenceappears to be determined by that of these plants. column23: The Pipistrelles are, in general, the first Chiroptera whichappear at dusk, and are the last to disappear at dawn.The flight is capricious and fluttering. In cold regions, peoplecan be seen quite often on the hunt during the day.Few of the Pipistrelles form significant concentrations inthe daytime lodging. Populations are made up of small, but closefrom each other, which mostly live in the roofs of buildings.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column14: Eurasia, Azores, perhaps from North Africa
column23: Genus Nyctalus Bowdich. Half a dozen species of Eurasia,Azores, perhaps from North Africa.BIOLOGY [214, 468, 603, 696]: N. noctula Schreber, N. leisleri Kuhl.Noctules are arboreal Chiroptera, well represented inwooded and mountainous palearctic regions. They are much more commonin northern and central Europe than in the southwestern plainsand the Mediterranean area.Although they sometimes occupy buildings, the Noctules are mainlyinhabitants of tree holes, especially those who are hollowed out the old trunks by the peaks. These holes most often have a circular opening,relatively small, polished by the passage of Chiroptera, and located at aquite large height above the ground. A population of Noctules hasalways several lodgings, individuals moving spontaneously from one tothe other, even without disturbance. Hibernation and summer lodges aregenerally the same.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: Genus Nyctalus Bowdich. column23: Genres Chalinolobus Peters and Glauconycteris Dobson. Six species ofChalinolobus have been described from Australia, New Zealand, New ZealandCaledonia. Glauconycteris - 9 species - have a wide distribution inwestern and central Africa.BIOLOGY [10, 21, 25, 205, 206, 617]: Chalinolobus gouldi (fig. 73, B) Gray,Glauconycteris papilio Thomas, G. argentatus Dobson, G. beatrix Thomas.Little is known about the biology of these two genera on the whole. Chalinolobusgouldi appears to have a varied ecology, the species having been notedin epiphytes, lianas, hanging in swarms in branches, intree holes, and in large colonies in caves. The GlauconycterisAfricans are probably exclusively arboreal. lilies live in the dayunder the foliage of palm trees, shrubs and bushes, where their coatsmottled and the reticule design of their membranes must help to conceal them.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: BIOLOGY (details scattered in many publications): B. barbastellusSchreber.Species with very wide distribution and low density. Ecology is phytophilicand lithophile with different summer and winter lodgings. La Barbastelle occupies duringin the summer the cracks in trees, and especially those in frames in oldconstructions; sometimes it clings to the walls of rooms in dwellings.This species is particularly insensitive to light in its daytime roost.In winter, it retreats into the holes and cracks of underground cavitieshumid, usually small, frequently changing its location duringof winter depending on temperature variations.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: BIOLOGY [130, 214, 603, 695, etc.]: E. fuscus Beauvais, E. serotinusSchreber, E. nilsonni Keyserling and Blasius, E. tennuipinnis Peters.The ecology is similar to that of Pipistrelles. Serotines areVery common anthropophilic bats that roost in dwellings,roofs and frames. In uninhabited regions they occupy the holestrees, or slip under the bark, these environments constituting the diurnal biotopeprimitive. In cold regions, some species such as Eptesicus fuscuswill hibernate in underground cavities, while the European SerotinEptesicus serotinus spends the winter in buildings.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

In cold regions, some species such as Eptesicus fuscuswill hibernate in underground cavities, while the European SerotinEptesicus serotinus spends the winter in buildings.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: BIOLOGY [21, 25, 100, 277]: S. haethi Horsfield, S. temmincki Horsfield,S. nigrita Schreber.We find in biology the unity characterizing the morphology of thisgroup, represented by many individuals in Asia and Africa.The lower, dead and drooping part of the foliage of Borassus palmseverywhere constitutes the preferential roost of Scotophilus. They also occupy thetree holes, roofs and even underground cavities, manifesting everywherea marked propensity for synanthropy.

column23: BIOLOGY [102, 142, 243]: L. borealis Muller, L. cinereus Beauvois,L. braehyotis J. A. Allen.The Lasiurus form a specialized group, whose biology is particularlyoriginal.They are outdoor species, even in northern regions. Theyspend the day in the foliage, or patches on the bark. Their coat frostgray and red, conceals them in the daytime lodging. All kinds of treeshardwoods can provide shelter to Lasiurus. The Galapagos species inhabit themangroves, and under the pallets of giant Opuntia. Rarely, subjectshave been observed in underground cavities.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: Genus Cheiromeles Horsfield. Two species from the Sunda Islands.BIOLOGY [425-426,491]: M. torquatus Horsfield (fig. 75), M. parvidens Millerand Hollister.Cheiromeles are remarkable for their large size, lack of peeling, and the possession of lateral membranous pockets in which theseChiroptera fold their wings. According to Kitchener, the day shelter would be intree holes, but Lord Medway observed the species in aSarawak. The colony, 18 to 20,000 individuals strong, gathered in swarmscompact. The behavior is noisy. These large Chiroptera hunt irregularly,and do not leave their lodge every night. Despite their badsmell, they are eaten by the Dayak people.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: The ecology is lithophilic and phytophilic, with subsequent adaptation tohuman environments: roofs, frames, etc. The Molossians are essentiallycontact Chiroptera that search for narrow faults, interstices ofstones, thin cracks in the branches and trunks, just leaving the animalthe place where to slip between the two walls. On the vaults of the caves, theypile up in tight swarms, satisfying their "chasmotropism" by contactmutual. In general the Molossians take off with difficulty from the ground; toodo they seek day lodgings whose openings overlook the void. Howeverseveral species roost under the slabs and rocks which accumulate in the bedrivers, at ground level or water. There are also manyMolossi in the dry drooping leaves of the crown of palm trees.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: The great European Horseshoe Bat, with its ecological associate Myotis emarginatus,also successively uses the different floors of the old castlesto the best of its metabolic comfort. Beaucournu gives an example with thecolony that he studied in the castle of the due de Nantes, and I made observationsvery similar in the castle colony of Glenay (Deux-Sevres).When Rhinolophs and Vespertilions arrive in April, they are localized in thecold cellars, where they hibernate during the day. Then when the femalesbecome pregnant, they reach the upper floor of the castle which benefitsof greater heat. This is where the birth takes place in June.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: The constancy of the associations of the great Horseshoe Bat with theHorseshoe Bat and with the echancre Vespertilion, that of the Vespernlion ofCapaccini with the Minioptera, that of Rhinolophus rouxi and Rhmolophuslepidus in India, respond, to a certain extent, to an identity of theecological
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: Associations of different species of Myotis are very frequent. In Europe, weeven observes constant groupings with different genera. Thereby,Myotis capaccinii Bonaparte slips under the swarms of Miniopteres, and Myotisemarginatus (Geoffroy) regularly parasitizes the colonies of the Greater Horseshoe Bat.

column23: In the two years I spent in India I had 1 opportunityto observe the habits of Megaderma lyra, which is particularly commonin the vicinity of inhabited places. During the night, under the lamps, we see himexplore the ground, the surface of walls and trunks in search of its prey,Geckos, Frogs and Small Birds. He also pursues the Pipistrelles, sometimesto the interior of the houses. To skin its prey, it hangs on the ceilingverandas, the humans who sleep there receive on their mosquito nets thereliefs of the Megaderm meal: wings and tails of Birds or Pipistrelles,Frogs' legs, etc. [17, 290, 565].
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: The only specific predator of bats is a Fauci; i twilightfrom the tropics of Africa and Asia, Machaeramphus alcinus. I've hadthe chance to observe at length the evolutions of this rare Bird in the forestGabonese, where it seems linked to the giant colonies of Hipposideros. From the twilight,this Falcon, who looks like a Pilgrim in size and Failure, appears,above the caves. He rushes into the column of Chiroptera, in the directionof their flight, and never seem to miss his attacks. Does he swallow the batsas one "gobbles an oyster" according to the expression of an ancient author?It is doubtful. It seems that the Chiroptera is seized and pierced first by thegreenhouses, before being swallowed whole. After ten passes, his huntis finished; the Bird is moving away. At dawn, he reappears and makes a secondmeal at the expense of the Hipposideros who return to their cave.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: BIOLOGY [112, 237, 271].The cirrhosa species has been observed in tree holes and caves,isolated or in small colonies of a dozen individuals of both sexes.These Chiroptera associate with other species. TheTrachops hunt small Vertebras, and in Panama they would eat mainlyGeckos.

column23: BIOLOGY [237, 271, 658]: A. geoffroyi Gray.Ecology is troglophile. The Anoura were observed in tight swarmsin the cavities of the ceilings, caves, not far from the porches. column23: BIOLOGY [25, 80, 104, 237, 271]: C. perspicillata (Linne) and castaneaH. Allen.Carollia are very common in tropical America. We observe themin all kinds of gites: caves, tree holes, under the foliage. Theyoften locate in drainage pipes under roads.The Carollia are sociable, and form colonies of two to a hundredof individuals, or males and females sometimes live together, sometimes separately.These Chiroptera associate with all kinds of other species.The flight is skilful and fast. Griffin has shown that the Carollias use avery special type of ultrasound, probably adapted to their lifestyle. The foodconsists of fruits; the small ones are taken away, the large ones consumed on the spot.Bananas are particularly popular.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: Subfamily Stenoderminae Gill - Genus Brachyphylla Gray.Two species from the Antilles.BIOLOGY [42, 83]: little known. B. cavernarum Gray.A colony of 2000/2500 subjects was observed by Bond and Seaman indark chambers of ruins. No reproduction in December, butlactating females in June. The diet is insectivorous, perhaps also fruit-eating.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: Genus Diaemus Miller. A D. yougi Jentink species from tropical America.BIOLOGY [271].Little different from that of the preceding species. Lives in hollow treesand caves, sometimes in association with Desmodus. Form colonies ormeet young people of various ages with adults of both sexes, breedersor not. Reproduction is not synchronous in individuals of asame population.The species seems clearly specialized from the food point of view byrelation to the Desmodus; it is the birds that she would immediately attack.

column23: Genus Rhinopoma Geoffroy. Three species specific to deserts, or semidesertsfrom the Old World, a species found as far as Sumatra.BIOLOGY [14, 100, 544].The distribution is related to aridity factors, and varies with these factors.In addition, Rhinopomas are absent from regions with cold winters: northernSahara, cold deserts of Asia.Caves and rock shelters constitute the primitive diurnal environment. CornRhinopomas have adapted to human environments, populating monuments,Pyramids in Egypt, palaces and temples in India, wells, inhabited housesand the Saharan rhettara. The most numerous colonies are linked toremains of ancient civilizations. Rhinopomas are localized duringday at the entrances to the cavities, taking refuge in the dark parts when they areworry.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: Genus Cheiromeles Horsfield. Two species from the Sunda Islands.BIOLOGY [425-426,491]: M. torquatus Horsfield (fig. 75), M. parvidens Millerand Hollister.Cheiromeles are remarkable for their large size, lack of peeling, and the possession of lateral membranous pockets in which theseChiroptera fold their wings. According to Kitchener, the day shelter would be intree holes, but Lord Medway observed the species in aSarawak. The colony, 18 to 20,000 individuals strong, gathered in swarmscompact. The behavior is noisy. These large Chiroptera hunt irregularly,and do not leave their lodge every night. Despite their badsmell, they are eaten by the Dayak people.
column34: Brosset, A.1966. La Biologie des Chiropteres. Masson et Cie, Paris, vii + 24

column23: On March 20, 1957, H. P. Kirby and the writer found Mexican free-tailed bats, Tadarida brasiliensis mexicana Saussure, and cave myotis, Myotis velifer incautus (J. A. Allen), occupying abandoned nests of the cliff swallow, Petrochelidon pyrrhonata, under a high bridge over a stream, locally known as Pinto Creek, 18.6 miles southeast of Del Rio, in Kinney County, Texas.
column34: Buchanan,O. M. 1958. Tadarida and Myotis occupying cliff swallow nests. J.Mamm., 39:344-345.

column23: In the State of Oklahoma there are five known cave-dwelling colonies of freetail bats. The species formerly also occupied the Alabaster Cavern, but has abandoned it except periods in spring and fall since it has been illuminated and opened to the public. The cavern is used by them throughout the summer as a night roost, however.
column34: Buchanan,O. M. 1958. Tadarida and Myotis occupying cliff swallow nests. J.Mamm., 39:344-345.

column23: The liquid capacity of this nest was estimated at about 1 1/2 pints. The 25 bats from this nest proved to consist of 20 Tadarida and 5 Myotis, all males. Subsequent collecting yielded 17 more bats from four additional nests: 11 Tadarida and 6 myotis, all males, with the exception of one female Myotis. The solitary female was taken from the nest containing both male Myotis and male Tadarida; she was without young and subsequent dissection proved her to be not pregnant. All nests from which specimens were collected contained both Tadarida and Myotis communially, with the exception of one nest which contained only two Myotis. Half of the ten nests examined contained no bats.
column34: Buchanan,O. M. 1958. Tadarida and Myotis occupying cliff swallow nests. J.Mamm., 39:344-345.

column23: During winter, M. septentrionalis is found at hibernacula,which are commonly caves or abandoned mines (Caireet al., 1979; Griffin, 1940; Hitchcock, 1965; Whitaker and Rissler,1992a, 1992b).

column34: Caceres, M.C.; Barclay, R.M. Myotis septentrionalis. Mamm. Species 2000, 634, 1-4.

column23: During winter, M. septentrionalis is found at hibernacula,which are commonly caves or abandoned mines (Caireet al., 1979; Griffin, 1940; Hitchcock, 1965; Whitaker and Rissler,1992a, 1992b).
column27: Caire et al., 1979; Griffin, 1940; Hitchcock, 1965; Whitaker and Rissler, 1992a, 1992b
column34: Caceres, M.C.; Barclay, R.M. Myotis septentrionalis. Mamm. Species 2000, 634, 1-4.

column23: M. septentrionalis was the second most common speciescaptured swarming at Renfrew Mine in Ontario but made up ,10%of all individuals caught (Fenton, 1969).
column34: Caceres, M.C.; Barclay, R.M. Myotis septentrionalis. Mamm. Species 2000, 634, 1-4.

column23: A large number of bats caught when trapping at an abandoned mine entrancein mid-March were M. septentrionalis (Whitaker and Rissler, 1992b).
column34: Caceres, M.C.; Barclay, R.M. Myotis septentrionalis. Mamm. Species 2000, 634, 1-4.

column23: During summer, M. septentrionalis occupies a variety of day and night roosts. It favors tree roosts, although individuals have been found in human-made structures (Barbour and Davis, 1969; Foster and Kurta, 1999; Kunz, 1973; Sasse and Pekins, 1996; van Zyll de Jong, 1985).
column27: Barbour and Davis, 1969; Foster and Kurta, 1999; Kunz, 1973; Sasse and Pekins, 1996; van Zyll de Jong, 1985
column34: Caceres, M.C.; Barclay, R.M. Myotis septentrionalis. Mamm. Species 2000, 634, 1-4.

column27: Barbour and Davis, 1969; Foster and Kurta, 1999; Kunz, 1973; Sasse and Pekins, 1996; van Zyll de Jong, 1985
column34: Caceres, M.C.; Barclay, R.M. Myotis septentrionalis. Mamm. Species 2000, 634, 1-4.

column23: Maternity groups roost in trees, under shingles, and in buildings (Brandon, 1961; Clark et al., 1987; Foster and Kurta, 1999; Mumford and Cope, 1964; Nagorsen and Brigham, 1993; Sasse and Pekins, 1996).
column27: Brandon, 1961; Clark et al., 1987; Foster and Kurta, 1999; Mumford and Cope, 1964; Nagorsen and Brigham, 1993; Sasse and Pekins, 1996
column34: Caceres, M.C.; Barclay, R.M. Myotis septentrionalis. Mamm. Species 2000, 634, 1-4.

column23: During the day, female M. septentrionalis in New Hampshire prefer to roost in tall, large-diameter hardwood trees in early stages of decay (Sasse and Pekins, 1996).
column34: Caceres, M.C.; Barclay, R.M. Myotis septentrionalis. Mamm. Species 2000, 634, 1-4.

column23: M. septentrionalis in BritishColumbia also roosted in tall, early decay trees or in live trees withless canopy closure than randomly available trees (Caceres, 1998).
column34: Caceres, M.C.; Barclay, R.M. Myotis septentrionalis. Mamm. Species 2000, 634, 1-4.

column23: Female M. septentrionalis in Michigan roosted in crevices, in hollows, or under bark of live and dead deciduous trees. Females roosted in larger-diameter tree species (maples, Acer, and green ash, Fraxinus pennsylvanica) present in the stand, but characteristics of occupied and unoccupied trees were not significantly different (Foster and Kurta, 1999).
column34: Caceres, M.C.; Barclay, R.M. Myotis septentrionalis. Mamm. Species 2000, 634, 1-4.

column23: Occasionally, M. septentrionalis will use caves as temporary night roosts between foraging bouts (Barbour and Davis, 1969).
column34: Caceres, M.C.; Barclay, R.M. Myotis septentrionalis. Mamm. Species 2000, 634, 1-4.

column23: Myotis septentrionalis will return to the same hibernaculumalthough not always in sequential seasons. Individuals generallyhibernate with large numbers of bats of other species, particularlyM. lucifugus, Eptesicus fuscus, and Pipistrellus subflavus, but M.septentrionalis usually forms a small proportion of the total hibernatingpopulation (Caire et al., 1979; Griffin, 1940; Hitchcock,1949; Mills, 1971).
column27: Caire et al., 1979; Griffin, 1940; Hitchcock,1949; Mills, 1971
column34: Caceres, M.C.; Barclay, R.M. Myotis septentrionalis. Mamm. Species 2000, 634, 1-4.

column23: One of the largest hibernating populations was about 300 M. septentrionalis hibernating with about 1,000 M. lucifugus in an abandoned mine in Quebec (Thomas, 1993).

column23: M. septentrionalis hosts chiggers (Trombiculidae: Euschoengastiapipistrelli, Leptotrombidium myotis), other mites (Acarina: Acanthopthirus,Macronyssus crosbyi, Spinturax americanus, Olabidocarpuswhitakeri), batbugs (Cimicidae: Cimex adjunctus—Jonesand Genoways, 1967; Whitaker, 1973), and internal helminths (Hymenolepischristensoni, Vampirolepis roundabushi, Prosthodendriumvolaticum, Plagiorchis vespertilionis—Blankespoor andSzymusiek, 1974; Nickel and Hansen, 1967). Rabies virus (CVS27) and eastern equine encephalomyelitis have been detected in afew northern long-eared bats (Burnett, 1989; Main, 1979).
column34: Caceres, M.C.; Barclay, R.M. Myotis septentrionalis. Mamm. Species 2000, 634, 1-4.

column34: Caire, W., R. K. Laval, M.L. Laval, and R. Clawson. 1979. Notes on the ecology of Myotis keenii (Chiroptera, Vespertilionidae) in eastern Missouri. The American Midland Natu-ralist, 102:404–407.

column23: Little is known about the winter ecology of Myotis keenii in eastern Missouri. As part of our investigations, 141 trips were made to 77 caves in the Sullivan area for the purpose of counting hibernating bats (primarily M. sodalis and M. grisescens) and recording environmental data. During these visits 86,936 bats (total of maximum monthly counts of Myotis observed in caves from October 1975 to April 1976) were observed in hibernation, primarily M. sodalis (see LaVal et al., 1976, for additional information on all species and methods). Of the total, only 39 were M. keenii. Many of the hibernating M. keenii secluded in the formations of the caves. This may account for the small number seen. Individuals trapped while exiting the caves were commonly soiled with mud and clay. This would suggest the bats were roosting in the tighter recesses of the caves, such as crevices.
column34: Caire, W., R. K. Laval, M.L. Laval, and R. Clawson. 1979. Notes on the ecology of Myotis keenii (Chiroptera, Vespertilionidae) in eastern Missouri. The American Midland Natu-ralist, 102:404–407.

column23: During summer, females and their young typically roost under loose bark (Cope et aI., 1974; Mumford and Cope, 1958), but also within tree crevices (J .E. Gardner and J .E. Hofmann, in lilt.) and cavities (Kurta et aI., 1993).
column34: Callahan, E. V., R. D. Drobney, and R. L. Clawson. 1997. Selection of summer roosting sites by Indiana bats (Myotis sodalis) in Missouri. Journal of Mammalogy, 78: 818-825.

column23: Studies of maternity colonies in Indiana (Humphreyet aI., 1977), lllinois (J.E. Gardner and J.E. Hofmann, in litt.), and Michigan (Kurta et aI., 1993) have yielded information concerning characteristics of roost trees and roosting behavior of Indiana bats. These studies showed that Indiana bats typically select large-diameter living and dead trees with loose or exfoliating bark, and that exposure to sunlight is an important characteristic influencing suitability of roosts.

column14: South Fabius River, South Knox, Missouri
column23: Four colonies located in three countries in northern Missouri were inc1uded in this study. Two colonies were located in Knox Co. and one colony was located in each of Macon and Sullivan counties. Each colony was situated near a stream or river. The South Knox colony was on the South Fabius River, the Dye colony (also in Knox Co.) was near Bridge Creek, the Macon colony was near the Middle Fork of the Salt River, and the Sullivan colony was near West Locust Creek. Colonies were situated on 25- 50% forested land, inc1uding riparian and upland areas. Forested areas comprised predominately oaks (Quercus) and shagbark hickories (Carya ovata). Non-forested areas were comprised predominately of row crops at the South Knox colony. but were largely field and pasture at the other three colonies. A maternity colony consisted of a group of female Indiana bats and their young that used the same set of roost trees. All roost trees used by female or juvenile bats were considered to be maternity roost trees in this study. Maternity roost trees used by members of each colony were found by attaching radiotransmitters (Holohil Systems Ltd., Woodlawn, Ontario) to Indiana bats and subsequently relocating them at their roosts in daylight during 1989 and 1990...Bats were netted over streams at night from15 May to 15 August using mist nets extendedto a height of 6 m (Gardner et al., 1989).
column34: Callahan, E. V., R. D. Drobney, and R. L. Clawson. 1997. Selection of summer roosting sites by Indiana bats (Myotis sodalis) in Missouri. Journal of Mammalogy, 78: 818-825.

column23: Fifty-four roost trees werelocated at four maternity colony sites of Indianabats in northern Missouri (Table 1).The number of roosts used by a colonyranged from 10 to 20. Seventy-two percentof the roost trees were snags (dead trees)and 56% were located in the forest interior.Only one roost was in a live tree exposedto direct sunlight. With four exceptions (onewhite ash-Fraxinus americana, two silvermaples-Acer saccharinum. and one cottonwood-populus deltoides), dead treeswere either oaks (Quercus) or shagbarkhickories. Live trees selected as roosts wereshagbark hickories, with the exception ofthree red oaks (Quercus rubra).
column34: Callahan, E. V., R. D. Drobney, and R. L. Clawson. 1997. Selection of summer roosting sites by Indiana bats (Myotis sodalis) in Missouri. Journal of Mammalogy, 78: 818-825.

column23: Of these, two species, Lasionycterisnoctivagans and Lasiurus cinereus,have been shown to be more commonin older forests within their range in the PacificNorthwest (Perkins and Cross, 1988;Thomas and West, 1991). The associationof these species with older forests is likelydue to their roosting requirements. Theyroost in foliage, in or under the bark oftrees, or in tree cavities (Barbour and Davis,1969; Barclay et aI., 1988; Kunz, 1982a).

column23: A NUMBER OF NEOTROPICAL BATS are known to modify leaves of plants into "tents" for use as daytime roosts. Barbour (1932) and Chapman (1932) were the first to describe this behavior in Artibeus watsoni and Uroderma bilobatum, respectively, two frugiv- orous bats of the subfamily Stenodermatinae (Fam- ily Phyllostomidae).
column34: Charles-Dominique, P. 1993. Tent use by the bat Rhinophylla pumilio (Phyllostomidae: Carolliinae) in French Guiana. Biotropica, 25: 111-116.

column23: Tents were made in horizontal leaves, ranging from 0.60 to 2.20 m in height, in a "free" environment, i.e., relatively far from the trunks, branches, or lianas as described by Brooke (1987) for the tents of Vampyressa nymphaea.
column34: Charles-Dominique, P. 1993. Tent use by the bat Rhinophylla pumilio (Phyllostomidae: Carolliinae) in French Guiana. Biotropica, 25: 111-116.

column23: These tents of a second type (in Philodendron) were similar to those described for Artibeus cinereus, A. gnomus, and Vampyressa nymphaea in the leaves of Philodendron and Monstera (Araceae) by Brooke (1987) and Timm (1987) and classified as "simple apical tents" by Kunz (pers. comm.).
column34: Charles-Dominique, P. 1993. Tent use by the bat Rhinophylla pumilio (Phyllostomidae: Carolliinae) in French Guiana. Biotropica, 25: 111-116.

column23: However, during a census conducted in May 1991 at the Nouragues station, a group of Mesophylla was ob- served in a typical tent constructed in a young A. sciophilum (A. Cockle, pers. comm.)...However, in French Guiana, with one exception (Mesophylla macconnelli), no other bat species have yet been observed roosting in such palm tents.

column23: The Stenodermatinae bat Ectophylla is also described in Central America for using tents both for diurnal roosting and for feeding activity (Brooke 1990).
column34: Charles-Dominique, P. 1993. Tent use by the bat Rhinophylla pumilio (Phyllostomidae: Carolliinae) in French Guiana. Biotropica, 25: 111-116.

column23: Careful examination of the ground below the tents yielded evi- dence of food remains (e.g., Piperaceae, infructes- cence axes, Araceae seeds, Schlegellia surinamensis fruit pericarps) from R. pumilio, indicating that this bat also uses tents as nocturnal feeding roosts.
column34: Charles-Dominique, P. 1993. Tent use by the bat Rhinophylla pumilio (Phyllostomidae: Carolliinae) in French Guiana. Biotropica, 25: 111-116.

column23: Bats were first reported modifying the shape of leaves to construct diurnal roostingstructures or 'tents' by Phillips (1924) in Sri Lanka, and by Barbour (1932) andChapman (1932) in Panama. To date, 16 species of bat of six genera in three familiesare known to alter plant leaves in order to construct tent roosts of various shapes andsizes (Phillips, 1924; Goodwin, 1979; Kunz, 1982; Timm, 1987; Rickart et al., 1989).Uroderma bilobatum, Peters's tent-making bat, was the species of bat that Barbour(1932) reported to have altered the leaves of two palms, Livistona chinensis andPrichardia pacifica. Since then, it has also been noted modifying leaves of at least fourother species of plants (Timm, 1987).
column34: Choe, J. C. 1994. Ingenious design of tent roosts by Peter's tent-making bat, Uroderma bilobatum (Chiroptera: Phyllostomidae). Journal of Natural History, 28: 731- 737.

column14: Barro Colorado Island (79050 , 15"W, 9°9'41"N), Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute,
column23: In October 1986 I discovered a new type of bat tent in Coccoloba manzanillensis Beurl. (Polygonaceae) by U. bilobatum on Barro Colorado Island, Panama (Fig. 1). While all previously known bat tents are made of large single leaves, I report for the first time tents that consist of multiple leaves and describe the complex behaviour exhibited in the construction of the tent.
column34: Choe, J. C. 1994. Ingenious design of tent roosts by Peter's tent-making bat, Uroderma bilobatum (Chiroptera: Phyllostomidae). Journal of Natural History, 28: 731- 737.

column14: Barro Colorado Island (79050 , 15"W, 9°9'41"N), Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute,
column23: In 1966 I located a total of 17 C. manzaniUensis whose leaves were alteredfor diurnal roosts. Three and four more trees with tents were added to the recordin 1987 and 1988, respectively.

column23: Why does U. bilobatum inhabiting C. manzanillensis use only juvenile plants?Foster (1992) also found a preference for young Astrocaryum macrocalyx fronds byVampyressa macconnelli. Choe and Timm (1985) suggested that Artibeus watsonimay find young Anthurium ravenii leaves easier to chew than older leaves. Anotheradvantage may come from the fact that juvenile plants produce much larger leaves withlonger petioles (Croat, 1978). Selection of young plants may also reflect the bat'spreferred height of foraging flight. Timm (1987) noted U. bilobatum hanging under aS. rostrata tent approximately 4.5 m above the ground. The mean height of C. nuciferawith tents is 2.3 m (Timm and Lewis, 1991). Based on these observations and mine,it appears that U. bilobatum roosts under tents within 2-5 m off the ground.
column34: Choe, J. C. 1994. Ingenious design of tent roosts by Peter's tent-making bat, Uroderma bilobatum (Chiroptera: Phyllostomidae). Journal of Natural History, 28: 731- 737.

column23: Why does U. bilobatum inhabiting C. manzanillensis use only juvenile plants?Foster (1992) also found a preference for young Astrocaryum macrocalyx fronds byVampyressa macconnelli. Choe and Timm (1985) suggested that Artibeus watsonimay find young Anthurium ravenii leaves easier to chew than older leaves. Anotheradvantage may come from the fact that juvenile plants produce much larger leaves withlonger petioles (Croat, 1978). Selection of young plants may also reflect the bat'spreferred height of foraging flight. Timm (1987) noted U. bilobatum hanging under aS. rostrata tent approximately 4.5 m above the ground. The mean height of C. nuciferawith tents is 2.3 m (Timm and Lewis, 1991). Based on these observations and mine,it appears that U. bilobatum roosts under tents within 2-5 m off the ground.
column34: Choe, J. C. 1994. Ingenious design of tent roosts by Peter's tent-making bat, Uroderma bilobatum (Chiroptera: Phyllostomidae). Journal of Natural History, 28: 731- 737.

column23: In Guanacaste, Costa Rica, Lewis (1992) observed that U. bilobatum arrive at the C. nucifera roost tents in June.
column34: Choe, J. C. 1994. Ingenious design of tent roosts by Peter's tent-making bat, Uroderma bilobatum (Chiroptera: Phyllostomidae). Journal of Natural History, 28: 731- 737.

column23: Bloedel (1955) reported that in late March, in Panama, females roost in clusters of 20-40 with their nursing young under palm tents, while males usually roost solitarily or in small groups of 2-5.

column23: I also located two maternity groups of U. bilobatum under Scheelea zonensis (probably the same as S. rostrata; see Croat, 1978 for details) fronds on Barro Colorado Island in early April 1987 (Choe, 1987 unpublished data).

column23: Bats were first noted altering the shape of leaves for diurnal roosting structures by Barbour (1932) who found that Uroderma bilobatum cut the leaves of palms in Panama.

column23: Chapman (1932) reported that Artibeus watsoni also roosted under altered palm leaves which he called 'tents'.

column23: One Old World bat, Cynopterus sphinx (Ptero- podidae), has been reported altering palm leaves to create a diurnal roosting structure (Goodwin 1979).

column14: Sirenia field station, Parque Nacional de Corcovad, Osa Peninsula, 80 29' N, 830 35' W
column23: The discovery of an abundant population of Artibeus watsoni in Costa Rica that was altering leaves of Anthurium ravenii for tents led to the following questions: (1) Does A. watsoni select leaves of a specific size class? (2) Does A watsoni preferentially select leaves located within a particular region of the plant? (3) How many leaves per plant does A. watsoni modify for tents? and (4) What is the selective advantage incurred by the bats in choos- ing specific leaves and modifying them?...Seventeen separate individuals of A. ravenii were found to have one or more leaves altered to form tents.
column34: Choe, J. C., and R. M. Timm. 1985. Roosting site selection by Artibeus watsoni (Chiroptera: Phyllostomidae) on Anthurium ravenii (Araceae) in Costa Rica. Journal of ropical Ecology, 1: 241-247.
