column34: Chu, D.K.W.; Peiris, J.S.M.; Chen, H.; Guan, Y.; Poon, L.L.M. 2008. Genomic characterizations of bat coronaviruses (1A, 1B and HKU8) and evidence for co-infections in Miniopterus bats. J. Gen. Virol. 2008, 89(5), 1282-1287.

column23: In addition, we also performed a longitudinal study on Miniopterus magnater and Miniopterus pusillus bats that cohabit an abandoned cave in Hong Kong (Chu et al., 2006). BtCoV HKU7 and bat- SARS-CoV were detected only once in our specimens, while BtCoVs 1A, 1B and HKU8 were detected repeatedly in these bats. A clear host species restriction was observed with BtCoV 1A being found in M. magnater and BtCoV 1B in M. pusillus even though these two CoVs are genetically very similar and the two bat species co-inhabit the same cave.
column34: Chu, D.K.W.; Peiris, J.S.M.; Chen, H.; Guan, Y.; Poon, L.L.M. 2008. Genomic characterizations of bat coronaviruses (1A, 1B and HKU8) and evidence for co-infections in Miniopterus bats. J. Gen. Virol. 2008, 89(5), 1282-1287.

column23: In addition, we also performed a longitudinal study on Miniopterus magnater and Miniopterus pusillus bats that cohabit an abandoned cave in Hong Kong (Chu et al., 2006). BtCoV HKU7 and bat- SARS-CoV were detected only once in our specimens, while BtCoVs 1A, 1B and HKU8 were detected repeatedly in these bats. A clear host species restriction was observed with BtCoV 1A being found in M. magnater and BtCoV 1B in M. pusillus even though these two CoVs are genetically very similar and the two bat species co-inhabit the same cave...A total of38 specimens collected in a period from 2004 to 2006 inHong Kong, which were known to be positive for CoV(Chu et al., 2006), were tested by six different speciesspecificRT-PCR assays (RdRp and N genes of BtCoV 1A,1B and HKU8). The identities of the amplified productswere all confirmed by sequencing. In summary, infectionwith 1A alone was detected in 16 specimens collected fromM. magnater, infection with 1B alone was detected in 14specimens collected from M. pusillus and infection withBtCoV HKU8 alone was detected in one specimen collectedfrom M. magnater. There was no evidence of co-infectionswith the more genetically closely related viruses 1A and 1B,even though these two viruses co-habited the same caveand were more frequently detected in our specimens fromtheir corresponding hosts. These results suggest that thereis a strong host restriction for these two viruses thatapparently hinders interspecies transmission between thesetwo species of bat. Interestingly, co-infections of 1B andHKU8 were detected in seven M. pusillus specimenscollected in 2004 (n52) and 2006 (n55) (Table 2).
column34: Chu, D.K.W.; Peiris, J.S.M.; Chen, H.; Guan, Y.; Poon, L.L.M. 2008. Genomic characterizations of bat coronaviruses (1A, 1B and HKU8) and evidence for co-infections in Miniopterus bats. J. Gen. Virol. 2008, 89(5), 1282-1287.

column14: Jackass Flats, 4 1/2 miles N Davis Dam, 3/4 miles W Lake Mohave, about 800 feet elevation, Clark County, Nevada
column23: To our knowledge, the cave myotis, Myotis velifer, has not been previously recorded from Nevada. As the following observations demonstrate, this bat is probably resident southeastern Clark County, Nevada, at least during the summer months. Musgrove visited a mine on Jackass Flats, 4 1/2 miles N Davis Dam, 3/4 miles W Mohave, about 800 feet elevation, Clark County, Nevada, on 9 April 1961 with his advanced science class from Kingman (Arizona) High School. On this date he observed 20 California leaf-nosed bats, Macrotus californicus. The mine consisted of a series of interconnected shafts and rooms. In places much guano was present, leading to the supposition that the mine was used as a summer roost by some other species
column34: Cockrum,E.L.,and B. F. Musgrove. 1964. Cave myotis, Myotis velifer, from southern Nevada. J.Mamm., 45: 636-637.

column14: Jackass Flats, 4 1/2 miles N Davis Dam, 3/4 miles W Lake Mohave, about 800 feet elevation, Clark County, Nevada
column23: The mine was again visited on 13 August 1961, this time by Musgrove and two graduate students from the Zoology Department at the University of Arizona. On this visit 46 males and 63 female Macrotus californicus were banded, as were 24 male and 22 female cave myotis, Myotis velifer. One male Yuma myotis Myotis yumanensis was found dead
column34: Cockrum,E.L.,and B. F. Musgrove. 1964. Cave myotis, Myotis velifer, from southern Nevada. J.Mamm., 45: 636-637.

column14: Jackass Flats, 4 1/2 miles N Davis Dam, 3/4 miles W Lake Mohave, about 800 feet elevation, Clark County, Nevada
column23: Musgrove again visited the mine on 29 June 1962. On this visit 7 male Macrotus californicus were banded of approximately 50 that were present. vertical airshafts and were not readily accessible for banding. About 70 Myotis were present, of which 3 males and 16 females were banded, and 4 males and 10 females recovered. All recoveries had been banded at the same place on 13 August 1961. Hanging in the same cluster with the cave myotis were about 100 Myotis yumanensis.
column34: Cockrum,E.L.,and B. F. Musgrove. 1964. Cave myotis, Myotis velifer, from southern Nevada. J.Mamm., 45: 636-637.

About 70 Myotis were present, of which 3 males and 16 females were banded, and 4 males and 10 females recovered. All recoveries had been banded at the same place on 13 August 1961. Hanging in the same cluster with the cave myotis were about 100 Myotis yumanensis.
column34: Cockrum,E.L.,and B. F. Musgrove. 1964. Cave myotis, Myotis velifer, from southern Nevada. J.Mamm., 45: 636-637.

column14: spillway at Davis Dam, Mohave County, Arizona
column23: Two of the recoveries were originally banded from crevices above the spillway at Davis Dam, Mohave County, Arizona, on 16 April 1962 and 1 from a mine tunnel at Telephone Cave, 1 mile N Katherine Landing, Mohave County, Arizona on 13 August 1961. In addition to these adult myotis there were hanging in the same cluster about 150 young, apparently of both species, that appeared to be a week to 10 days old. In another room, two lump-nosed bats, Plecotus townsendi, were taken and banded.
column34: Cockrum,E.L.,and B. F. Musgrove. 1964. Cave myotis, Myotis velifer, from southern Nevada. J.Mamm., 45: 636-637.

column14: Jackass Flats, 4 1/2 miles N Davis Dam, 3/4 miles W Lake Mohave, about 800 feet elevation, Clark County, Nevada
column23: The mine was again visited on 13 August 1961, this time by Musgrove and two graduate students from the Zoology Department at the University of Arizona. On this visit 46 males and 63 female Macrotus californicus were banded, as were 24 male and 22 female cave myotis, Myotis velifer. One male Yuma myotis Myotis yumanensis was found dead
column34: Cockrum,E.L.,and B. F. Musgrove. 1964. Cave myotis, Myotis velifer, from southern Nevada. J.Mamm., 45: 636-637.

column14: Jackass Flats, 4 1/2 miles N Davis Dam, 3/4 miles W Lake Mohave, about 800 feet elevation, Clark County, Nevada
column23: This mine was again visited on 10 July 1963 by Musgrove and his two sons, Terry and Kent. At 3:00 Pm, the temperature in the shade outside the mine entrance was 112? F and the temperature in the mine was 78? F. About 200 Macrotus californicus were present; 45 males and 51 females were banded, 2 males and 12 females recovered. All specimens had been originally banded in the same mine, the females and one of the males on 13 August 1961 and one male on 29 June 1962. The males were hanging in an airshaft and the females in a small room. The females each had a small young attached. Two male Plecotus were banded and one female recovered (originally banded in the same mine on 29 June 1962). Only a few myotis were present: four Myotis velifer (one female a re- covery, banded at the same place on 13 August 1961); five Myotis yumanensis (one female a recovery, banded at Davis Dam on 15 April 1962) and one Myotis californicus
column34: Cockrum,E.L.,and B. F. Musgrove. 1964. Cave myotis, Myotis velifer, from southern Nevada. J.Mamm., 45: 636-637.

column14: western edge of Camilla, Mitchell County, adjacent to a sewage disposal plant, Georgia
column23: During the period August 8, 1955 to June 30, 1956, while engaged in wildlife rabies investigations at the Newton Field Station, 12 miles southwest of Newton, Baker County, Georgia, the writer took advantage of occasional opportunities to seek out and observe Lasiurine bats...Oak hammock No. 1 is an area situated at the western edge of Camilla, Mitchell County, adjacent to a sewage disposal plant...Bat/day observations for L. seminolus at oak hammock No. 1 are: Feb. 8 (1), 12 (1), March5 (1),22 (1),23 (1),26 (1),April21(3)...Moss shelters.-In every instance bats were discovered hanging in or on pendant clumps of moss. In oak hammock No. 1 bats were found in moss on four live oaks and one overcup oak.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1958. Ecological observations on lasiurine bats in Georgia. Journal of Mammalogy, 39: 64-70.

column14: Newton Field Station, west of Ichawaynochaway Creek,  12 miles southwest of Newton, Baker County, Georgia
column23: Oak hammock No. 2 is an area at the Newton Field Station situated west of Ichawaynochaway Creek and separated from the creek by a narrow strip streambank forest (Norris, loc. cit.)...Similar data for oak hammock No. 2 are: Feb. 21 (1), 22 (1), March 22 (1), 23 (1), 24 (1), 25 (1), 30 (1), April 1 (1), 11 (1), 19 (2), 20 (1). One L. borealis was found in oak hammock No. 1 on April 11, and a D. floridanus was discovered in that area April 3.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1958. Ecological observations on lasiurine bats in Georgia. Journal of Mammalogy, 39: 64-70.

column23: Rabid Seminole bats and red bats have been taken in Georgia and adjacent states, and rabid yellow bats have been taken in Florida. Consideration is being given to the query regarding the questionable role of bats as reservoirs of the disease and agents in transmitting it to other species.

column23: During the period July 5 through September 16, 1954, while collecting bats for a bat rabies survey (Enright et al., 1955), the writer conducted an extensive search for the roosting sites of lasiurine bats in Yolo, Napa, Lake, Sonoma and Marin counties, California...Lasiurus borealis teliotis, western red bat.-On August 9, 500 fig trees were closely inspected in an orchard at Esparto, Yolo County. One immature male red bat was found hanging on the outer side of a leaf, 5 feet above the ground, on the southwest side of a fig tree. The following day an adult female red bat, an immature female and an immature male were discovered at the cemetery at Capay, Yolo County, hanging in close apposition within a leafy overhang on the southern exposure of a China berry tree, at an elevation of 25
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1959. Ecological observations on lasiurine bats in the North Bay area of California. Journal of Mammalogy, 40: 13- 15.

column14: cemetary in Capay, Yolo County, California

column14: Shell Orchard, 1 mi. S Rumsey, Yolo Couny, California
column23: An adult male red bat was found August 12 in an apricot tree in Shell Orchard, 1 mi. S Rumsey, Yolo County, and the following day another adult male red bat was discovered in an apricot tree in Forest Orchard, 1.5 mi. S Rumsey.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1959. Ecological observations on lasiurine bats in the North Bay area of California. Journal of Mammalogy, 40: 13- 15.

column14: Forest Orchard, 1.5 mi. S Rumsey, California
column23: An adult male red bat was found August 12 in an apricot tree in Shell Orchard, 1 mi. S Rumsey, Yolo County, and the following day another adult male red bat was discovered in an apricot tree in Forest Orchard, 1.5 mi. S Rumsey.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1959. Ecological observations on lasiurine bats in the North Bay area of California. Journal of Mammalogy, 40: 13- 15.

column14: Belflower Orchard, 1 mi. S and 2 mi. W Esparto, California
column23: The apricot trees of Belflower Orchard, 1 mi. S and 2 mi. W Esparto, were investigated August 26. An adult male red bat and an immature male were found hanging in separate trees, and a third red bat, which escaped capture, was found in another tree. A cluster of three red bats, hanging in still another tree, escaped by flying, and a group of approximately 15 red bats similarly dispersed when discovered. Thereafter, three adult females, three immature females and three immature males were captured as individuals in separate trees. Another adult male red bat was taken here in an apricot tree September 5. This orchard was investigated on three occasions during the following winter, when no bats were found.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1959. Ecological observations on lasiurine bats in the North Bay area of California. Journal of Mammalogy, 40: 13- 15.

column14: Belflower Orchard, 1 mi. S and 2 mi. W Esparto, California
column23: The apricot trees of Belflower Orchard, 1 mi. S and 2 mi. W Esparto, were investigated August 26. column14: Black Winery, 2 mi. SE Cloverdale, Sonoma County, California
column23: A female red bat was captured while hanging in an overhang produced by the overlapping canopies of two fig trees at Black Winery, 2 mi. SE Cloverdale, Sonoma County, on September 8.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1959. Ecological observations on lasiurine bats in the North Bay area of California. Journal of Mammalogy, 40: 13- 15.

column14: Matsumoto Orchard, about 1 mi. S and 4 mi. W Esparto, California
column23: The Matsumoto Orchard, about 1 mi. S and 4 mi. W Esparto, was visited on March 27, 1955. The previous summer Mr. Matsumoto had related his bat experiences, gained during some 30 years of residence in the area. "In February or March reddish bats appear in the small orange grove just west of the house, selecting the south or southeast sides of trees. Later a somewhat larger and darker bat appears. The bats gradually move out of the orange trees into the nearby apricot trees, as the latter develop leaves. When handled or disturbed the bats fly away but are back the next day. day. The bats fly more readily on warm days. No bats are present in winter."
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1959. Ecological observations on lasiurine bats in the North Bay area of California. Journal of Mammalogy, 40: 13- 15.

column14: Matsumoto Orchard, about 1 mi. S and 4 mi. W Esparto, California

column14: Matsumoto Orchard, about 1 mi. S and 4 mi. W Esparto, California
column23: The eleven orange trees were examined, and three large trees contained red bats. One tree contained two bats, one of which was captured and proved to be a male. The other flew when touched. Both bats were a dark red color, typical of males captured that day and less yellow than the female that was captured later. These two bats were on the south side of the tree, 3 feet apart, hanging at an elevation of 51/2 feet. Another tree contained a female red bat, hanging on the south side of the tree, at an elevation of 81/2 feet. The third tree contained three males, hanging 3 feet apart on the south, southeast and east sides of the tree at elevations of about 5 feet 8 inch
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1959. Ecological observations on lasiurine bats in the North Bay area of California. Journal of Mammalogy, 40: 13- 15.

column14: Belflower Orchard, 1 mi. S and 2 mi. W Esparto, California
column23: The Matsumoto Orchard was again visited April 17, 1955. No bats were found in the orange trees, which were then blossoming and attracting many bees. An examination of 30 nearby apricot trees, now fairly heavily leafed, revealed no bats. Nearby Belflower Orchard was then visited, and 30 apricot trees were examined. One red bat was observed in a heavy clump of leaves, about 35 feet from the ground, on the very top of the tree. The bat was swinging back and forth, 45? from vertical on either side, as wind blew through the leaves
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1959. Ecological observations on lasiurine bats in the North Bay area of California. Journal of Mammalogy, 40: 13- 15.

column14: Brione Orchard, 3 mi. NW Bolinas, California
column23: An adult female hoary bat was discovered hanging to a small branch, 20 feet from the ground, in a leafy overhang produced by the overlapping canopies of two cherry trees in Brione Orchard, 3 mi. NW Bolinas, on September 1. The bat was on the west side of the trees over dark, recently turned earth. The following day an adult male hoary bat was found hanging 15 feet above plowed ground on the rigid, nearly upright limb on the north side of a cherry tree the Martinelli Ranch, about 2 mi. NW Bolinas.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1959. Ecological observations on lasiurine bats in the North Bay area of California. Journal of Mammalogy, 40: 13- 15.

column14: Martinelli Ranch, about 2 mi. NW Bolinas, California
column23: An adult female hoary bat was discovered hanging to a small branch, 20 feet from the ground, in a leafy overhang produced by the overlapping canopies of two cherry trees in Brione Orchard, 3 mi. NW Bolinas, on September 1. The bat was on the west side of the trees over dark, recently turned earth. The following day an adult male hoary bat was found hanging 15 feet above plowed ground on the rigid, nearly upright limb on the north side of a cherry tree the Martinelli Ranch, about 2 mi. NW Bolinas.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1959. Ecological observations on lasiurine bats in the North Bay area of California. Journal of Mammalogy, 40: 13- 15.

column14: country road near Davis, Yolo County, California
column23: At 10:45 AM, March 22, 1955, while driving along a country road near Davis, Yolo County, the author noticed a California jay, Aphelocoma californica, pecking at an object at the side of the road. The object proved to be an female red bat, lying on its back with wings extended and curved upward. The auto was stopped and, as the site was approached, the jay flew and a male Brewer's blackbird, Euphagus cynocephalus, alighted about 2 from the bat. When the writer arrived at the site the blackbird flew away. Leafless walnut trees, containing fairly dense growths of mistletoe, extended over the road at this point. The day was sunny and warm and no wind evident. The bat lived several days in captivity, after which it was killed prepared as a specimen. No obvious external or internal injuries were present. The eastern blue jay was earlier reported (Allan, 1947) attacking
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1959. Ecological observations on lasiurine bats in the North Bay area of California. Journal of Mammalogy, 40: 13- 15.

column23: Collections and observations were made within a mile of Lewis, Cass County, Iowa, in 1960, within a 10-mile radius of Lewis in 1962, and throughout Cass and Pottawattamie counties in 1963. The greatest were invested in 1963, when ages were determined of all bats bats were banded and released...In 1960 only 3 August and the previous evening were spent collecting; little time was available study. Red bats were discovered at 18 roost stations; 20 were 8 escaped. Included were 13 solitary bats and 5 clusters of bats. Solitary were 2 adult males, 7 males of undetermined age, 2 adult females, which escaped capture. Known composition of the 5 clusters is presented Table 1...Red bats and hoary bats almost invariably selected roosts in trees in "edge" areas, i.e., forest edge or wide fencerows, and with equal consistency these sites bordered dense, leafy crops such as corn or beans...The 100 roost stations of red bats found in 1963 offer good examples of species of tree selected: American elm, 41; box elder, 33; wild plum, 10; silver maple, 4; wild black cherry, 3; Chinese elm, 2; mulberry, 1; willow, 1; hackberry, 1; catalpa, 1; hawthorn, 1; sumac, 1; black walnut, 1. Ten of the 100 roosts were of the vine canopy type. Hoary bats demonstrated similar preferences to red bats in trees selected and specific shelter type utilization (Table 2).
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1966. Ecological observations of lasiurine bats in Iowa. Journal of Mammalogy, 47: 34 -41.

Red bats were discovered at 18 roost stations; 20 were 8 escaped. Included were 13 solitary bats and 5 clusters of bats. Solitary were 2 adult males, 7 males of undetermined age, 2 adult females, which escaped capture. Known composition of the 5 clusters is presented Table 1...Red bats and hoary bats almost invariably selected roosts in trees in "edge" areas, i.e., forest edge or wide fencerows, and with equal consistency these sites bordered dense, leafy crops such as corn or beans...The 100 roost stations of red bats found in 1963 offer good examples of species of tree selected: American elm, 41; box elder, 33; wild plum, 10; silver maple, 4; wild black cherry, 3; Chinese elm, 2; mulberry, 1; willow, 1; hackberry, 1; catalpa, 1; hawthorn, 1; sumac, 1; black walnut, 1. Ten of the 100 roosts were of the vine canopy type. Hoary bats demonstrated similar preferences to red bats in trees selected and specific shelter type utilization (Table 2).
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1966. Ecological observations of lasiurine bats in Iowa. Journal of Mammalogy, 47: 34 -41.

column23: Three roosts were noted to be used by different bats on different dates in 1963. The first roost was a vine-infiltrated canopy in a short plum tree, on the north side of a dense, wide fencerow which bordered the south edge of a sorghum crop. An adult female hoary bat was collected here 27 July.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1966. Ecological observations of lasiurine bats in Iowa. Journal of Mammalogy, 47: 34 -41.

column23: Two days later later an adult female red bat was collected here; the following day an adult male red bat was captured in the shelter.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1966. Ecological observations of lasiurine bats in Iowa. Journal of Mammalogy, 47: 34 -41.

column23: Two days later later an adult female red bat was collected here; the following day an adult male red bat was captured in the shelter.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1966. Ecological observations of lasiurine bats in Iowa. Journal of Mammalogy, 47: 34 -41.

column23: The second roost was a dense leafy overhang, 24 ft above ground level on the south side of a silver maple, facing a cornfield. An adult female red bat was captured here 1 August. On 3 August, 4 red bats escaped capture at this site.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1966. Ecological observations of lasiurine bats in Iowa. Journal of Mammalogy, 47: 34 -41.

column23: The second roost was a dense leafy overhang, 24 ft above ground level on the south side of a silver maple, facing a cornfield. An adult female red bat was captured here 1 August. On 3 August, 4 red bats escaped capture at this site.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1966. Ecological observations of lasiurine bats in Iowa. Journal of Mammalogy, 47: 34 -41.

column23: The third roost was situated on the north side of an American elm at an elevation of 10 ft, opposite a cornfield. Three hoary bats, an adult female, an immature male and an immature female, were banded and released here 30 July. This roost by a different immature female hoary bat on 7 August.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1966. Ecological observations of lasiurine bats in Iowa. Journal of Mammalogy, 47: 34 -41.

column23: The third roost was situated on the north side of an American elm at an elevation of 10 ft, opposite a cornfield. Three hoary bats, an adult female, an immature male and an immature female, were banded and released here 30 July. This roost by a different immature female hoary bat on 7 August.
column34: Constantine, D. G. 1966. Ecological observations of lasiurine bats in Iowa. Journal of Mammalogy, 47: 34 -41.

column23: In Samoa, for example, Freycinetia reineckei (Pan- danaceae), a dioecious liana, is pollinated by the flying fox Pteropus samoensis (Cox 1982, 1984, 1990).
column34: Cox, P. A.,. Elmqvist, E. D. Pierson, and W. E. Rainey. 1991. Flying foxes as strong interactors in South Pacific island ecosystems: a conservation hypothesis. Conservation Biology, 5: 448- 454.

column23: In Samoa, for example, Freycinetia reineckei (Pan- danaceae), a dioecious liana, is pollinated by the flying fox Pteropus samoensis (Cox 1982, 1984, 1990).
column34: Cox, P. A.,. Elmqvist, E. D. Pierson, and W. E. Rainey. 1991. Flying foxes as strong interactors in South Pacific island ecosystems: a conservation hypothesis. Conservation Biology, 5: 448- 454.

column23: In Samoa, for example, Freycinetia reineckei (Pan- danaceae), a dioecious liana, is pollinated by the flying fox Pteropus samoensis (Cox 1982, 1984, 1990).
column34: Cox, P. A.,. Elmqvist, E. D. Pierson, and W. E. Rainey. 1991. Flying foxes as strong interactors in South Pacific island ecosystems: a conservation hypothesis. Conservation Biology, 5: 448- 454.

column23: Flying foxes have few natural predators (primarily raptors and snakes), but their limited reproductive ca- pacity makes them vulnerable to unnatural predation (overhunting and introduced predators) and cata- strophic events (e.g., typhoons and epidemics).
column34: Cox, P. A.,. Elmqvist, E. D. Pierson, and W. E. Rainey. 1991. Flying foxes as strong interactors in South Pacific island ecosystems: a conservation hypothesis. Conservation Biology, 5: 448- 454.

column23: Flying foxes have few natural predators (primarily raptors and snakes), but their limited reproductive ca- pacity makes them vulnerable to unnatural predation (overhunting and introduced predators) and cata- strophic events (e.g., typhoons and epidemics).
column34: Cox, P. A.,. Elmqvist, E. D. Pierson, and W. E. Rainey. 1991. Flying foxes as strong interactors in South Pacific island ecosystems: a conservation hypothesis. Conservation Biology, 5: 448- 454.

column23: For example, the pollination ecology of Ceiba pentandra (Bombacaceae) has been studied in West Africa (Baker & Harris 1959), India (van der Pijl 1935), Brazil (Car- valho 1960), Peru (Uanson et al. 1981), and Mexico (To- ledo 1977), where its flowers have been found to be visited by a large suite of insects, birds, nonflying mam- mals, and bats. Analysis of its reproductive ecology in Samoa, where it is an aboriginal introduction (Whistler, in press), revealed a single pollinator, the flying fox Pteropus tonganus (Elmqvist et al., in press).
column34: Cox, P. A.,. Elmqvist, E. D. Pierson, and W. E. Rainey. 1991. Flying foxes as strong interactors in South Pacific island ecosystems: a conservation hypothesis. Conservation Biology, 5: 448- 454.

column23: Unfortunately, today a similar inadvertent experiment involving island pollinators and seed dispersers is occur- ring: the extinction of flying foxes on Pacific islands. These important pollinators and seed dispersers have suffered serious population declines throughout much of their range due primarily to habitat loss and over- hunting, locally exacerbated by typhoons and intro- duced predators (Wodzicki & Felten 1975, 1980; Racey 1979; Cheke & Dahl 1981; Cox 1983a; Carroll 1984; Wiles 1987a,b; Falanruw 1988; Pierson & Rainey, in press).
column27: Wodzicki & Felten 1975, 1980; Racey 1979; Cheke & Dahl 1981; Cox 1983a; Carroll 1984; Wiles 1987a,b; Falanruw 1988; Pierson & Rainey, in press
column34: Cox, P. A.,. Elmqvist, E. D. Pierson, and W. E. Rainey. 1991. Flying foxes as strong interactors in South Pacific island ecosystems: a conservation hypothesis. Conservation Biology, 5: 448- 454.

column23: Unfortunately, today a similar inadvertent experiment involving island pollinators and seed dispersers is occur- ring: the extinction of flying foxes on Pacific islands. These important pollinators and seed dispersers have suffered serious population declines throughout much of their range due primarily to habitat loss and over- hunting, locally exacerbated by typhoons and intro- duced predators (Wodzicki & Felten 1975, 1980; Racey 1979; Cheke & Dahl 1981; Cox 1983a; Carroll 1984; Wiles 1987a,b; Falanruw 1988; Pierson & Rainey, in press).
column27: Wodzicki & Felten 1975, 1980; Racey 1979; Cheke & Dahl 1981; Cox 1983a; Carroll 1984; Wiles 1987a,b; Falanruw 1988; Pierson & Rainey, in press
column34: Cox, P. A.,. Elmqvist, E. D. Pierson, and W. E. Rainey. 1991. Flying foxes as strong interactors in South Pacific island ecosystems: a conservation hypothesis. Conservation Biology, 5: 448- 454.

column23: Between 1975 and 1990, the decline was greatly accelerated by commercial importation of 8000-29,000 frozen flying foxes per year into Guam to supply a lux- ury food market (Wiles & Payne 1986; Wiles in press).
column34: Cox, P. A.,. Elmqvist, E. D. Pierson, and W. E. Rainey. 1991. Flying foxes as strong interactors in South Pacific island ecosystems: a conservation hypothesis. Conservation Biology, 5: 448- 454.

column14: Lac La Biche, Alberta, between 54° and 55° N and 111° and 113°W
column23: We conducted this study in the aspen mixedwood forestto the northwest and northeast of Lac La Biche, Alberta,Canada, between 54° and 55° N and 111° and 113°W...In 1994, to examine day-roost selection, we followed radiotagged bats to their day-roost trees. In 1994 we followed nine female (one pregnant, fourlactating, three nonreproductive, one unknown) M. lucifugusto 16 roost trees, and six female L. noctivagans (two pregnant, one lactating, two post-lactating, and one juvenile)to 11 trees, for a total of 27 roost trees and 28roost entrances...All bats, regardlessof capture location, roosted in old stands (.120 years)of large Populus sp. M. lucifugus used 13 aspen (P.tremuloides), 2 balsam poplar (P. balsamifera), and 1unidentified Populus sp. L. noctivagans used 9 aspenand 2 Populus sp...Two M. lucifugus roosts (of two and fourbats) were under loose bark, both in trees of decay classD3/D4.
column34: Crampton, L. H.,and R. M. R. Barclay. 1998. Selection of roosting and foraging habitat by bats in different-aged aspen mixedwood stands. Conservation Biology, 12: 1347- 1358.

column14: Lac La Biche, Alberta, between 54° and 55° N and 111° and 113°W
column23: We conducted this study in the aspen mixedwood forestto the northwest and northeast of Lac La Biche, Alberta,Canada, between 54° and 55° N and 111° and 113°W...In 1994, to examine day-roost selection, we followed radiotagged bats to their day-roost trees. In 1994 we followed nine female (one pregnant, fourlactating, three nonreproductive, one unknown) M. lucifugusto 16 roost trees, and six female L. noctivagans (two pregnant, one lactating, two post-lactating, and one juvenile)to 11 trees, for a total of 27 roost trees and 28roost entrances...All bats, regardlessof capture location, roosted in old stands (.120 years)of large Populus sp. M. lucifugus used 13 aspen (P.tremuloides), 2 balsam poplar (P. balsamifera), and 1unidentified Populus sp. L. noctivagans used 9 aspenand 2 Populus sp...Two M. lucifugus roosts (of two and fourbats) were under loose bark, both in trees of decay classD3/D4.
column34: Crampton, L. H.,and R. M. R. Barclay. 1998. Selection of roosting and foraging habitat by bats in different-aged aspen mixedwood stands. Conservation Biology, 12: 1347- 1358.

column14: Cueva de Abra, beside the Pan American Highway, extreme southern Tamaulipas
column23: Cueva de Abra is a large cave in a limestone hill beside the Pan American Highway in extreme southern Tamaulipas. Numerous mammalogists have visited the cave (see bibliography) since the senior author first collected specimens there (Dalquest and Hall, 1947). Thousands of free-tailed bats belonging to two otherwise rare species of Tadarida then inhabited the cave, but the population has been greatly reduced, perhaps by rabies (Villa, 1967), and in 1966 we found no Tadarida living in the cave
column34: Dalquest, W.W., and E. Roth. 1970. Late Pleistocene mammals from a cave in Tamaulipas, Mexico. Southwestern Naturalist15:217–230.

column14: Cueva de Abra, beside the Pan American Highway, extreme southern Tamaulipas
column23: Artibeus jamaicensis Leach.-3 jaws, 1 isolated molar (MU 7956). The specimens are of the Jamaican fruit bat, rather than the larger A. lituratus palmarum. Both species occur now in the general vicinity of the cave, and A. jamaicensis was cap- tured in nets set at the mouth of the cave. Both species are here near the northern limits of their ranges.
column34: Dalquest, W.W., and E. Roth. 1970. Late Pleistocene mammals from a cave in Tamaulipas, Mexico. Southwestern Naturalist15:217–230.

column14: Cueva de Abra, beside the Pan American Highway, extreme southern Tamaulipas
column23: Tadarida laticaudata Geoffroy.-144 jaws, many with complete dentition (MU 7959). For a summary of the complicated nomenclatorial history of this free-tailed bat at Cueva de Abra see Jones and Alvarez (1962) and Alvarez and Avina (1964). When the flights of Tadarida were at their height, as in past years, thousands of the bats left the cave mouth in groups and spirals. A dozen or more barn owls would fly from perches nearby and dash through the masses, snatching up any unfortunate bats that chanced to come within range of their claws. Doubtless the fossil jaws came from bats captured in the same fashion
column34: Dalquest, W.W., and E. Roth. 1970. Late Pleistocene mammals from a cave in Tamaulipas, Mexico. Southwestern Naturalist15:217–230.

column14: Cueva de Abra, beside the Pan American Highway, extreme southern Tamaulipas
column23: Tadarida aurispinosa (Peale).-6 jaws (MU 7960). Peale's free-tailed bat is a rare species, first reported from Mexico at Cueva de Abra by Carter and Davis (1961) and since found at several other localities (Villa, 1966). Jaws and teeth of aurispinosa are distinctly larger than those of T. laticaudata or T. femorosaca. T. molossa (Pal- las) has teeth only slightly larger but has jaws and rostrum greatly elongated, with teeth widely spaced, as compared with T. aurispinosa. We have examined several hundred free-tailed bats, taken or found dead at Cueva de Abra. Three of these were aurispinosa and all of the rest were laticaudata. The collection of fossils suggests that aurispinosa has been relatively rare at Cueva de Abra since the late Pleistocene.
column34: Dalquest, W.W., and E. Roth. 1970. Late Pleistocene mammals from a cave in Tamaulipas, Mexico. Southwestern Naturalist15:217–230.

column14: Aeolus Cave, Mt. Aeolus, southwestern Vermont
column23: In 1960-1963 a study was made of the common little brown bat, Myotis l. lucifugus, in New England and eastern New York...Over 73,000 bats were banded, of which about 49,000 were in caves mines and 24,000 in summer colonies in buildings. All but about 2,000 M. lucifugus. A cave on Mt. Aeolus, in southwestern Vermont, and two abandoned iron mines in Essex County, New York, were studied most...Table 2.
column34: Davis, W. H., and H. B. Hitchcock. 1965. Biology and migration of the bat, Myotis lucifugus, in New England. J. Mamm., 46:296-313.

column23: An adult female banded at Aeolus Cave 30 April 1960 was recaptured in a house 5 miles S of Brookfield, Massachusetts, on 3 May 1960.

column23: On 29 April 1961 a house in Middlebury, Vermont, contained an estimated 300 bats. Some may have been transients, for one was later recovered in a maternity colony 40 miles ESE, near Sharon, Vermont.
column34: Davis, W. H., and H. B. Hitchcock. 1965. Biology and migration of the bat, Myotis lucifugus, in New England. J. Mamm., 46:296-313.

column23: Summer colonies were most commonly found in barns and attics of old buildings. If the attic is sufficiently dark and the bats are seldom disturbed, they are usually found clinging to the rafters beneath the ridgepole. Otherwise most of them are found in crevices between boards, around window frames, next to the chimney at roof level, beneath roofing and siding material and in cornices. Mortises in large timbers frequently shelter bats. Bats were also discovered in stacked boards, behind pictures hanging on a wall, between the folds of a mattress hanging in an attic and in the hollow pillars of a porch.
column34: Davis, W. H., and H. B. Hitchcock. 1965. Biology and migration of the bat, Myotis lucifugus, in New England. J. Mamm., 46:296-313.

column23: Adult males, if present, do not appear to cluster with the females. The largest number of males found was 27 (3 yearlings and 24 older ones) South Hero, Vermont, 28 June 1962, where 453 adult bats were handled. colony the adult males were found in crevices beneath the sloping region the roof, whereas the females were clustered atthe peak.
column34: Davis, W. H., and H. B. Hitchcock. 1965. Biology and migration of the bat, Myotis lucifugus, in New England. J. Mamm., 46:296-313.

column23: On 7 July 1962 bats were collected from two buildings near North Montpelier, Vermont. In the attic of one building many young were flying. The other building could not be entered, so a trap was built where the bats exited. Of 158 bats caught, only one was young.
column34: Davis, W. H., and H. B. Hitchcock. 1965. Biology and migration of the bat, Myotis lucifugus, in New England. J. Mamm., 46:296-313.

column23: On 4 July 1961, 808 bats taken from a house at Sunset Lake, Rutland County, Vermont, were banded and released in the yard during the afternoon and evening. Of this number 116 were young females capable of flight. Examination of the colony on 22 June 1962 revealed only one of the banded yearlings, whereas 78 of the 589 adults were retaken. Since juvenile females banded at summer colonies later in the summer were frequently recaptured in the same colony as yearlings, we think that few of the Lake Sunset juveniles banded 4 July found their way back to the roost.
column34: Davis, W. H., and H. B. Hitchcock. 1965. Biology and migration of the bat, Myotis lucifugus, in New England. J. Mamm., 46:296-313.

column23: On 16 September 1961 we found only three bats in a barn in Shoreham, Vermont, that had about 300 the following June.
column34: Davis, W. H., and H. B. Hitchcock. 1965. Biology and migration of the bat, Myotis lucifugus, in New England. J. Mamm., 46:296-313.

column23: All winter recoveries of banded M. lucifugus were investigated, resulting in two records of live bats in buildings in December. One was caught in a house in Newfane, Vermont, 4 December and the other in a dairy barn in West Milton, Vermont, 12 December
column34: Davis, W. H., and H. B. Hitchcock. 1965. Biology and migration of the bat, Myotis lucifugus, in New England. J. Mamm., 46:296-313.

column23: Folk (1940) presented evidence sug- gesting that the population of M. lucifugus in a New York cave does not reach maximum size until midwinter, and Griffin (1940b) found a few that moved from one cave to another during the season for hibernation. We suspect that occasional transients will be found in buildings in the winter
column34: Davis, W. H., and H. B. Hitchcock. 1965. Biology and migration of the bat, Myotis lucifugus, in New England. J. Mamm., 46:296-313.

column23: On 8 July 1960, 54 adult females, 32 juvenile females and 27 juvenile males were taken from a house in Leicester Junction, Vermont, and released in Middlebury, 12 miles to the north. The house was revisited 25 July 1960 and five banded bats recaptured; all were adults. Two of the juvenile females were caught in Middlebury 24 July 1960 and 10 May 1961, respectively. On 24 July 1960 one of the adult females and one of the juvenile females were found in a house about one mile W of the place where they had been caught originally.
column34: Davis, W. H., and H. B. Hitchcock. 1965. Biology and migration of the bat, Myotis lucifugus, in New England. J. Mamm., 46:296-313.

column34: Davis, W. H., and H. B. Hitchcock. 1965. Biology and migration of the bat, Myotis lucifugus, in New England. J. Mamm., 46:296-313.

column14: Near Lake Champlain, Essex County, New York
column23: Fig. 3 shows the dispersal patterns of bats tagged in two mines in Essex County and one in Ulster County, New York. The Essex County mines are 13 miles apart, and although some interchange occurs between them, they draw bats from somewhat different areas. The mine close to Lake Champlain contains the most localized population studied; its bats summer mostly in the Champlain Valley. Of 47 recoveries only three were outside this region- two in the mountains of central Vermont and one in the central Adirondacks. The other mine serves bats in the area westward into the Adirondacks as well as a local population. Stragglers outside this pattern were found at North Waterford, Maine, Royalton, Vermont, and Kingston, Ontario. These were males, taken from the mine in May and June and released in Middlebury, 25 miles E
column34: Davis, W. H., and H. B. Hitchcock. 1965. Biology and migration of the bat, Myotis lucifugus, in New England. J. Mamm., 46:296-313.

column23: We were unable to confirm the report of Gifford and Gifford (1960) that bats from a mine at Chester, in western Massachusetts, summer in south- eastern Massachusettes. Massachusetts. They reported banding 26 females at the mine 28 September 1957 and retaking 11 of them in a colony in Dartmouth, Massachusetts, the following June. In January 1962 we visited the Chester mine after banding 12,000 bats in buildings the previous summer, including 381 from Dartmouth, where Gifford and Griffin had worked. Among approxi- mately 4,000 M. lucifugus observed we found none banded. However, 12 bats are known to have moved from the Dartmouth colonies to Aeolus Cave
column34: Davis, W. H., and H. B. Hitchcock. 1965. Biology and migration of the bat, Myotis lucifugus, in New England. J. Mamm., 46:296-313.

column14: Approximately 7 km to the north andwest is Barmah Forest, Northern Plains extending fromthe inland side of the Great Dividing Range tothe Murray River, Victoria
column23: The Northern Plains is a natural physiographicregion in northern Victoria that extends fromthe inland side of the Great Dividing Range tothe Murray River (Fig. 1), forming the VictorianRiverina bioregion (Thackway & Cresswell 1995)...This research was based near Picola, north-east ofEchuca, an area used primarily for sheep and wheatfarming, in which remnant vegetation is restrictedto roadsides and small (i.e. < 10 ha) blocks withinpaddocks. Approximately 7 km to the north andwest is Barmah Forest, an extensive floodplainwoodland (29,000 ha) of River Red Gum adjacentto the Murray River. Miniature radio transmitterswere temporarily attached to 45 individual LesserLong-eared Bats and 27 Gould’s Wattled Bats.Individuals were trapped at night while they foragedin remnant woodland amongst farmland and then, during the day, they were tracked back to their roostsites, generally in hollow-bearing trees...Gould’s Wattled Batsfavoured large, old, live River Red Gums with amean diameter of 120 cm. Trees of this size are rare,and were significantly larger than trees in thesurrounding area. Roost sites were usually in a deadspout with an opening approximately 9 cm in width(Fig. 6).
column34: Balancing Conservation and Production in Grassy Landscapes: Proceedings of the Bushcare Grassy Landscapes Conference, Clare, South Australia, 19- 21 August 1999

column23: For the Lesser Long-eared Bat, males andfemales showed marked differences in the types ofroost they used. This species had previously beenreported roosting in structures of human origin(e.g. sheds, hanging material, fence posts)(Churchill 1998), however, during this study onlymales roosted in these situations. All roosts used byfemales were in trees, either under exfoliating barkor in hollows.
column34: Balancing Conservation and Production in Grassy Landscapes: Proceedings of the Bushcare Grassy Landscapes Conference, Clare, South Australia, 19- 21 August 1999

column14: Approximately 7 km to the north andwest is Barmah Forest, Northern Plains extending fromthe inland side of the Great Dividing Range tothe Murray River, Victoria
column23: Maternity roosts, where females givebirth to their young, were very specialized—thesewere located in large old ring-barked River Red Gums (Fig. 7). The roost entrances were narrowcracks in the main trunk (approximately 2.5 cmwide), which presumably opened into a largerchamber capable of housing up to 40 individuals. While the roosts of Gould’sWattled Bats werepredominantly in live trees, roosts used by LesserLong-eared Bats were mainly in dead trees androosting areas were located in parts of the forestin which there were high densities of dead trees.
column34: Balancing Conservation and Production in Grassy Landscapes: Proceedings of the Bushcare Grassy Landscapes Conference, Clare, South Australia, 19- 21 August 1999

column14: Approximately 7 km to the north andwest is Barmah Forest, Northern Plains extending fromthe inland side of the Great Dividing Range tothe Murray River, Victoria
column23: Individuals of both species shifted roosts on aregular basis, moving to a new roost every 1-2 days.Subsequent roosts were mostly within 300 m of theprevious roost. Bats were faithful to a general roostarea, but regularly moved roost sites within thatarea. This has implications for the number of roostsneeded to support an individual or a colony of bats,with possibly as many as 20 or 30 suitable roosttrees required in the one area.
column34: Balancing Conservation and Production in Grassy Landscapes: Proceedings of the Bushcare Grassy Landscapes Conference, Clare, South Australia, 19- 21 August 1999

column14: Approximately 7 km to the north andwest is Barmah Forest, Northern Plains extending fromthe inland side of the Great Dividing Range tothe Murray River, Victoria
column23: More than 1500 individuals of 13 species ofinsectivorous bats were caught during this study(Table 1). Together, these species comprise 45%of the extant mammalian fauna of the region.The most common species were Gould’sWattledBat (Chalinolobus gouldii), ChocolateWattled Bat(C. morio), Lesser Long-eared Bat (Nyctophilus geoffroyi)and Little Forest Bat (Vespadelus vulturnus),which together accounted for 60% of captures...Table 1...All species of insectivorous bats in the NorthernPlains use tree hollows or crevices for roost sites,which most frequently occur in large trees.
column34: Balancing Conservation and Production in Grassy Landscapes: Proceedings of the Bushcare Grassy Landscapes Conference, Clare, South Australia, 19- 21 August 1999

column23: The species is mostly found in dry to wet lowland forests and prefers to roost inside old mines, cracks, culverts, crevices in old buildings, caves, among large boulders, overhanging ledges, tunnels, dungeons, forts, temples and churches (Bates & Harrison 1997); sometimes co-roosting with other bat species (Flannery 1995; Payne et al. 2005).

column14: Bonai Forest Division in Sundergarh District, western Odisha (21045’39.43”N & 85006’50.01”E) at the base of Khandadhar Waterfall at an elevation of 408m
column23: On 18 February 2012, while surveying the fauna of Bonai Forest Division in Sundergarh District, western Odisha, we observed a single individual of the species in a cave (21045’39.43”N & 85006’50.01”E) at the base ofKhandadhar Waterfall at an elevation of 408m (Fig. 1).

column14: Koraput District, southern Odisha (18049’15.42”N & 82010’0.21”E; elevation457m) at Gupteswar, Eastern Ghat hill range extensions in Odisha adjoining Kanger Valley National Park of the neighbouring state Chhatisgarh.
column23: During another occasion on 28October 2014, while surveying bats in Koraput District,southern Odisha, we observed this species in a limestone cave (18049’15.42”N & 82010’0.21”E; elevation457m) at Gupteswar co-roosting with Hipposiderosater at a height of 3m from ground (Fig. 1). Gupteswarlies within the Eastern Ghat hill range extensions inOdisha adjoining Kanger Valley National Park of theneighbouring state Chhatisgarh.

column23: The winter distribution of Myotis grisescensis restricted to relatively cold, humid caves in areas characterizedby limestone karst at latitudes < 39°N (Fig. 3; Tuttle, 1975).

column23: The most northern summer colony (400 gray bats)was found in an abandoned limestone quarry in Clark Co., southernIndiana (Brack et al., 1984).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: The most western occurrence of gray bats was a summer maternity colony found ina storm sewer in extreme southeastern Kansas (Choate and Decher,1995; Grigsby, 1965; Hays and Bingman, 1964; Long, 1961).

column23: Fetal development takes place throughout April andMay. Parturition coincides with the return to maternity caves attimes ranging from early May (Florida-Rice, 1955) until late June(Kansas and Missouri-Barker, 1986; Guthrie, 1933b), probablydepending on weather conditions during the year.
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Equally important for growth ratesare heat retention properties of caves, such as pockets, small chambers,and surface porosity of the cave ceiling, which enables youngto cluster more densely and conserve heat (Tuttle, 1975).

column23: During the first 20 to 30 days of flight young demonstrate little movement between caves(Tuttle, 197 6b).

column23: For hibernation, M. grisescens selects the coldest caves of allMyotis species found in its range (Tuttle, 1975).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Mean temperatures in three hibernation cavesin Tennessee and Alabama ranged from 6.7° to 10.0°C (Tuttle,1976a).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Mean temperatures in three hibernation cavesin Tennessee and Alabama ranged from 6.7° to 10.0°C (Tuttle,1976a).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: As a summer habitat, this species chooses,much warmer cavesand mines that usually are located < 1-2 km from rivers or otherbodies of water (Tuttle, 1976b).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Mean temperatures, measured 3 cm below the ceiling near maternity roosts, ranged from 13.9° to26.3OC in six caves in Alabama and Tennessee. Mean relative humidityin the same caves ranged from 86% to 99% (Tuttle, 1976a).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Mean temperatures, measured 3 cm below the ceiling near maternity roosts, ranged from 13.9° to26.3OC in six caves in Alabama and Tennessee. Mean relative humidityin the same caves ranged from 86% to 99% (Tuttle, 1976a).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Maternity roosts often are found in high places onnearly horizontal or domed ceilings with surfaces of porous limestone.Heat-trapping in domes is microclimatically advantageous to growthrates of juvenile bats. Ceilings used by clusters of gray bats appeardarkly stained by urine and abraded by the claws of bats. In onecave in Alabama, clustered bats pulled out pieces resulting "innumerous pockets where juveniles aggregated in exceptionally denseclusters (Tuttle, 1975:4)."
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: In Arkansas, females choose maternitysites in highly vaulted ceilings above the cave entrance (Saugey,1978).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Every year, gray bats disperse from a few hibernatingcaves to widely distributed summer caves (LaVal and LaVal,1980).

column23: Gray bats from a hibernation cave in Kentucky movedseasonally to 10 caves in Kentucky, Illinois, and Tennessee, coveringan area of 16,905 km2 and involving a maximum movement ofmore than 164 km (Hall and Wilson, 1966).

column23: In another study, the average one-way migration distance was 200 km. Maximum migrationdistances measured were 640 km to an abandoned mine in LaSalle Co., Illinois (Elder and Gunier, 1978), and 775 km betweena hibernaculum in northern Tennessee and a summer roost in Florida(Tuttle, 197 6a).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: In Kentucky and Missouri, male and female gray bats arrive separately in summer caves fromlate March to late April (Guthrie, 1933a; Hall and Wilson, 1966).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: In Kentucky and Missouri, male and female gray bats arrive separately in summer caves fromlate March to late April (Guthrie, 1933a; Hall and Wilson, 1966).

column23: Bachelor caves are used by adult males and yearlings andare 1-35 km away from the maternity caves. Females and juvenilesjoin males in July and August, causing sex ratios to become moreeven (Tuttle, 1976a). The females were relatively sedentary atmaternity caves, whereas males moved among caves as far as 30km apart in the vicinity of maternity caves (Tuttle, 1976a).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: At Marvel Cave, southwestern Missouri, 311 bats returned from 14nursery colonies spread over an area of 126,000 km2 (Elder andGunier, 1978).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Numerous smaller roosts, and especially nursery caves, remain threatened, but protectivemeasures proved successful for many larger hibernacula. Forexample, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service acquired theimportant nursery caves BlowingWind Cave and Cave Springs Cave,Alabama, and one of the three most important hibernacula, NewFern Cave, Alabama (Tuttle, 1986).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: With assistance from Bat ConservationInternational, The Nature Conservancy acquired HubbardsCave, Tennessee and Judges Cave, Florida (Tuttle, 1985, 1986).The former is the second most important hibernaculum, which hasbeen secured with the largest cave-entrance gate in the world (Tuttle,1985), and the latter houses the most important remaining nurserycolony in Florida (Tuttle, 1986).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: The third most important hibernaculum(James Cave, southwestern Kentucky), doubled in size overthe last two decades from approximately 100,000 gray bats becauseof continued cave entrance protection (Bat Conservation International,1993).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Following human disturbance and vandalism, a large(~250,000 bats) maternity colony at Hambrick Cave, Alabama,had disappeared by 1973 (identified as cave 50 in Stevenson andTuttle, 1981), but has been reestablished through protective effortssince 1977 (Tuttle, 1986, and pers. comm.).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: As a result of recent conservation efforts, Blowing Wind Cave, Alabama, and NickajackCave, Tennessee, are accessible to visitors between May and Septemberto watch the dusk emergence of 500,000 and 125,000 graybats, respectively (Tuttle, 1986).

column23: Bats migrating between Florida and a hibernating cave in northern Alabamawere found flying directly between rivers but also deviatingfrom the shortest possible pathway in order to stay near caves (Tuttle,1976a).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: A wounded, hand-held female emittedcries that attracted several dozen other individuals at a cave entrance(Guthrie, 1933a).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Myotis grisescens is one of the few bats that roosts in cavesin both winter and summer. Inside hibernacula in Arkansas, graybats were associated with clusters of M. sodalis (Sealander andYoung, 1955), as they were in a hibernaculum in Shannon Co.,Missouri, ". . . where groups of M. sodalis were covered with M.grisescens" (Myers, 1964:80). In Florida, gray bats associated withPipistrellus subflavus in the fall and with M. austroriparius in thesummer (Lee, 1976; Tuttle 197 6a).

column23: The gray bat's main prey consists of several genera and atleast six species of mayflies (Ephemeroptera: Ephemeridae) and otheraquatic insects (Tuttle, 1976b).

column23: Thus, analysis of 100 fecal pellets from beneath amaternity roost revealed a diet consisting of 34.2% Diptera, 43.3%Coleoptera, 17.5% Lepidoptera, and 0.8% Homoptera and Trichoptera,and only 1.6% Hemiptera and Ephemeroptera. Dipteraconsisted mainly of the family Chironomidae and Coleoptera of thefamilies Platypodidae, Carabidae, and Scarabaeidae. However, theseresults were not confirmed by nocturnal observations revealing thatgray bats selected foraging areas where mayflies were exceptionallyabundant (Rabinowitz and Tuttle, 1982).

column23: A study of bats over the Meramec River in eastern Missouri suggested that M. grisescenscompetitively excludes M. sodalis from the river area, forcing M.sodalis to forage away from water (LaVal et al., 1977).

column23: Rabies virus is known to occur in M. grisescens (Constantine,1979).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Dieldrin-induced mortality, resulting from routine insecticideusage, is believed to have led to the poisoning of M. grisescensbeneath two maternity roosts in Missouri (Clark et aI., 1978).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: The elimination of mayflies (Ephemeroptera) in areas of their formerhabitat through aquatic pollution may have a disastrous effect onpredators like the gray bat (Tuttle, 1979a).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Pesticide concentration during lactation led to a 30-fold increase of residue levels in graybat milk, compared to residue levels in the insects. Gray bats werelethally poisoned by these chemicals at caves in Missouri and Alabama(Clark et aI., 1981; 1983a; 1983b).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Pesticide concentration during lactation led to a 30-fold increase of residue levels in graybat milk, compared to residue levels in the insects. Gray bats werelethally poisoned by these chemicals at caves in Missouri and Alabama(Clark et aI., 1981; 1983a; 1983b).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Repeated sampling of dead gray bats, guano, and insects in threecounties in Missouri in 1988 and 1989 revealed a lower but continuedexposure to residues of chlorinated hydrocarbon pesticidesstill remaining in the food chain (Clawson, 1991).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Metal pollution from a battery salvage plant in Jackson Co., Florida, was not harmfulto the gray bat population (Clark et aI., 1986), but cadmium incombination with DDD and DDE may have caused gray bat mortalityat Cave Springs Cave, Alabama (Clark, 1988).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column14: Alabama, Arkansas, Kentucky, Missouri and Tennessee
column23: During winter 1982, it was estimated that nine hibernacula in Alabama,Arkansas, Kentucky, Missouri and Tennessee contained roughly95% (1,575,000 bats) of the estimated total gray bat population(Brady et aI., 1982). Reasons for the decline are human disturbanceand vandalism as well as large-scale habitat destruction and pollution(Clark et aI., 1978; Tuttle, 1979a).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column14: Alabama, Arkansas, Kentucky, Missouri and Tennessee
column23: During winter 1982, it was estimated that nine hibernacula in Alabama,Arkansas, Kentucky, Missouri and Tennessee contained roughly95% (1,575,000 bats) of the estimated total gray bat population(Brady et aI., 1982). Reasons for the decline are human disturbanceand vandalism as well as large-scale habitat destruction and pollution(Clark et aI., 1978; Tuttle, 1979a).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: For example, the deaths of several thousand gray bats, including 154 banded individuals, werecaused by burning debris after construction work at Marvel Cave,Missouri, in 1971 (Mohr, 1972).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Following human disturbance and vandalism, a large(~250,000 bats) maternity colony at Hambrick Cave, Alabama,had disappeared by 1973 (identified as cave 50 in Stevenson andTuttle, 1981), but has been reestablished through protective effortssince 1977 (Tuttle, 1986, and pers. comm.).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column23: Gray bat guano was mined for the production of nitrates forgunpowder during the Civil War at Hubbards Cave, Tennessee(Tuttle, 1985).
column34: Decher, J.; Choate, J.R. Myotis grisescens. Mamm. Species 1995, 510, 1-7

column14: Meu Rei Cave in Catimbau National Park, Pernambuco
column23: Our literature survey yielded 81 records of N. macrourus inBrazil (Fig. 1; Supplementary Table S1). We added new recordsfor the north-eastern state of Pernambuco, obtainedfrom captures made during a bat inventory in the cave MeuRei in Catimbau National Park (62,292ha), which is locatedwithin the Caatinga biome (ICMBio, 2015). The cave is withina sandstone formation, with a horizontal length of 162 m(Azevedo & Bernard,2015). It harbours a bat communitythat includes at least seven other species of two families(Phyllostomidae: Diphylla ecaudata, Carollia perspicillata,Glossophaga soricina, Anoura geoffroyi, Lonchorhina aurita,Tonatia bidens; and Mormoopidae: Pteronotus gymnonotus),which at certain times can surpass 120,000 individuals, mostof them P. gymnonotus.
column34: Delgado-Jaramillo M, Barbier E, Bernard E. New records, potential distribution, and conservation of the Near Threatened cave bat Natalus macrourus in Brazil. Oryx. 2018 Jul 1;52(3):579.

column14: 11 miles frm Meu Rei Cave in Catimbau National Park
column23: All the other bats were released at the site of capture.We recorded another individual of N. macrourus on 14May 2015 during a visit to another cave 11 km away, outsidethe limits of Catimbau National Park.

Species of the genus Natalus are consideredto be dependent on caves for roosting (Taddei & Uieda,2001; Tejedor et al., 2004; Tejedor & Davalos, 2016), andour analysis confirms this strong association.

Considering the high potential occurrence ofcaves in north-eastern Brazil (Jansen et al., 2012), and consideringthat at least three (N. macrourus, L. aurita andFuripterus horrens) of the six threatened bat species inBrazil are frequent or exclusive cave users, caves in northeasternBrazil are a priority for bat inventories so that roostsused by Natalus or any other threatened bat species can beidentified and proposed for full protection.

column14: Meu Rei Cave in Catimbau National Park, Pernambuco
column23: Our literature survey yielded 81 records of N. macrourus inBrazil (Fig. 1; Supplementary Table S1). We added new recordsfor the north-eastern state of Pernambuco, obtainedfrom captures made during a bat inventory in the cave MeuRei in Catimbau National Park (62,292ha), which is locatedwithin the Caatinga biome (ICMBio, 2015). The cave is withina sandstone formation, with a horizontal length of 162 m(Azevedo & Bernard,2015). It harbours a bat communitythat includes at least seven other species of two families(Phyllostomidae: Diphylla ecaudata, Carollia perspicillata,Glossophaga soricina, Anoura geoffroyi, Lonchorhina aurita,Tonatia bidens; and Mormoopidae: Pteronotus gymnonotus),which at certain times can surpass 120,000 individuals, mostof them P. gymnonotus.
column34: Delgado-Jaramillo M, Barbier E, Bernard E. New records, potential distribution, and conservation of the Near Threatened cave bat Natalus macrourus in Brazil. Oryx. 2018 Jul 1;52(3):579.

column23: Approximately 30% of the area of potential distributionof N. macrourus is located in north-eastern Brazil, where44% of the caves are in human-modified areas. We estimatethat N. macrourus has already lost 50% of its natural habitatin north-eastern Brazil, and up to 65% in areas of highestenvironmental suitability in the eastern part of the region,where human population growth is higher.
column34: Delgado-Jaramillo M, Barbier E, Bernard E. New records, potential distribution, and conservation of the Near Threatened cave bat Natalus macrourus in Brazil. Oryx. 2018 Jul 1;52(3):579.

column23: Hence, a scenario in which low roostprotection is combined with other threats, such as miningand habitat loss, degradation and fragmentation, could extitrpatesome populations locally (Tejedor,2011).
column34: Delgado-Jaramillo M, Barbier E, Bernard E. New records, potential distribution, and conservation of the Near Threatened cave bat Natalus macrourus in Brazil. Oryx. 2018 Jul 1;52(3):579.

column14: Muierilor Cave, (45°10'N, 23°46'E) is situated in theGetic Depression of Oltenia on the right slope of theGalben Gorges, 2 km North from Baia de Fier villageat the relative altitude of 40 m, Southern Carpathians
column23: The first observations of batsinhabiting Muierilor Cave were made in1930 by Chappuis and Winkler (Chappuis &Jeannel 1951, Borda et al. 2006) (P. Muierilor(GJ) 1930.05.25., one male leg. Chappuis &Winkler, in ISERC no. 1380) and in 1951 byDumitrescu et al. (1962-1963b). The cave was repeatedly visited over the next sevenyears, but observations regarding the batfauna were made only during spring andsummer seasons. For this period, theauthors recorded the presence of four batspecies: Rhinolophus ferrumequinum, R.hipposideros, Myotis myotis/oxygnathus andMiniopterus schreibersii. After that, the cave came to bat researcher’s attention only in1974, when Bazilescu started a systematicalresearch of the bat fauna from Oltenia(Bazilescu 1974). Unfortunately, these datacannot be used for quantitative comparisonsas they are incomplete.
column34: Dragu A. Species structure of the bat community hibernating in Muierilor Cave (Southern Carpathians, Romania). North-Western Journal of Zoology. 2009 Dec 1;5(2):281-9.

Chappuis &Winkler, in ISERC no. 1380) and in 1951 byDumitrescu et al. (1962-1963b). For this period, theauthors recorded the presence of four batspecies: Rhinolophus ferrumequinum, R.hipposideros, Myotis myotis/oxygnathus andMiniopterus schreibersii. After that, the cave came to bat researcher’s attention only in1974, when Bazilescu started a systematicalresearch of the bat fauna from Oltenia(Bazilescu 1974). Unfortunately, these datacannot be used for quantitative comparisonsas they are incomplete.
column34: Dragu A. Species structure of the bat community hibernating in Muierilor Cave (Southern Carpathians, Romania). North-Western Journal of Zoology. 2009 Dec 1;5(2):281-9.

column23: The first observations of batsinhabiting Muierilor Cave were made in1930 by Chappuis and Winkler (Chappuis &Jeannel 1951, Borda et al. 2006) (P. Muierilor(GJ) 1930.05.25., one male leg. Chappuis &Winkler, in ISERC no. 1380) and in 1951 byDumitrescu et al. (1962-1963b). The cave was repeatedly visited over the next sevenyears, but observations regarding the batfauna were made only during spring andsummer seasons. For this period, theauthors recorded the presence of four batspecies: Rhinolophus ferrumequinum, R.hipposideros, Myotis myotis/oxygnathus andMiniopterus schreibersii. After that, the cave came to bat researcher’s attention only in1974, when Bazilescu started a systematicalresearch of the bat fauna from Oltenia(Bazilescu 1974). Unfortunately, these datacannot be used for quantitative comparisonsas they are incomplete.
column34: Dragu A. Species structure of the bat community hibernating in Muierilor Cave (Southern Carpathians, Romania). North-Western Journal of Zoology. 2009 Dec 1;5(2):281-9.

column23: The cave was visited four timesin the winter season 2004/2005 (in November 2004,and January, February and April 2005), once in 2006(February) and three times in the winter season2007/2008 (November 2007, and December andFebruary 2008)...During the eight visits conducted atMuierilor Cave between 2004 and 2008 wefound six bat species (Table 1): greater horseshoebat (Rhinolophus ferrumequinum),lesser horseshoe bat (R. hipposideros), greatermouse eared bat/lesser mouse eared bat(Myotis myotis/oxygnathus), Geoffroy's bat(Myotis emarginatus), Daubenton’s bat(Myotis daubentonii) and Schreiber’s bat(Miniopterus schreibersii).

column23: In the caves from the North-WesternRomania, the greater horseshoe bat wasfound hibernating at temperatures varyingbetween 8.5ºC and 9.6ºC and sometimes even at 3.6ºC (Szodoray-Parádi & Szántó1998).
column34: Dragu A. Species structure of the bat community hibernating in Muierilor Cave (Southern Carpathians, Romania). North-Western Journal of Zoology. 2009 Dec 1;5(2):281-9.

column23: According to Zukal et al. (2005), R.hipposideros prefers portions of the caveswith very stable microclimatic conditions,the optimum temperature oscillating from2°C to 14°C (Roer & Schober 2001).
column34: Dragu A. Species structure of the bat community hibernating in Muierilor Cave (Southern Carpathians, Romania). North-Western Journal of Zoology. 2009 Dec 1;5(2):281-9.

column23: The study of some Romanian caves show thatM. myotis/oxygnathus can hibernate at temperaturesranging from –2ºC to 9.5ºC (Dumitrescuet al. 1962-1963a, Borda et al 2004).
column34: Dragu A. Species structure of the bat community hibernating in Muierilor Cave (Southern Carpathians, Romania). North-Western Journal of Zoology. 2009 Dec 1;5(2):281-9.

column23: The study of some Romanian caves show thatM. myotis/oxygnathus can hibernate at temperaturesranging from –2ºC to 9.5ºC (Dumitrescuet al. 1962-1963a, Borda et al 2004).

column23: Before our investigations, the presence of M. schreibersiiin Muierilor Cave was mentionedonly for the maternity period...Nevertheless, today thereis little sign of the large nursery colonymentioned in the literature from the 1950’sand 70’s. It is plausible that the disappearanceof this colony was caused by humandisturbance during the visits that are morefrequent in the summer and, therefore, theanthropogenic impact cannot be ignored interms of noise, heat and light.
column34: Dragu A. Species structure of the bat community hibernating in Muierilor Cave (Southern Carpathians, Romania). North-Western Journal of Zoology. 2009 Dec 1;5(2):281-9.

column23: Grey-headed flying-foxes, Pteropus poliocephalus, occur along the east coast of Australiafrom Rockhampton to Bass Strait (Fig. 1), roosting communally by day in camps thatfluctuate in size but may contain over 200 000 individuals. They appear to be obligatefrugivores and nectarivores, feeding primarily on tree species from various forest types. Studies of their feeding ecology have identified blossoms of Myrtaceae (especially species ofEucalyptus) and Proteaceae as their predominant pollen and nectar source (McWilliam 1986,Parry-Jones 1987).
column34: Eby, P. 1991. Seasonal movements of grey-headed flying foxes, Pteropus poliocephalus (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae), from two maternity camps in northern New South Wales. Wildlife Research, 18: 547- 559.

He also identified a range of species that fruited in all months, especiallyspecies of Ficus and Solanum. Both genera are important food sources for Pteropus inAustralia (McWilliam 1986; Parry-Jones 1987; Richards 1990). column23: Although Pteropus are most commonly associated with frugivory, native blossoms arean important component of the diet of P. poliocephalus. The sclerophyll forests aroundGrafton provided a nectar and pollen resource from various species of Myrtaceae duringJanuary and February, as evidenced by records from apiarists.
column34: Eby, P. 1991. Seasonal movements of grey-headed flying foxes, Pteropus poliocephalus (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae), from two maternity camps in northern New South Wales. Wildlife Research, 18: 547- 559.

column23: E. maculata is distributed throughout eastern Australia from approximately 25° to 38°S.and may occur in almost pure stands (Boland et al. 1984). Flowering occurs sequentiallyfrom north to south, and intensive flowering in discrete areas occurs every 4-10 years(Clemson 1985), persisting for as long as six months (M. Gill, CSIRO, unpublished data).Blossoms produce heavy crops of pollen and continuous supplies of nectar (Clemson 1985)and pollen analyses show crude protein levels of 24-7-27-3% (20% being considered a goodprotein source for A. mellifera) (Stace and Baigent 1988). In years of intensive flowering,E. maculata therefore produces a consistent energy and protein source over many weeks.Blossom of this species have been identified as an important food source for Pteropus,in northern N.S.W. by McWilliam (1986), and Parry-Jones (1987) who associated highnumbers of P. poliocephalus in south-coast camps with an intensive flowering in 1985.
column34: Eby, P. 1991. Seasonal movements of grey-headed flying foxes, Pteropus poliocephalus (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae), from two maternity camps in northern New South Wales. Wildlife Research, 18: 547- 559.

column23: The P. poliocephalus population, therefore, is vulnerable to further destruction of habitatand reduction of diversity and abundance of tree species throughout their range. Movementsof 65 km north from Currie Park would take animals into Qld where they may be culledwithout regulation. As a large portion of the P. poliocephalus population may be a singlebreeding population, management strategies for the species should be revised to be consistentthroughout their range. Further, their potential importance as pollinators of Eucalyptusspecies, capable of responding to the unpredictable flowering phenology of this genus,should be acknowledged and incorporated into management strategies.
column34: Eby, P. 1991. Seasonal movements of grey-headed flying foxes, Pteropus poliocephalus (Chiroptera: Pteropodidae), from two maternity camps in northern New South Wales. Wildlife Research, 18: 547- 559.

column23: Grey-headed Flying-foxes are highly colonialand roost conspicuously in the branches ofcanopy trees. The species shares its campswith two other Pteropus, the Black FlyingfoxP alecto and the Little Red Flying-foxI? scapulatus, in areas where their distributionsoverlap (Webb and Tidemann 1995)...Although Pteropus species share camps, theygenerally segregate within them (Ratcliffe1932).

column23: Grey-headed Flying-foxes Pteropus poliocephalusare large (600-900 g), nectarivorous andfrugivorous bats which are endemic to easternAustralia (Tidemann 1995). They feed incanopy vegetation and have a diverse dietcomprising 54 species of flowers, primarilyfrom Eucalyptus and related genera and48 species of fruit produced in subtropicalrainforest (Parry-Jones and Augee 1991; Eby1995, 1996).
column34: Eby, P., G. Richards, L. Collins, and K. Parry-Jones. 1999. The distribution, abundance and vulnerability to population reduction of the grey-headed flying fox Pteropus poliocephalus in New South Wales. Australian Zoologist, 31: 240- 253.

column23: Grey-headed Flying-foxes are affected by anumber of threatening processes throughouttheir range and are particularly vulnerableto loss or modification of foraging habitatand to culling by humans, which primarilyaffects pregnant and lactating females (Eby1995; Tidemaun et a l . 1997; Richards andHall 1998).

column23: A decline in the New South Wales population hasbeen inferred from changes in the sizes andfrequencies of current camps relative toaccounts from earlier this century (Lunney andMoon 1997). These changes have beenattributed to the cumulative impact of habitatloss, shooting and increasing competition fordiminishing resources from Black Flying-foxes(Ratcliffe 1932; Lunney and Leary 1988; Eby1995; Webb and T~demann 1995; Tidemannet al. 1997).

column23: I HAVE read with much interest the remarks of Dr. S. Archerin NATURE, val. xv. p. 313, on the habits of Ryttchonyctl!risnaso, Wied. ( = Proboscidea saxatilis et 1-ivalis, Spix. ), as theyquite agree with notes on the same species made by me whentravelling some years ago in British Guiana...Of one of the two first-namedspec:es, Mr. Swinhoe remarks :-"A species of alliedto K. picta and K . .formosa, was brought to me by a native.The body of this bat was of an orange brown ; but the wingswere painted with orange-yellow and black. It was caught,suspended head downwards, on a cluster of the round fruit of theLongan-tree (Nephelium longanum). Now this tree is an evergreen; and all the year through some portion of its foliage isundergoing decay, the particular leaves being, in such a stage,partially orange and black. This bat can, therefore, at allseasons, suspend from its branches, and elude its enemies by itsresemblar.ce to the leaf of the tree. It was in Augu$t when thisspecimen was brought to me.
column34: Dobson, G. E. 1877. Protective mimicry among bats. Nature, 15: 354.

column23: A familiar instance of what appears to be "protectivemimicry " occurs in the species of the genus Pteropus (Flyingfoxesof European residents in India). These, the largest of allbats, measuring, on an average, nearly one foot in length with anexpanse of wing of from four to five feet, are, from their largesize, very conspicuous objects even when the wings are closed,and easily seen from the ground when hanging from lofty trees.
column34: Dobson, G. E. 1877. Protective mimicry among bats. Nature, 15: 354.

column23: At first sight it might appear that this remarkable contrast of colours wouldrender the animal more conspicuous to passing enemies, and consequentlymore subject to their attacks when hanging in a semi·torpid condition. But any one who has seen a colony of thesebats suspended from the branches of a banyan tree, or from asilk cotton tree (Erwdmdron orientale), must have been struckwith their resemblance to large ripe fruits, and this is especiallynoticeable when they hang in clusters from the leaf-stalks of thecocoa-nut palm, where they may be easily mistaken for a bunchof ripe cocoa-nuts.
column34: Dobson, G. E. 1877. Protective mimicry among bats. Nature, 15: 354.

column23: The much smaller species of Cynopterus and Macroglossus,which feed on the fruit of guavas, ·plantains, and mangoes, resemblethese fruits closely in the yellow colour of their fur and intheir size, so that it is very difficult to detect one of these batswhen suspended among the leaves of any of these trees.

column23: The short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx Vahl, 1797 roosts alone or in small groups in so-called 'tents' created from modified foliage, modified flower and fruit clusters (Bhat & Kunz 1995) and modified mast trees and vines (Balasingh et al. 1993, 1995), as well as beneath living and dead palm fronds and sometimes in buildings (Bhat & Kunz 1995).
column34: Elangovan, V., G. Marimuthu, and. H. Kunz. 1999. Temporal patterns of individual and group foraging behaviour in the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx, in south India. Journal of Tropical Ecology, 15: 681- 687.
