column23: C. sphinx visits fruit-bearing plants which have both 'steady state' (production of a small number of fruits over an extended time period, e.g. PolyalthIa long folia) and 'big-bang' (production of a large number of fruits over a short period, e.g. Ficus religiosa) phenological patterns (Gentry 1974).
column34: Elangovan, V., G. Marimuthu, and. H. Kunz. 1999. Temporal patterns of individual and group foraging behaviour in the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx, in south India. Journal of Tropical Ecology, 15: 681- 687.

column23: C. sphinx visits fruit-bearing plants which have both 'steady state' (production of a small number of fruits over an extended time period, e.g. PolyalthIa long folia) and 'big-bang' (production of a large number of fruits over a short period, e.g. Ficus religiosa) phenological patterns (Gentry 1974).
column34: Elangovan, V., G. Marimuthu, and. H. Kunz. 1999. Temporal patterns of individual and group foraging behaviour in the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx, in south India. Journal of Tropical Ecology, 15: 681- 687.

column23: We observed bats foraging on ten species of fruit trees near the Madurai Kam- araj University campus (9?58'N, 78?10'E) for 121 nights between May 1996 and January 1998. The fruit-bearing species that we observed included Annona squamosa (nine nights), PolyalthIa longifolia (18 nights), Polyalthia pendula (16 nights), Achras sapota (six nights), Calophyllum inophyllum (24 nights), Coccinia indica (14 nights), Terminalia catappa (11 nights), Ficus religiosa (five nights), Ficus benjamina (11 nights) and Ficus bengalensis (seven nights). The three species of Ficus have a big-bang fruiting pattern, whereas the other seven plant species exhibit a steady state fruiting pattern (Gentry 1974). The number of feeding bouts of Cynopterus sphinx was recorded every hour continuously between 18h00 and 05hOO, resulting in c. 1331 h of observation. A typical feeding bout resulted in a bat collecting a part or a whole fruit in its mouth
column34: Elangovan, V., G. Marimuthu, and. H. Kunz. 1999. Temporal patterns of individual and group foraging behaviour in the short-nosed fruit bat, Cynopterus sphinx, in south India. Journal of Tropical Ecology, 15: 681- 687.

column23: Summer day roosts used by P. auritus are most commonly found in buildings, and bats are often visible in the attic spaces of houses, churches and barns (Swift 1991).

column23: Other roosts that may be used by this species include bat boxes (Boyd & Stebbings 1989) and tree holes (Hanak 1969), although the extent to which such structures are used as maternity sites in Britain is unknown.
column34: Entwistle, A. C., P. A. Racey, and J. R. Speakman. 1997. Roost selection by the brown long-eared bat (Plecotus auritus). Journal of Applied Ecology, 34: 399-408.

column14: west of Aberdeen in north-east (570N), and was enclosed by a rectangle that extended 60 km west from Aberdeen. It measured 35 km north to south, and contained a land area of 2100 square kilometres (the balance of the rectangle enclosing the sea). A second study site lay 45km further west, and enclosed 975 square kilometres along the valley of the river Spey.
column23: A total of 54 summer day roosts of P. auritus were identified within the two study areas, and all of these buildings were visited. Thirty-nine of these roosts had been identified during surveys carried out prior to 1988 (Speakman et al. 1991), and an additional five roosts had been reported to Scottish Natural Heritage (the statutory nature conservation agency) after 1988.
column34: Entwistle, A. C., P. A. Racey, and J. R. Speakman. 1997. Roost selection by the brown long-eared bat (Plecotus auritus). Journal of Applied Ecology, 34: 399-408.

column14: west of Aberdeen in north-east (570N), and was enclosed by a rectangle that extended 60 km west from Aberdeen. It measured 35 km north to south, and contained a land area of 2100 square kilometres (the balance of the rectangle enclosing the sea). A second study site lay 45km further west, and enclosed 975 square kilometres along the valley of the river Spey.
column23: All the roosts were situated within buildings. In most cases, the bats roosted in the apex of attic spaces, or equivalent spaces in steadings (farm buildings of stone construction), usually in direct contact with the wooden beams. In addition, the bats sometimes roos- ted in smaller, less accessible, compartments that com- municated with the primary roof area. The majority of roosts were found within occupied houses (n = 48), but two churches and four unoccupied steadings were also used.
column34: Entwistle, A. C., P. A. Racey, and J. R. Speakman. 1997. Roost selection by the brown long-eared bat (Plecotus auritus). Journal of Applied Ecology, 34: 399-408.

column23: Most of the roosts (n = 43) were occupied by maternity colonies, as determined by the regular pres- ence of bats, including pregnant or lactating females.

column23: P. auritus forages in woodland habitats (Swift & Racey 1983; Barataud 1990; Swift 1991) where insect prey, particularly moths, are available.
column34: Entwistle, A. C., P. A. Racey, and J. R. Speakman. 1997. Roost selection by the brown long-eared bat (Plecotus auritus). Journal of Applied Ecology, 34: 399-408.

column14: The Gresswell Nature Conservation Reserve (GresswellNCR), (Latitude:–37.72, Longitude: 145.05), Melbourne, Victoria
column23: In January and February 2007, immediately following thebreeding season for C. gouldii , 15 adult bats were collected,during the day, from nest boxes within the reserve. The sixmale and nine female C. gouldii (testes-abdominal andpost-lactating respectively) were fitted with LB-2, 0.6 gradio transmitters (Holohil Systems Ltd, Ontario, Canada), which weighed less than 5% of the bat’s bodymass (13–17 g), as recommended by Aldridge andBrigham (1988).
column34: Evans LN, Lumsden LF. A comparison of the roosting behaviour of Gould’s wattled bats Chalinolobus gouldii using bat boxes and tree hollows in suburban Melbourne. The Biology and Conservation of Australasian Bats’.(Eds B. Law, P. Eby, D. Lunney, and L. Lumsden.) pp. 2011 Jan 1:288-96.

column14: The Gresswell Nature Conservation Reserve (GresswellNCR), (Latitude:–37.72, Longitude: 145.05), Melbourne, Victoria
column23: We located 22 day roosts used by bats during the 138 battracking days between January and March 2007 (Table1). Of these, 10 were in tree hollows and 12 in bat boxes.
column34: Evans LN, Lumsden LF. A comparison of the roosting behaviour of Gould’s wattled bats Chalinolobus gouldii using bat boxes and tree hollows in suburban Melbourne. The Biology and Conservation of Australasian Bats’.(Eds B. Law, P. Eby, D. Lunney, and L. Lumsden.) pp. 2011 Jan 1:288-96.

column14: The Gresswell Nature Conservation Reserve (GresswellNCR), (Latitude:–37.72, Longitude: 145.05), Melbourne, Victoria
column23: We located 22 day roosts used by bats during the 138 battracking days between January and March 2007 (Table1). Of these, 10 were in tree hollows and 12 in bat boxes...All roosts in tree hollowswere in E. camaldulensis, with 70% of these in dead spouts in large live trees (Figure 2). The remaining three roosts were: in a central, vertically opening hollow in a live tree, used by a solitary female; in a hollow in a major branch of a large tree (> 1 m DBH [diameter at breast height]),used by a solitary female; and under loose bark on a small stag (< 30 cm DBH), used by a solitary male.
column34: Evans LN, Lumsden LF. A comparison of the roosting behaviour of Gould’s wattled bats Chalinolobus gouldii using bat boxes and tree hollows in suburban Melbourne. The Biology and Conservation of Australasian Bats’.(Eds B. Law, P. Eby, D. Lunney, and L. Lumsden.) pp. 2011 Jan 1:288-96.

column14: approximately 400 m from the Gresswell NCR boundary, The Gresswell Nature Conservation Reserve (GresswellNCR), (Latitude:–37.72, Longitude: 145.05), Melbourne, Victoria
column23: Four individuals were recorded in night roosts. Two females used separate liveE. camaldulensis trees; both located approximately 400 mfrom the Gresswell NCR boundary and about 450 mfrom their day roost. These night roosts were not used bythese females as day roosts during the tracking period.Two males were recorded roosting in bat boxes that theyalso used as day roosts.

column23: Parasite loads in the bat boxes were recorded by counting the number of ticks( Argas dewae ) and bat fly pupae ( Basilia troughtoni ), both of which are known to parasitise C. gouldii , and spend atleast part of their life cycle within the roost (unlike spinturnicid mites that are located permanently on the animal).
